    transform: translateX(100px) scale(0.5);

  to {
    transform: translateX(0px) scale(1);

    googletag.cmd.push(function () {
        var sizes = {
            leaderboard: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([320, 100], [[300, 50], [320, 50]])
                .addSize([740, 100], [728, 90])
                .addSize([0, 0], 'fluid')
                .build(),
            mobileleaderboard: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([300, 100], [300, 50])
                .addSize([320, 100], [320, 50])
                .build(),
            mobilefooter: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([0, 0], [300, 50])
                .addSize([0, 0], [320, 50])
                .build(),
            rail: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([0, 0], [300, 250])
                .build(),
            interstitial: googletag.sizeMapping()
                .addSize([0, 0], [640, 480])
                .build()
        };

        gptPage = window.digitalData && digitalData.page && digitalData.page.page ? digitalData.page.page : "blank";
        gptSubPage = window.digitalData && digitalData.page && digitalData.page.subPage ? digitalData.page.subPage : "blank";

        function gptClean(gptText) {
            if (typeof (gptText) == "string") {
                gptText = gptText.replace(/\&/g, '%26');
                return gptText.replace(/\^|\*|#|\$|\"|\'|\=|\,|\!|\+|\~|\;|\(|\)|\<|\>|\[|\]|\?|\%|\:|\@|\;|\&|\||\{|\}|\\|/g, '');
            }
            return "blank";
        }

        googletag.pubads()
            .setTargeting('property', 'value-of-property')    // Change and duplicate this line for as many additional keywords to send
            .setTargeting('doi', gptClean('10.1002/aenm.202303833')) // Publication DOI
            .setTargeting('pbPage', gptClean(gptPage))
            .setTargeting('pbSubPage', gptClean(gptSubPage))
            .setTargeting('urlpath', gptClean(document.location.pathname));

        googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-leaderboard')
            .defineSizeMapping(sizes.leaderboard)
            .addService(googletag.pubads())
            .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        // googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-mobileleaderboard')
        //     .defineSizeMapping(sizes.mobileleaderboard)
        //     .addService(googletag.pubads())
        //     .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-mobileleaderboard')
        //     .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        // googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-mobilefooter')
        //     .defineSizeMapping(sizes.mobilefooter)
        //     .addService(googletag.pubads())
        //     .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-mobilefooter')
        //     .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-rail-1')
            .defineSizeMapping(sizes.rail)
            .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-rail-1')
            .addService(googletag.pubads())
            .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-rail-2')
            .defineSizeMapping(sizes.rail)
            .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-rail-2')
            .addService(googletag.pubads())
            .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);

        // googletag.defineSlot($GooglePublisherCategory, 'fluid', 'advert-video')
        //     .defineSizeMapping(sizes.interstitial)
        //     .setTargeting('Position', 'advert-video')
        //     .addService(googletag.pubads())
        //     .setCollapseEmptyDiv(true);


        // googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();


        if(isProgrammaticAdsEnabled) {
            // PERICLES-17135
            googletag.pubads().disableInitialLoad();
        }

        googletag.enableServices();
    });

    if(isProgrammaticAdsEnabled) {
        googletag.cmd.push(function () {
            apstag.fetchBids({timeout: 2000}, function (bids) {
                apstag.setDisplayBids();
                googletag.pubads().refresh();
            });
        });
    }
</script>

    <!-- Get whether TNSI is in live or test mode -->
    
    <!-- Get the configured TNSI Javascript version number -->
    
    <!-- Get the configured TNSI MerchantID -->
    
    <!-- Add "TEST" to beginning of merchant ID when running in test mode -->
    

    
<!-- loading Javascript for using the persistence Service -->
    <script src="/templates/jsp/pb2/js/plugin/thiss-ds.js" nonce="b9598e2498a54461a8e7826b81a83701"></script>

    <script type="text/javascript" nonce="b9598e2498a54461a8e7826b81a83701">

        function getParameter(parameterName) {
            let result = null,
                tmp = [];
            location.search
                .substr(1)
                .split("&")
                .forEach(function (item) {
                    tmp = item.split("=");
                    if (tmp[0] === parameterName) result = tmp[1];
                });
            return result;
        }

        var SeamlessAccessService = {
            spUrl: "/action/ssostart",
            returnURL: window.location.href,
            my_context: 'seamlessaccess.org',
            queryParamsDelimiter: encodeURIComponent('?'),

            getWAYFLessUrl: function (entityId) {
                let redirectURL = getParameter('redirectUri');
                if(redirectURL == null){
                    redirectURL = encodeURIComponent(this.returnURL);
                }
                if(redirectURL.indexOf('saml_referrer') < 0){
                    redirectURL += encodeURIComponent(((redirectURL.indexOf(this.queryParamsDelimiter) !== -1) ? '&' : '?') + 'saml_referrer');
                }
                return this.spUrl + "?idp=" + encodeURIComponent(entityId)
                    + "&redirectUri=" + redirectURL;
            },
            retrieveEntity: function () {
                var self = this;
                var ps = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    ps.entities(self.my_context)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            // get the results
                            var results = res.data;
                            return resolve(results);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            reject('retrieve entity error: ' + err);
                        });
                });
            },
            updateEntity: function (entitydata) {
                var self = this;
                var ps = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                var jsonObj = {};
                try {
                    //try to parse it, if it is a json string
                    jsonObj = JSON.parse(entitydata.val());
                } catch (e) {
                    jsonObj = entitydata;
                }
                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    ps.update(self.my_context, jsonObj)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            // Process the results
                            var ssoInstitutions = res.data;
                            return resolve(ssoInstitutions);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            console.log('failed to update the local storage duo to: ' + err);
                            reject(err);
                        });
                })
            },
            removeEntity: function (entityId) {
                var self = this;
                var persistService = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                return new Promise(function (resolve) {
                    persistService.remove(self.my_context, entityId)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            return resolve(res);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            console.log('failed to remove from local storage duo to: ' + err);
                        });
                })
            },
            getAccessibleEntityStatus: function (doi, entityId, entityTitle) {
                return new Promise(function (resolve) {
                    $.ajax({
                        type: 'POST',
                        url: '/action/seamlessAccess',
                        accept: {
                            text: "application/json"
                        },
                        data: {doi: doi, entityid: entityId, entityTitle: entityTitle, eventGroupKey: 'ea61f0a8-2988-4fde-989a-429ed35bbcbd'}

                    }).done(function (status) {
                        return resolve(status);
                    });
                });
            },
            getEntitiesWithAllInfo: function (doi) {
                let self = this,
                    arrayOfPromises = [];
                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    self.retrieveEntity().then(function (res) {
                        let allSsoInstitutions = res;
                        for (let i in allSsoInstitutions) {
                            let ssoInstitution = allSsoInstitutions[i];
                            arrayOfPromises.push(new Promise(function (resolve) {
                                self.getAccessibleEntityStatus(doi, ssoInstitution.entity.entityID, ssoInstitution.entity.title)
                                    .then(function (entityStatus) {
                                        resolve({
                                            entityID: ssoInstitution.entity.entityID,
                                            entityTitle: ssoInstitution.entity.title,
                                            entityStatusObj: entityStatus,
                                            entitySsoUrl: self.getWAYFLessUrl(ssoInstitution.entity.entityID)
                                        });
                                    }, function (err) {
                                        console.log('failed to get the entity status: ' + err);
                                    });
                            }));
                        }
                        Promise.all(arrayOfPromises)
                            .then(function (finalResponse) {
                                resolve(finalResponse);
                            });

                    }).catch(function (err) {
                        reject(err);
                    })
                });
            }
        };

        window.addEventListener('load', function () {
            document.querySelectorAll(".sso-institution").forEach(function (institution) {
                var entityId = institution.getAttribute('data-entityid');
                var entityName = institution.getAttribute('data-name');
                var entitydata = {
                    entityID: entityId,
                    title: entityName
                };
                institution.addEventListener("click", function (e) {
                    e.preventDefault();
                    var self = this;
                    SeamlessAccessService.updateEntity(entitydata).then(function (res) {
                        console.log(res);
                        window.location.href = self.href;
                    }).catch(function (err){
                        window.location.href = self.href;
                    });
                });
            });
        });

    </script>

            (function() {
                function isBrowserChrome() {
                    return /Chrome/.test(navigator.userAgent) && /Google Inc/.test(navigator.vendor);
                }

                if (isBrowserChrome()) {
                    const originTrialToken = 'AkNzJOW9KcqV6Qlbg96xP2jqRsvzla/CKZY+FSKbiPtVTSST6mhuoiD7RFVzdtCrn2wI4LU0tmr8jf521BokXgkAAACJeyJvcmlnaW4iOiJodHRwczovL29ubGluZWxpYnJhcnkud2lsZXkuY29tOjQ0MyIsImZlYXR1cmUiOiJEaXNhYmxlVGhpcmRQYXJ0eVN0b3JhZ2VQYXJ0aXRpb25pbmczIiwiZXhwaXJ5IjoxNzU3OTgwODAwLCJpc1N1YmRvbWFpbiI6dHJ1ZX0=';
                    const originTrialMetaTag = document.createElement('meta');
                    originTrialMetaTag.httpEquiv = 'origin-trial';
                    originTrialMetaTag.content = originTrialToken;
                    document.head.append(originTrialMetaTag);
                }
            })();

    <script type="text/javascript" nonce="b9598e2498a54461a8e7826b81a83701">
        (function() {
            function riskifiedBeaconLoad() {
                var store_domain = 'https://advanced.onlinelibrary.wiley.com';
                var session_id = '7F6E4EF619CDEA64E4E45B2B4CE25BCA';
                var url = ('https:' == document.location.protocol ? 'https://' : 'http://')
                    + "beacon.riskified.com?shop=" + store_domain + "&sid=" + session_id;
                var s = document.createElement('script');
                s.type = 'text/javascript';
                s.async = true;
                s.src = url;
                var x = document.getElementsByTagName('script')[0];
                x.parentNode.insertBefore(s, x);
            }
            if (window.attachEvent)
                window.attachEvent('onload', riskifiedBeaconLoad)
            else
                window.addEventListener('load', riskifiedBeaconLoad, false);
        })();
    </script>

                     <p>Université de Strasbourg, Strasbourg, F-67081 France</p>
                     <p>Réseau sur le Stockage Electrochimique de l'Energie (RS2E), CNRS FR3459, 33 Rue Saint Leu, Cedex, Amiens, 80039 France</p>
                     <p>E-mail: <a class="corr-email" title="Link to email address" href="mailto:camelia.ghimbeu@uha.fr"><span>camelia.ghimbeu@uha.fr</span></a></p><a class="moreInfoLink" href="/authored-by/Matei+Ghimbeu/Cam%C3%A9lia">Search for more papers by this author</a></div></span><span class="accordion-tabbed__tab-mobile  accordion__closed"><a href="/authored-by/Beda/Adrian" class="author-name accordion-tabbed__control" data-id="a2" data-db-target-for="a2" aria-controls="a2" aria-haspopup="true" id="a2_Ctrl" role="button"><span>Adrian Beda</span><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-section_arrow_d"></i></a><span class="comma-separator">,&nbsp;</span><div class="author-info accordion-tabbed__content" data-db-target-of="a2" aria-labelledby="a2_Ctrl" role="region" id="a2">

   <div class="abstract-group ">
      <section class="article-section article-section__abstract" lang="en" data-lang="en" lang-name="English" id="section-1-en">
         <h2 id="d154663442" class="article-section__header section__title main abstractlang_en main">Abstract</h2>
         <div class="article-section__content en main">
            
            <p>Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have attracted a significant amount of interest in the past decade as a credible alternative to the lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) widely used today. The abundance of sodium, along with the potential utilization of electrode materials without critical elements in their composition, led to the intensification of research on SIBs. Hard carbon (HC), is identified as the most suitable negative electrode for SIBs. It can be obtained by pyrolysis of eco-friendly and renewable precursors, such as biomasses, biopolymers or synthetic polymers. Distinct HC properties can be obtained by tuning the precursors and the synthesis conditions, with a direct impact on the performance of SIBs. In this work, an in-depth overview of how the synthesis parameters of HC affect their properties (porosity, structure, morphology, surface chemistry, and defects) is provided. Several synthesis-property relationships are established based on a database created using extensive literature data. Moreover, HC properties are correlated with the electrochemical performance (initial Coulombic efficiency (iCE) and reversible capacity) vs. Na, in half-cells. The Na-ion storage mechanisms and solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation are discussed along with the HC performance in full-cell devices, as well as the SIB prototypes and a short history of SIBs enterprises.</p>
            </div>
      </section>
   </div>
   <div class="pb-dropzone" data-pb-dropzone="below-abstract-group"><!-- Empty dropzone --></div>
   
   <section class="article-section article-section__full">
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0010">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202303833-sec-0010-title">1 Introduction</h2>
         
         <p>Renewable energy resources (e.g., wind, solar, and geothermal) and the implementation of zero-emission electric vehicles have gained considerable popularity over the last 5 years<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0001" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0001_R_d154663148e634" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 1">1</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> as viable solutions to limit carbon dioxide emissions. The development of efficient, inexpensive, and improved mobile and stationary energy storage systems (ESSs) is crucial for the next step of the energy transition. The expected increase in population growth of 2 billion in the next 20 years<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0002" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0002_R_d154663148e639" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 2">2</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and industrial development contribute to the increased demand for ESSs. The role of batteries in the economic and environmental landscape will play a key role in the future (&gt;2030) thanks to their potential to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by ≈60%<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0003" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0003_R_d154663148e644" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 3 - Sustainability">3</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0004" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0004_R_d154663148e644" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 4 - Joule">4</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and global warming effects by 1.0 °C.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0005" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0005_R_d154663148e650" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 5">5</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0006" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0006_R_d154663148e650" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 6 - ACS Energy Lett.">6</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Today, Li-ion batteries (LIBs) are considered one of the most advanced technologies for energy storage with wide applications in different fields, such as electronics, telecommunication, and transport. Taking into account different scenarios, the implementation of LIBs in zero-emission electric vehicles (EV) will significantly increase their demand by 2030 to reach an order of magnitude larger than today (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0001">1a</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0007" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0007_R_d154663148e663" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 7">7</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In parallel, the implementation of stationary grid installations that are able to store and deliver intermittent renewable energy from solar, wind, and/or tides will also increase. Therefore, the development of both electric vehicles and stationary large-scale ESSs will play a crucial role in transport decarbonization and storage of excess renewable energy. Consequently, lithium availability is becoming a serious limitation due to a lack of resources, which has been estimated to be insufficient to satisfy the overall demands by 2030.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0008" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0008_R_d154663148e668" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 8 - Conservation Lett.">8</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, the main battery component resources (cobalt (Co), copper (Cu), and graphite (G)) are unequally localized worldwide (e.g., 70% in non-EU countries<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0009" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0009_R_d154663148e674" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 9 - Chem. Rev.">9</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), while their depletion (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0001">1b</a>)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0010" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0010_R_d154663148e682" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 10 - J. Cleaner Prod.">10</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> has raised serious concern over the last decade.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0011" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0011_R_d154663148e688" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 11">11</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0012" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0012_R_d154663148e688" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 12 - J. Cleaner Prod.">12</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0001"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/70bef6ea-3332-4b58-9e4e-cd92a1a1f86c/aenm202303833-fig-0001-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/70bef6ea-3332-4b58-9e4e-cd92a1a1f86c/aenm202303833-fig-0001-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/9bad9140-5a38-46e0-b4f2-fa16fca9af94/aenm202303833-fig-0001-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/70bef6ea-3332-4b58-9e4e-cd92a1a1f86c/aenm202303833-fig-0001-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 1<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0001&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Estimation of LIB energy demands over the next few years for different devices. Readapted from<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0007" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0007_R_d154663148e712" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 7">7</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> using the original source: BloombergNEF Avicenne, and b) the repartition of the main resources of battery components (Li, Ni, Co, graphite) across the world. Readapted from,<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0010" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0010_R_d154663148e717" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 10 - J. Cleaner Prod.">10</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> with permission, Copyright 2019, Elsevier.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <p>Alternative metal-based resources (LiOH vs. Li<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>) were explored,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0013" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0013_R_d154663148e729" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 13 - Resour. Conserv. Recycl..">13</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> along with the intensification of metal recycling after the end of battery life.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0014" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0014_R_d154663148e734" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 14 - Nature">14</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> These pathways alone are not sufficient to fulfill future requirements. Therefore, intensive efforts to overcome these limitations&nbsp;and to find long-lasting and sustainable alternative energy storage options for LIBs have been tremendously studied.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0015" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0015_R_d154663148e740" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 15 - New J. Chem.">15</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> New technologies based on sodium (Na), calcium (Ca), zinc (Zn), or aluminum (Al) ions are being developed, although they present many challenges. Among them, Na-ion batteries (SIBs) are considered one of the most promising.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0016" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0016_R_d154663148e745" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 16 - J. Alloys, Comp.">16</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>SIBs have attracted considerable attention in the last 10 years, and their development is highly motivated by the “unlimited” resources of Na in seawater and the promising electrochemical performance (see <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0002">2a</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0015" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0015_R_d154663148e758" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 15 - New J. Chem.">15</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0016" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0016_R_d154663148e758" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 16 - J. Alloys, Comp.">16</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The possibility of using a cheaper and lighter Al current collector (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0002">2b</a>) instead of Cu used in LIBs<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0017" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0017_R_d154663148e767" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 17 - ChemSusChem">17</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> is another advantage of this technology (<b>Table</b> <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0001">1</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0017" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0017_R_d154663148e777" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 17 - ChemSusChem">17</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0018" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0018_R_d154663148e777" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 18 - Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.">18</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, SIBs can be discharged close to 0 V (zero energy); therefore, they are safer for transportation than LIBs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0019" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0019_R_d154663148e783" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 19">19</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> On the other hand, Na<sup>+</sup> has a larger size compared to Li<sup>+</sup> (0.97 vs. 0.68 Å), a lower potential, and lower gravimetric capacity (Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0001">1</a>), which could lead to a lower energy density for SIBs than for LIBs, but higher energy density compared to the other alternative technologies&nbsp;(Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0002">2a</a>). Therefore, SIBs can be considered more suitable for applications where the weight requirement is less important, such as stationary grids for fluctuating renewable energy storage. These large devices require a large amount of materials, and thus, the cost and availability of the battery components involved are of paramount importance. Therefore, SIBs represent a feasible, cost-effective, and long-term energy storage alternative to accompany the fossil-to-renewable energy transition.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0002"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/64ec321c-07cf-491c-9635-6c9926319b63/aenm202303833-fig-0002-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/64ec321c-07cf-491c-9635-6c9926319b63/aenm202303833-fig-0002-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/0f780cbd-22f3-43ed-93c9-10a3690c6cda/aenm202303833-fig-0002-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/64ec321c-07cf-491c-9635-6c9926319b63/aenm202303833-fig-0002-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 2<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0002&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Comparison of the energy density of LIBs with different novel battery technologies (RMB: Mg-ion battery, SIB: Sodium-ion battery, CAB: Ca-ion battery, ZIB: Zn-ion battery, and Al-ion battery). Readapted from<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0016" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0016_R_d154663148e819" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 16 - J. Alloys, Comp.">16</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> with permission under the terms of CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 DEED license, Copyright 2019, The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. and b) scheme of a SIB, as proposed by the authors of this work.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <div class="article-table-content" id="aenm202303833-tbl-0001">

            </div>
            
            
            <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
         </div>
         
         <p>By shifting from LIB technology to SIB technology, the anode and cathode host materials traditionally used in LIBs are no longer efficient. In particular, Na insertion into graphite (the common anode of LIBs) led to a low storage capacity in SIBs (31 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> in carbonate ester-based electrolytes)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0020" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0020_R_d154663148e970" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 20 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">20</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> due to the weak interaction of Na with graphite<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0021" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0021_R_d154663148e975" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 21 - Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA">21</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and its narrow graphitic interlayer space (d<sub>002</sub>). By using ether-based electrolytes, the capacity of graphite can be increased (150 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0022" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0022_R_d154663148e985" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 22 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">22</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> due to the Na<sup>+</sup>-solvent co-intercalation, however, the performance is still insufficient for practical applications. Consequently, other types of carbon materials have been evaluated for SIBs, such as porous carbon, graphene, doped carbon, and hard carbon (HC). The latter has gained much interest as viable anode for SIBs due to their higher delivered capacity (≈300 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>). However, it remains a challenge to design sustainable and low-cost HCs that exhibit charge storage capacity with performance comparable to that of graphite anodes in LIBs (370 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0015" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0015_R_d154663148e997" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 15 - New J. Chem.">15</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>HCs display a structure composed of a mixture of disordered and pseudo-graphitic domains that are randomly oriented, with some micropores placed between them, resembling a “house of cards”, as proposed by Stevens and Dahn.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0023_R_d154663148e1004" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Carbon">23</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> They are produced by thermal pyrolysis of widely available precursors, such as biomass waste,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0024" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0024_R_d154663148e1009" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 24 - J. Mater. Chem. A">24</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0027" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0027_R_d154663148e1009" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 27 - Green Energy Environ.">27</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> biopolymers,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0028_R_d154663148e1014" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Carbon">28</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0031" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0031_R_d154663148e1014" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 31 - J. Energy Chem.">31</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and synthetic polymers.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0032" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0032_R_d154663148e1020" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 32 - Carbon">32</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0034" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0034_R_d154663148e1020" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 34 - Electrochim. Acta">34</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Usually, simple pyrolysis at temperatures between 1000 and 2000 °C, for a short time (one to few hours), in an oxygen-free atmosphere is sufficient to transform any of these parent materials into HCs. The lower temperature and duration of thermal treatment for the production of HC is advantageous compared to those for graphite (3000 °C for several weeks). Along with the eco-friendly, renewable, and cheaper HC resources (biomass/waste vs. petrochemical for graphite), the CO<sub>2</sub> footprint and price of HC should be lower than graphite. However, although the CO<sub>2</sub> footprint is lower for HC than graphite,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0035" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0035_R_d154663148e1030" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 35 - Philos. Trans. R. Soc. A.">35</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0036" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0036_R_d154663148e1030" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 36">36</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> the HC production market should be better developed to effectively benefit from lower-cost HC, its cost being currently two to three times higher than graphite.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0037" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0037_R_d154663148e1035" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 37 - J. Energy Storage">37</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0035" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0035_R_d154663148e1035" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 35 - Philos. Trans. R. Soc. A.">35</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Sometimes, however, a pre- or post-pyrolysis step is required to adjust the physico-chemical properties of the final product. The choice of the parent material is often primarily dictated by its abundance and cost and secondly by its chemical composition and structure, even if the latter two have an obvious influence on the physico-chemical properties and the yield of the resulting HC. In addition, the main HC properties are significantly impacted by the applied synthesis conditions (synthesis method, pyrolysis temperature, etc.).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0038" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0038_R_d154663148e1042" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 38 - ChemElectroChem">38</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0042" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0042_R_d154663148e1042" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 42 - J. Power Sources">42</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, the control of HC properties is of prime importance to achieve good electrochemical performance.</p>
         
         <p>A good compromise between the initial Coulombic Efficiency (iCE), reversible capacity, and long-term cyclability has been determined and can be achieved only when several carbon properties are reunited. The HC graphitic interlayer space, specific surface area (SSA), closed porosity, and surface functionalities have been shown to have an important role in dictating electrochemical performance. A clear relationship between the characteristics of HCs and their electrochemical performance (versus Na metal) is difficult to draw due to the lack of “standard protocols” (a standard procedure that can be used worldwide for battery assembly and testing) among different laboratories. Moreover, despite the differences between the materials used and various analytical techniques, some insightful observations have been made in the literature.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e1050" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e1050" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0046" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0046_R_d154663148e1050" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 46 - Adv. Energy Mater.">46</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, Na-ion storage in HCs is still controversial, and no consensus has been found so far. The proposed storage mechanisms include Na<sup>+</sup> adsorption in open pores and/or defects, Na<sup>+</sup> insertion between graphene layers, and/or Na<sup>+</sup> filling in closed pores.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0047" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0047_R_d154663148e1062" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 47 - Carbon Energy">47</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0048" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0048_R_d154663148e1062" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 48 - Energy Environ. Sci.">48</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, no common agreement has been reached on the attribution of these processes in a specific region (sloping/plateau) of the galvanostatic charge/discharge profile.</p>
         
         <p>Several review articles have been published on SIBs and have focused mainly on general aspects of battery components,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0049" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0049_R_d154663148e1071" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 49 - Chem. Soc. Rev">49</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0053" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0053_R_d154663148e1071" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 53 - Electrochem. Energy Rev.">53</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> on state-of-the-art anodes,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0018" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0018_R_d154663148e1076" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 18 - Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys.">18</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0054" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0054_R_d154663148e1076" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 54 - Energychem">54</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or more specifically on HC materials. Regarding the HC reviews, they have presented insights related to the synthesis, performance, and storage mechanisms in most cases,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0055" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0055_R_d154663148e1081" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 55 - Adv. Energy Mater.">55</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0058" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0058_R_d154663148e1081" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 58 - Prog. Energy">58</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and few have focused on specific topics, that is, hard carbon biomass,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0059" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0059_R_d154663148e1087" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 59 - C">59</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0060" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0060_R_d154663148e1087" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 60 - Mater. Technol.">60</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> the Coulombic efficiency of hard carbons<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0061" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0061_R_d154663148e1092" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 61 - Nano Materials Science">61</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and their storage mechanisms.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0047" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0047_R_d154663148e1098" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 47 - Carbon Energy">47</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This review attempts to provide a comprehensive view of how the synthesis conditions affect hard carbon properties and the electrochemical performance in SIBs. Several synthesis-property-performance relationships have been obtained for three classes of precursors (i.e., biomass, biopolymers, and synthetic polymers) and different pyrolysis temperatures (i.e., 600–2000 °C) by studying more than 300 scientific articles. Nevertheless, the Na-ion storage mechanisms and SEI formation are reviewed and are correlated to the hard carbon properties. The overall insights given within this review provide a clear picture of the optimal design of hard carbon anodes, of the key features of hard carbon to enhance the performance, and of further development required in this field.</p>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0020">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202303833-sec-0020-title">2 From Precursor to Hard Carbon</h2>
         
         <p>Based on many reports in the literature, hard carbons may be synthesized from a variety of inexpensive and readily available sources (<b>Tables</b> <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2</a>, <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0003">3</a> and <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0004">4</a>), which makes it economically viable and provides the opportunity to tailor its properties. These precursors can be classified into three main groups: raw biomass, biopolymers, and synthetic polymers. As shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0003">3a</a>, raw biomass dominates the precursors explored for hard carbon synthesis, accounting for ≈42%. This may be linked to the variety and accessibility of different wastes, such as trees, plants, and agriculture. Different publications have reported HC anodes obtained from a wide variety of biomass precursors (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0003">3b</a>), including corn cobs,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0062" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0062_R_d154663148e1133" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 62 - J. Mater. Chem. A">62</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0063" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0063_R_d154663148e1133" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 63 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">63</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> lotus,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0026" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0026_R_d154663148e1138" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 26 - J. Power Sources">26</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> various nut shells,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0024" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0024_R_d154663148e1144" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 24 - J. Mater. Chem. A">24</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0064" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0064_R_d154663148e1144" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 64 - Electrochim. Acta">64</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0065" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0065_R_d154663148e1144" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 65 - Nano Energy">65</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> pine,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0066" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0066_R_d154663148e1149" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 66 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">66</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and different tree woods.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0067" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0067_R_d154663148e1154" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 67 - Energy Storage Mater.">67</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0068" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0068_R_d154663148e1154" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 68 - J. Environ. Chem. Eng.">68</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, drawbacks, such as the high amount of inorganic impurities, the intrinsic complex structure, low carbon yield, and seasonal/geographical factors, make their use challenging in some cases.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0003"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/9c15cc3e-e386-4300-b176-045d479cd6fb/aenm202303833-fig-0003-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/9c15cc3e-e386-4300-b176-045d479cd6fb/aenm202303833-fig-0003-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/e674c471-5bbd-4877-b385-66473d9d55a8/aenm202303833-fig-0003-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/9c15cc3e-e386-4300-b176-045d479cd6fb/aenm202303833-fig-0003-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 3<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0003&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Graphical representation of different categories of precursors used to synthesize hard carbon materials: a) repartition of precursors (%) into three main categories and the raw materials used in each class of precursors: b) biomass, c) biopolymers, and d) synthetic polymers. The % are based on the studied publications listed in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <p>The second category of resources used for HC&nbsp;preparation, after biomass, is biopolymers, accounting for ≈32%; see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0003">3a</a>. These sustainable precursors are used to develop innovative materials for energy storage applications. Plant-derived biopolymers, such as sucrose,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0069" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0069_R_d154663148e1188" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 69 - Chem. Mater.">69</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> cellulose,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0031" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0031_R_d154663148e1193" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 31 - J. Energy Chem.">31</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> glucose,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0070" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0070_R_d154663148e1199" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 70 - Electrochim. Acta">70</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and lignin,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0071" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0071_R_d154663148e1204" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 71 - Carbon">71</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> are the main precursors used for the synthesis of HCs (≈81%); see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0003">3c</a>. However, animal-derived biopolymers (chitosan, chitin, or gelatine)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0029" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0029_R_d154663148e1213" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">29</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0072" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0072_R_d154663148e1213" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 72 - J. Mater. Chem. A">72</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have also been explored but to a relatively limited extent. Generally, biopolymers have a less complex composition than biomass and lower impurity content, and in some cases, they may present a high carbon yield that can reach ≈50% (in the case of lignin<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0030" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0030_R_d154663148e1218" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 30 - Carbon">30</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>).</p>
         
         <p>The last category of precursors is synthetic polymers, at ≈26% (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0003">3a</a>). The primary benefit of these precursors is their high adaptability to synthesize high-purity carbon materials at high carbon yields with regulated microstructures and morphologies. Various synthetic polymers are used to synthesize HC materials, such as pitch,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0073" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0073_R_d154663148e1229" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 73 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">73</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> polyvinyl chloride,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0074" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0074_R_d154663148e1234" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 74 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">74</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> polyacrylonitrile,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e1240" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and phenolic resin.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0038" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0038_R_d154663148e1245" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 38 - ChemElectroChem">38</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The latter alone accounts for a fifth of the polymeric precursors used for HC synthesis; see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0003">3d</a>. The great advantage of these polymers is their high carbon yield (≈50%) and their solubility in different solvents, which allow them to be used in wet chemistry to obtain different carbon architectures (fibers, spheres, etc.). However, most synthetic precursors have a negative environmental impact due to their petroleum-based feedstock and synthesis processes based on toxic precursors (phenol, formaldehyde). However, few reports of polymeric precursors obtained from natural resources and green synthesis routes are available in the literature.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0032" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0032_R_d154663148e1254" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 32 - Carbon">32</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> If at the academic level, the biosourced precursors (biomass + biopolymers) are mainly used for HC production (≈75% based on the review study presented herein), at an industrial level the petrochemical resources (synthetic polymers) are dominant (75%).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0037" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0037_R_d154663148e1259" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 37 - J. Energy Storage">37</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The advancements of Na-ion technology will certainly allow one to inverse this paradigm in the next years.</p>
         
         <p>From precursors to active materials, different strategies have been adapted to synthesize hard carbons depending on the precursor type and the desired final structure, morphology, and surface chemistry. The generally adopted routes for HC preparation are illustrated in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0004">4</a> and consist of pyrolysis processes under inert atmospheres (absence of oxygen), associated or not with a pre- and/or post-treatment. Whether on a laboratory or industrial scale, the simplest, fastest, and most economical way to obtain HCs is direct pyrolysis. The precursor source (e.g., biomass, biopolymer, or synthetic polymer) is usually heated in the range of 1000–1700 °C in the presence of an atmosphere of N<sub>2</sub> or Ar.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0031" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0031_R_d154663148e1274" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 31 - J. Energy Chem.">31</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0039" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0039_R_d154663148e1274" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 39 - Carbon">39</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0076" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0076_R_d154663148e1274" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 76 - J. Mater. Chem. A">76</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0077" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0077_R_d154663148e1274" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 77 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">77</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Some authors have reported higher pyrolysis temperatures of 2000–3000 °C.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0041" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0041_R_d154663148e1280" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 41 - Adv. Energy Mater.">41</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e1280" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0078" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0078_R_d154663148e1280" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 78 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">78</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0079" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0079_R_d154663148e1280" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 79 - J. Power Sources">79</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, the carbon structure is strongly affected, and the interlayer distance d<sub>002</sub> diminishes (≤ ≈0.34 nm), which impedes the intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> ions.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0004"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/cf0e52a5-6920-498d-b5dd-a3206cd45299/aenm202303833-fig-0004-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/cf0e52a5-6920-498d-b5dd-a3206cd45299/aenm202303833-fig-0004-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/87dbc1d0-4ccd-459b-87de-9038561cbec5/aenm202303833-fig-0004-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/cf0e52a5-6920-498d-b5dd-a3206cd45299/aenm202303833-fig-0004-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 4<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0004&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic representation of hard carbon synthesis based on pyrolysis, pre- and/or post-treatment processes, as proposed by the authors of this work.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <p>In addition to pyrolysis, pre- and/or post-treatments are widely applied during HC synthesis to adjust the properties of the material and thus achieve improved sodium storage. The pre-treatment process is used to control the structural, textural, chemical, and morphological properties of HC, and various strategies can be adopted.</p>
         
         <p>Carbon washing is one of the most common strategies used to remove inorganic and organic impurities from precursors, particularly biomass. Other pre-treatments are used to activate the carbon (increase its porosity) or dope it (introduce heteroatoms in its structure). For this purpose, acids (HCl,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0080" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0080_R_d154663148e1314" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 80 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">80</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0081" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0081_R_d154663148e1314" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 81 - J. Alloys, Comp.">81</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0082" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0082_R_d154663148e1323" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 82 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">82</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> HF,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0083" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0083_R_d154663148e1329" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 83 - Renewable Energy">83</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>4</sub><sup>84</sup>), bases (KOH,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0064" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0064_R_d154663148e1340" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 64 - Electrochim. Acta">64</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0085" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0085_R_d154663148e1340" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 85 - Carbon">85</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> NaOH,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0086" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0086_R_d154663148e1345" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 86 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">86</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0087" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0087_R_d154663148e1345" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 87 - ChemElectroChem">87</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) and solvents (water, acetone, and ethanol)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0024" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0024_R_d154663148e1350" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 24 - J. Mater. Chem. A">24</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0080" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0080_R_d154663148e1350" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 80 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">80</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0088" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0088_R_d154663148e1350" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 88 - Surf. Coating. Technol.">88</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> are used alone or by combining them in different steps. For example, Dahbi et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0024" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0024_R_d154663148e1356" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 24 - J. Mater. Chem. A">24</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized HC from argan shells and evaluated the influence of HCl acid washing pre-treatment on inorganic impurities (i.e., alkali and transition metals). Potassium impurities were successfully removed, while heavy metals (i.e., Ni, Co, Fe, Mn, and Zn) could not be eliminated. This treatment also leads to an increase in both C-yield (from 24 wt% to 32 wt%) and specific surface area (from 2.6 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> to 24 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>). Other pre-treatments that involve HF washing on pollen<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0066" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0066_R_d154663148e1370" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 66 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">66</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and rice husk<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0089" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0089_R_d154663148e1375" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 89 - Carbon">89</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> precursors were used to eliminate inorganic impurities from the structural composition of the obtained HC. Some greener ways to remove alkaline inorganic impurities involve&nbsp;the use of hot water.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0030" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0030_R_d154663148e1380" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 30 - Carbon">30</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Na-based impurities (Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>) could be efficiently removed by this treatment and allowed at the same time a decrease in the specific surface area from 180 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> to ≈6 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> and an improvement of electrochemical performance. Alkaline impurities (Na, K, and Ca-based) are known to favor the activation of carbon, therefore, their removal may limit the specific surface area development during pyrolysis. Dou et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0090" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0090_R_d154663148e1399" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 90 - ChemSusChem">90</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> showed that prolonged acid treatment improves the HC structure by creating crystalline domains at lower pyrolysis temperatures, thus reducing the synthesis costs. The authors used phosphoric acid (H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>) as a pre-treatment medium (1 to 14 days) for peanut shells, followed by pyrolysis (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0005">5a</a>). Longer acid treatment leads to modification of the macromolecular composition (e.g., lignin, cellulose, and hemicellulose), i.e., destruction of the basic structure of the precursor. This caused an increase in HC structural order (<i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> decreased from 1.41 to 1.20 and 0.98 for 1 day, 6 days, and 14 days of treatment, respectively) and resulted in mesoporosity.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0005"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/5cba4949-fd47-4cb7-9684-229c7fd7dcbe/aenm202303833-fig-0005-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/5cba4949-fd47-4cb7-9684-229c7fd7dcbe/aenm202303833-fig-0005-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/1bb62c8f-7411-4d18-968c-d0d9e61b699c/aenm202303833-fig-0005-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/5cba4949-fd47-4cb7-9684-229c7fd7dcbe/aenm202303833-fig-0005-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 5<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0005&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic representation of the main classes of pre-treatments and post-treatments used for hard carbon synthesis: a) washing, reproduced with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0090" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0090_R_d154663148e1440" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 90 - ChemSusChem">90</a></span>], Copyrights 2018, John Wiley and Sons, b) hydrothermal carbonization, reproduced from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0100" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0100_R_d154663148e1443" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 100 - Adv. Energy Mater.">100</a></span>] under the terms of CC BY 4.0 DEED license, Copyright 2022, The Authors. Published by Wiley-VCH GmbH, c) electrospinning, reproduced with the permission form Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0106" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0106_R_d154663148e1446" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 106 - Small">106</a></span>], Copyrights 2020, John Wiley and Sons, d) precipitation polymerization, reproduced with the permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e1449" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></span>], Copyrights 2021, Royal Society of Chemistry e) emulsion polymerization, reproduced with the permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0108" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0108_R_d154663148e1452" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 108 - Adv. Energy Mater.">108</a></span>], Copyrights 2016, John Wiley and Sons, f) thermal treatment, reproduced under the terms of CC BY 4.0 DEED license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0109" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0109_R_d154663148e1456" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 109 - Sustain. Mater., Technol.">109</a></span>], Copyright 2022. The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V. and g) ball milling, reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0110" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0110_R_d154663148e1459" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 110 - ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng.">110</a></span>]. Copyright 2019, American Chemical Society.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <p>The washing step is also used as a post-treatment after the synthesis of carbon to remove impurities. Zhang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0091" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0091_R_d154663148e1466" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 91 - RSC Adv.">91</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> demonstrated that post-treatment of pinecone-derived HC with an aqueous solution of KOH and then with HCl at 60 °C significantly eliminates HC inorganic impurities (Si-based) and therefore improves the C/O ratio (from ≈12 to ≈17). Several authors used a similar procedure of washing<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0092" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0092_R_d154663148e1471" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 92 - ACS Nano">92</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0093" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0093_R_d154663148e1471" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 93 - J. Phys. Chem. C">93</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and showed effective elimination of impurities, however, their type is not mentioned. Other post-treatments have also been used involving several acids, that is, HNO<sub>3</sub>/HCl<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0094" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0094_R_d154663148e1479" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 94 - Nano Energy">94</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> or H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>/HNO<sub>3</sub>/HCl.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0080" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0080_R_d154663148e1491" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 80 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">80</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Hydrothermal pre-treatment (or hydrothermal carbonization–HTC) is widely used to control the morphology of carbon and to avoid precursor volume expansion during pyrolysis. HTC consists of a low thermal treatment (180–230 °C) under the auto-generated pressure of a precursor dissolved or immersed in a solvent (generally water). Biopolymers, such as sucrose<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0095" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0095_R_d154663148e1498" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 95 - Adv. Energy Mater.">95</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0097" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0097_R_d154663148e1498" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 97 - Adv. Energy Mater.">97</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and glucose,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e1503" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0099" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0099_R_d154663148e1503" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 99 - Carbon">99</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> are the most commonly used for this purpose because of their high solubility and versatility for obtaining particles with different sizes and interconnectivity. For example,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0100" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0100_R_d154663148e1508" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 100 - Adv. Energy Mater.">100</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> glucose was treated at 200 °C for 12 h, followed by further pyrolysis (1000–1500 °C), and a spherical morphology (200 nm) was obtained compared to direct pyrolysis, producing irregular particles of varying sizes (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0005">5b</a>). Cellulose<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0101" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0101_R_d154663148e1517" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 101 - J. Mater. Chem. A">101</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and complex biomass (wood, lotus leaves, etc.),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0102" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0102_R_d154663148e1522" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 102 - J. Environ. Chem. Eng.">102</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0103" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0103_R_d154663148e1522" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 103 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">103</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> which are not soluble in water, have also been explored by HTC. Qatarneh et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0102" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0102_R_d154663148e1528" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 102 - J. Environ. Chem. Eng.">102</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> studied the impact of various driftwood biomasses (Alnus, Conifer, Fraxinus, Populus, and Salix), HTC temperatures (180, 200, and 220 °C), and HTC residence times (4, 6, and 12 h) on the properties and performance of the resulting hydrochar and HC. The produced hydrochar presented lower ash content than the raw biomass, and the C-yield and C amount were found to increase with temperature and residence time. However, the synthesis conditions did not lead to a significant difference in HC porosity or interlayer space, but primarily, differences in impurity level and morphologies were observed. The Alnus bark material which has the highest amount of impurity (CaCO<sub>3</sub> and CaC<sub>2</sub>) presented the lowest performance vs. Na<sup>+</sup>/Na, while the others reached a capacity of ≈300 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at C/10. Zheng and coauthors<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0104" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0104_R_d154663148e1542" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 104 - Sci. Rep.">104</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used a holly leaf precursor by HTC at 160 °C for 10 h followed by a pyrolysis step at 800 °C. This led to larger open nanopores (1.1 nm) compared to directly pyrolyzed precursors (0.5 nm) and improved Na-ion storage capacity.</p>
         
         <p>Another synthesis pathway explored is electrospinning. Typically, a solution of polymer is passed through a metallic needle submitted to a high voltage (15-20 kV), which allows one to obtain a polymer film with fibrous morphology. One of the most widely used polymers is polyacrylonitrile (PAN) dissolved in <i>N</i>,<i>N</i>-dimethylformamide. Zhao et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0105" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0105_R_d154663148e1554" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 105 - J. Power Sources">105</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used the PAN polymer and fulvic acid to fabricate electrospun HC nanofibers in a pyrolysis range between 800 and 1500 °C. The material made at 1300 °C had the highest reversible sodium capacity (248 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 100 mA g<sup>−1</sup>). They associated these results with the rich oxygen functional groups, large interlayer spaces, and stable morphologies compared to those of other materials. In another work,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e1564" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> PAN was used to obtain binder-free and self-standing HC films in a wide temperature range of 650 °C to 2800 °C. It is worth mentioning that PAN polymers require a stabilization step at low temperatures (≈200–300 °C) prior to the pyrolysis step to increase cyclization and avoid the melting of PAN during the thermal treatment. The authors studied the Na-ion mechanisms in these materials and identified three distinct mechanisms, depending on the temperature range. At low temperatures (650–950 °C), adsorption mechanisms with O and N functional groups, active sites and porosity are predominant; at intermediate temperatures, (1100–1550 °C), a combined mechanism based on adsorption and insertion between graphene layers has been proposed, while at high temperature (2000–2800 °C), a closed pore-filling mechanism has been suggested. The best temperature range was found to be the intermediate-range since it allows the benefit of two mechanisms, i.e., adsorption and insertion. Ding et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0106" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0106_R_d154663148e1569" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 106 - Small">106</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> combined a PAN polymer with melamine (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0005">5c</a>) to obtain a flexible carbon nanofabric with high performance in SIBs that was suitable for the development of wearable devices. Bai et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0074" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0074_R_d154663148e1578" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 74 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">74</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used polyvinyl chloride (PVC) in tetrahydrofuran and dimethylformamide solvents to prepare PVC nanofibers at 600−800 °C. The materials delivered a higher reversible capacity (271 vs. 206 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>) and higher iCE (69.9% vs. 60.9%) than materials obtained by direct pyrolysis of PVC. Furthermore, good cycling stability and rate performance were demonstrated by the electrospun HC. Another approach involved the use of electrospinning to synthesize polycaprolactone nanofibers, which served as a template to obtain N-doped hollow porous carbon nanofibers, through the polymerization of polycaprolactone and polypyrrole.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0107" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0107_R_d154663148e1585" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 107 - RSC Adv.">107</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The as-prepared material exhibited a reversible capacity of 160 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles at a current density of 0.05 A g<sup>−1</sup>.</p>
         
         <p>Polymerization reactions have also been widely explored for HC synthesis. The approach most often involves the synthesis of phenolic resins. Hasegawa et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0111" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0111_R_d154663148e1599" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 111 - ChemElectroChem">111</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used a sol-gel process to synthesize resorcinol-formaldehyde (RF) gels and subsequently thermal pyrolysis at high temperatures (800–3000 °C) to obtain HC materials. The iCE was significantly increased between 800 and 1600 °C and then remained stable at a high value (≈92%) at elevated temperatures. The authors explained that the higher temperature renders HC less porous and less defective, which effectively improves the iCE. The reversible capacity increases to ≈350 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> up to 2000 °C and then decreases significantly at 2500 and 3000 °C. Using similar RF resins, the same authors fabricated binder-free monolithic electrodes with tuned macropore sizes by varying the volume of ethanol solvent in the reaction mixture.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0079" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0079_R_d154663148e1606" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 79 - J. Power Sources">79</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> They showed that improvement of the iCE requires a decrease in the surface area related to mesopores and macropores.
