Qiu et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0046" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0046_R_d154663148e1612" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 46 - Adv. Energy Mater.">46</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used phenol with formaldehyde polymerization in the presence and absence of a soft template (Pluronic F127) to obtain nonporous and micro-mesoporous carbon. They observed different electrochemical behaviors; a sloping and plateau region was observed in the galvanostatic charge–discharge curves for nonporous material, and only the sloping region was observed in the case of porous carbon. Based on these results, they concluded that the plateau region is not related to the Na filling of pores. Wang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0112" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0112_R_d154663148e1617" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 112 - J. Alloys, Comp.">112</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized codoped phosphorus/sulfur HC using a resorcinol-formaldehyde resin, a hard silica sacrificial template, and P-red and S powders as doping agents. The materials showed high Na-ion storage performance, i.e., a high iCE of 88.7%, a high-reversible capacity of ≈450 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 140 cycles at 0.2 A g<sup>−1</sup> and long-term cycling stability of 276 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> after 3000 cycles at 10 A g<sup>−1</sup>. The doping of S increased the interlayer spacing of graphite, while the doping of P promoted the formation of C-S-P and P-O bonds, which can contribute to abundant structural defects, and the presence of redox reaction sites contributes to capacitive reactions at a high rate and stability.</p>
         
         <p>Some works reported the use of phenol-formaldehyde phenolic resin followed by a pre-oxidation treatment in air at low temperatures (&lt;300 °C) before the pyrolysis step.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0113" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0113_R_d154663148e1634" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 113 - Mater. Chem. Front.">113</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0114" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0114_R_d154663148e1634" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 114 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">114</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This treatment allows better cross-linking of the phenolic resin and, therefore, a lower specific surface area of the resulting HC but also introduces several oxygen functionalities, which lead to a more disordered structure and larger graphitic interlayer space. These properties induced improved Na-ion storage performance. As most phenolic resin synthesis relies on toxic phenol or formaldehyde precursors, much greener precursors, such as phloroglucinol, tannin and glyoxylic acid, have been proposed (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0005">5d</a>), with obtained HC materials showing high performance vs. Na<sup>+</sup>/Na (e.g., iCE of ≈92% and reversible capacity of ≈300 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> at C/10).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0032" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0032_R_d154663148e1647" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 32 - Carbon">32</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e1647" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0115" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0115_R_d154663148e1647" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 115 - J. Mater. Chem. A">115</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>Other polymers, such as polyaniline (PANI), have also been used to obtain HC materials. Cao et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0116" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0116_R_d154663148e1654" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 116 - Nano Lett.">116</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized hollow carbon nanowires through the pyrolysis of a hollow PANI nanowire precursor. The latter was obtained by polymerization and self-assembly of aniline molecules with DL-tartaric acid micelles, which acted as a sacrificial template. The material delivered a reversible capacity of 251 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> vs. Na<sup>+</sup>/Na and a capacity retention of 82.2% over 400 cycles. The good Na-ion insertion was associated with the short diffusion distance provided by the carbon nanowire and the large interlayer distance (0.37 nm) between the graphitic sheets. Based on theoretical calculations, the authors concluded that such an interlayer distance ensures Na-ion insertion in carbon materials. In another work,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0117" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0117_R_d154663148e1663" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 117 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">117</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> polymerization of aniline in the presence of a calcium carbonate (CaCO<sub>3</sub>) template, followed by acid washing and carbonization, resulted in the formation of nitrogen-rich mesoporous carbon. The as-obtained material delivered a higher capacity (338 vs. ≈213 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 30 mA g<sup>−1</sup>) and better iCE (54.2% vs. 49.6%), compared to its counterpart prepared in the absence of CaCO<sub>3</sub>. The better sodium storage performance of the nitrogen-rich mesoporous carbon was attributed to the disordered structure having a large interlayer distance, the interconnected porosity, and the richer surface chemistry in nitrogen. N/S co-doped carbon microspheres were obtained using cellulose/PANI precursors via an emulsion polymerization pathway (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0005">5e</a>) in the presence of dodecyl benzene sulfonic acid (DBSA), which served as the S-source.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0108" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0108_R_d154663148e1681" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 108 - Adv. Energy Mater.">108</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The N and S heteroatoms induced defects and expanded the interlayer space in the carbon structure, favoring Na storage. Therefore, a high capacity (280 mA h g <sup>−1</sup> at 30 mA g<sup>−1</sup>) and long cycle life of more than 3000 cycles has been reported for such materials. Petrochemical-derived pitch was also used for the synthesis of HC; however, pre-oxidation treatments or mixtures with precursors containing oxygen (lignin, phenolic resin or reduced graphite oxide) have been used to avoid the graphitization of pitch and formation of soft carbon.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0118" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0118_R_d154663148e1690" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 118 - Fuel Process. Technol.">118</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0121" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0121_R_d154663148e1690" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 121 - Chem. Eng. J.">121</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
         
         <p>In several works, thermal pre-treatments, such as oxidation,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0084" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0084_R_d154663148e1697" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 84 - Mater. Tod. Energ.">84</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0109" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0109_R_d154663148e1697" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 109 - Sustain. Mater., Technol.">109</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0122" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0122_R_d154663148e1697" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 122 - Carbon">122</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> pre-carbonization,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0094" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0094_R_d154663148e1702" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 94 - Nano Energy">94</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0123" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0123_R_d154663148e1702" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 123 - Electrochim. Acta">123</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and dehydration,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0028_R_d154663148e1707" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Carbon">28</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0124" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0124_R_d154663148e1707" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 124 - J. Energy Chem.">124</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have been explored to modify the carbon properties (interlayer space, functionalities, and porosity), to increase the C-yield, or to avoid expansion of the precursor during the pyrolysis step (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0005">5f</a>).</p>
         
         <p>Most post-treatments involve washing with different chemicals to remove inorganic impurities (alkali and transition-metal based: carbonates, hydroxides, and oxides), as described above. Other treatments, such as activation, intend to increase the porosity of the carbon. Chemical activation (KOH)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0125" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0125_R_d154663148e1719" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 125 - Nanoscale">125</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and physical activation (with CO<sub>2</sub> and air)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0028_R_d154663148e1726" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Carbon">28</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0126" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0126_R_d154663148e1726" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 126 - ASC Nano.">126</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> are used for this purpose. Using a sucrose precursor and activation process with CO<sub>2</sub> under different conditions, Bommier et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0028_R_d154663148e1734" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Carbon">28</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> obtained a series of porous materials that showed evidence of a relationship between the porosity (BET surface area and pore volume) and the reversible/irreversible capacity. Therefore, higher reversible and lower irreversible capacities are achieved when the porosity measurable by N<sub>2</sub> adsorption is low. Indeed, other studies have shown low iCE (50-65%) when the carbons are activated and possess a high specific surface area.</p>
         
         <p>Ball milling is often employed as a post-treatment to reduce the particle size of HC to be suitable for electrode preparation.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0127" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0127_R_d154663148e1744" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 127 - ChemElectroChem">127</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0128" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0128_R_d154663148e1744" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 128 - ChemElectroChem">128</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, the impact of such treatment on the performance of SIBs has been rarely studied. For example, the effect of ball milling time at a constant speed of 500 rpm on the porosity of HC and the performance of SIBs was investigated.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0129" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0129_R_d154663148e1749" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 129 - Carbon">129</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The authors measured a significant increase in open porosity and a decrease in closed porosity with an increase in ball milling time, which therefore showed a decrease in reversible Na<sup>+</sup> storage. In addition, Zr-based impurities that came from the jar were found to increase with milling time. Ball milling at 500 rpm with dry ice (CO<sub>2</sub>) was used to modify the HC oxygen-based functionalities (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0005">5g</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0110" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0110_R_d154663148e1762" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 110 - ACS Sustainable Chem. Eng.">110</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The amount of oxygen was significantly increased (from 12.1 to 19.3 at. %); in particular, carboxylic acid groups were introduced, and this had a positive impact on the reversible capacity, which increased compared to the unmodified material. However, iCE is very low for practical applications (≈40%).</p>
         
         <p>The carbon yield is a key parameter in the precursor selection for HC development in terms of cost, synthesis time, efficiency, and sustainability. It represents the proportion of carbon derived from a certain precursor after thermal treatment under an inert atmosphere (i.e., Ar, N<sub>2</sub> or vacuum). The most common method used to determine the C-yield is thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). This technique provides information on precursor conversion into carbon by monitoring the mass change as a function of temperature under a controlled inert atmosphere. According to Dou et&nbsp;al.,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0130" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0130_R_d154663148e1773" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 130 - Mater. Today">130</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> during thermal annealing, the precursors undergo different chemical reactions that occur at various temperatures, including evaporation, condensation, dehydrogenation, H transfer, and isomerization. Depending on the temperature at which these reactions take place, three decomposition domains have been reported mainly in the literature.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0131" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0131_R_d154663148e1778" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 131 - J. Appl. Electrochem.">131</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0132" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0132_R_d154663148e1778" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 132 - J. Mater. Chem. A">132</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The first weight loss occurs at low temperatures (up to 150 °C), related to solvent and/or moisture evaporation. The second region at ≈400 °C, known as the pyrolysis phase, corresponds to the decomposition of precursors and the release of volatiles and is characterized by high weight loss. The third region, at higher temperatures (above 600 °C), where the mass loss becomes approximately constant, is associated with oxygen-/nitrogen-based functional group desorption, hydrogen removal, and structural reorganization. As shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0006">6</a>, the final C-yield is highly dependent on both the macromolecular composition of the precursors (i.e., biomass (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0006">6a</a>), biopolymers (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0006">6b</a>) or synthetic polymers (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0006">6c</a>)), as well as on the pyrolysis temperature, especially for biomass precursors (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0006">6a</a>). Another way to determine the C-yield, in particular, at high temperatures (1400 °C to 1600 °C) difficult to assess by TGA, is by weighing the sample before and after pyrolysis. Using this approach, higher carbon yields are generally obtained from biopolymers and synthetic polymers (18 to 40 wt. %) compared to biomass precursors (18 to 35 wt. %); see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0006">6</a>.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
            <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0006"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/6b819f8a-8189-4183-b859-f12e9d29a966/aenm202303833-fig-0006-m.jpg"><picture>
                     <source srcset="/cms/asset/6b819f8a-8189-4183-b859-f12e9d29a966/aenm202303833-fig-0006-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/9bb01ae2-0373-48b1-b571-b21132f4ce8e/aenm202303833-fig-0006-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/6b819f8a-8189-4183-b859-f12e9d29a966/aenm202303833-fig-0006-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                  <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 6<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0006&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                  </div>
                  <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Carbon yield obtained by pyrolysis of several types of precursors by weighing the sample or by TGA analysis: a) biomass-based precursors, b) biopolymers, and c) synthetic polymers. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
               </figcaption>
            </figure>
         </section>
         <p>Wang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0025" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0025_R_d154663148e1831" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 25 - ACS Omega">25</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> observed a decrease in C-yield from 54.7 to 31.8 wt% when increasing the pyrolysis temperature from 800 °C to 1600 °C for the mangosteen shell precursor. A similar effect was observed when rice husks were used as HC precursors.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0133" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0133_R_d154663148e1836" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 133 - J. Energy Chem.">133</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In this case, an increase in temperature from 900 °C to 1600 °C reduced the carbon yield from ≈30 to 20 wt%. Furthermore, Rios et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0044" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0044_R_d154663148e1841" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 44">44</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> explained that a lower carbon yield for the biomass precursor can be attributed to the lower C/O ratio and the presence of large amounts of intrinsic impurities, such as Na, Si, Zn, Mg, and Cl. In particular, a higher degree of ash (i.e., the inorganic residue resulting after combustion) indicates that the precursor has a significant amount of impurity and therefore a low carbon content after pyrolysis.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0134" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0134_R_d154663148e1847" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 134 - Energy Fuels">134</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e1847" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Moreover, during the pyrolysis process, high oxygen functionalities (such as –OH and R–O–R′ groups) with lower C/O ratios break down more easily, resulting in a lower carbon yield due to the volatile by-products they produce. Susanti et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0136" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0136_R_d154663148e1852" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 136 - J. Industr., Eng.Chem.">136</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> attributed this behavior to the lower bonding energies of the oxygenated functionalities compared to CC aromatic bonds. Importantly, such impurities (functional groups and/or metal-based impurities) can affect the process cost, the environment (i.e., CO<sub>x</sub> emission), and the application for which the HC is intended, i.e., irreversible reactions with Na<sup>+ 137</sup>. Unlike biomass resources, the C-yield resulting from the pyrolysis of biopolymers and synthetic polymers is less affected by the pyrolysis temperature. Wu et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0083" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0083_R_d154663148e1862" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 83 - Renewable Energy">83</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> found constant values while heat-treating lignin (44 wt%) and microcrystalline cellulose (12 wt%) biopolymers in the temperature range of 1000 °C to 1600 °C. The same behavior was reported by Beda et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e1867" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> for a heat-treated phenolic resin polymer in the range 1300–1600 °C (≈40 wt% C-yield). However, the authors noticed that the C-yield highly depends on the synthesis conditions. For example, the resin obtained using ethanol as a solvent led to a higher C-yield than when water was used (≈33 vs. 31 wt%) while drying in an oven was more efficient than freeze-drying to achieve higher C-yields (≈33 vs. ≈25 wt%).</p>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0030">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202303833-sec-0030-title">3 Relationship Between Synthesis Parameters and Hard Carbon Properties</h2>
         
         <p>Several parameters are known to affect the formation of HC and its properties (i.e., morphology, structure, chemical composition (heteroatoms/impurities), etc. Among them, the precursor type, pyrolysis conditions, and synthesis pathways have been reported to have a considerable impact on the HC properties. Therefore, the next section aims to provide an overview of how the main carbon properties are affected by the synthesis conditions and the precursor types. The literature review focuses on the three main classes of precursors: biomass, biopolymers, and synthetic polymers.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0040">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0040-title">3.1 Hard Carbon Morphology</h3>
            
            <p>Generally, a HC derived from a given precursor preserves its natural morphology. Many hard carbon morphologies, from (0D) to (3D) structures, including nanoparticles,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0138" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0138_R_d154663148e1888" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 138 - Nano Energy">138</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> spheres,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0139" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0139_R_d154663148e1893" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 139 - Electrochim. Acta">139</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> nanosheets,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0140" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0140_R_d154663148e1898" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 140 - Adv. Mater.">140</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> nanofibers,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0141" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0141_R_d154663148e1904" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 141 - Fuel Process. Technol.">141</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and porous carbon structures,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0092" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0092_R_d154663148e1909" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 92 - ACS Nano">92</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> have been reported using different precursors and/or altering the synthesis procedures. However, the majority of explored natural precursors do not have a particular morphology, and a random-like shape is usually obtained.</p>
            
            <p>To obtain (0D) to (3D) morphologies, specific synthesis routes are applied to help shape the precursor prior to the pyrolysis process, or the precursor already has an inherent specific morphology. Among (0D) architectures, the spherical shape is particularly interesting for hard carbons. Here, the synthesis route (HTC, polymerization, etc.) is more important than the precursor type. Spherical particles can be obtained by a hydrothermal method by using different HC sources, such as natural biopolymers and synthetic polymers (e.g., glucose,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0142" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0142_R_d154663148e1917" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 142 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">142</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> sucrose,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0143" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0143_R_d154663148e1922" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 143 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">143</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> phenolic resin<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0144" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0144_R_d154663148e1927" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 144 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">144</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) with good control over the particle size and shape. The precursor type, solution concentration, and temperature/time/pressure used have a strong impact on tuning the sphere properties. For example, Wang and co-authors<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0144" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0144_R_d154663148e1933" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 144 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">144</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized spherule-shaped HC with a particle size of 1 to 8 µm from phenolic resin using HTC (500 °C for 12 h), followed by pyrolysis (800 °C to 1500 °C for 3 h, under N<sub>2</sub> flow). Väli et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0142" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0142_R_d154663148e1940" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 142 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">142</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported a similar 2-step procedure to prepare HC spheres. Specifically, the glucose precursor was first pre-treated by HTC at 180 °C for 24 h and then pyrolyzed at 1100 °C for 2 h, under Ar flow. As a result, linked micrometer-sized carbon spheres (≈3 µm) with restricted size distribution and smooth surfaces were formed. In another study, Pol et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0139" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0139_R_d154663148e1946" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 139 - Electrochim. Acta">139</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized spherical carbon particles (4 ± 0.3 µm) using an autogenic decomposition process in a sealed autoclave (700 °C, 33.1 bar), under argon by using either mesitylene or polyethylene precursors (see <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7a</a>). The authors highlighted the advantages of spherical HCs when used as host materials for SIBs: high energy density, minimization of SEI build-up, and optimization of electrolyte consumption due to their regular morphology and edge-free structure. In some cases, the HTC of the biomass (e.g. Fraxinus driftwood biomass)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0102" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0102_R_d154663148e1957" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 102 - J. Environ. Chem. Eng.">102</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> leads to some spherical particle formation, but the morphology is more heterogeneous, in particular, because solid precursors with complex structures are used.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0007"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/e6ee20ab-f43a-45f6-8b1f-748c72f08a1b/aenm202303833-fig-0007-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/e6ee20ab-f43a-45f6-8b1f-748c72f08a1b/aenm202303833-fig-0007-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/1ae6da9d-c30d-4c07-bb92-58c6487a3219/aenm202303833-fig-0007-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/e6ee20ab-f43a-45f6-8b1f-748c72f08a1b/aenm202303833-fig-0007-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 7<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0007&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">SEM images of hard carbons exhibiting different morphologies: a) sphere-like, Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0139" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0139_R_d154663148e1981" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 139 - Electrochim. Acta">139</a></span>], Copyright 2014, Elsevier b) TEM image of hollow spheres, Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0145" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0145_R_d154663148e1984" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 145 - Adv. Energy Mater.">145</a></span>] Copyright 2012, John Wiley and Sons, c) twisted microfibers, Reprinted with permission from from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0146" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0146_R_d154663148e1987" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 146 - Carbon">146</a></span>], Copyright 2012, Elsevier, d) unwoven microfibers, Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0086" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0086_R_d154663148e1990" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 86 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">86</a></span>], Copyright 2016, Elsevier e,f) unwoven nanofiber-like, Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0147" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0147_R_d154663148e1993" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 147 - Adv. Energy Mater.">147</a></span>], Copyright 2016, John Wiley and Sons, g,h) woven microfibers, Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0078" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0078_R_d154663148e1997" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 78 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">78</a></span>], Copyright 2019, American Chemical Society i) interconnected microfibrous HCs, Reprinted with the permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0148" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0148_R_d154663148e2000" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 148 - Energy Environ. Sci.">148</a></span>], Copyright 2011, Royal Society of Chemistry, j) random sheets, Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0086" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0086_R_d154663148e2003" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 86 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">86</a></span>], Copyright 2016, Elsevier, k) macroporous HCs with spherical pores, Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0092" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0092_R_d154663148e2006" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 92 - ACS Nano">92</a></span>], Copyright 2012, American Chemical Society and l) macroporous HCs with rectangular pores, Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0149" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0149_R_d154663148e2009" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 149 - Adv. Energy Mater.">149</a></span>] Copyright 2019, John Wiley and Sons.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Although HTC is highly employed, the process has some limitations, including the need for heating (temperature) and high pressure, which are aspects that increase the cost of industrial production. Thus, eco-friendlier approaches are of great interest. For example, Beda et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e2016" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0115" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0115_R_d154663148e2016" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 115 - J. Mater. Chem. A">115</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> adopted a low-energy approach and successfully prepared HC spheres at ambient temperature and pressure using a green phenolic resin and a cross-linker. The synthesis was based on a simple sol-gel process and a thermopolymerization step followed by thermal annealing.</p>
            
            <p>Another type of morphology, i.e., hollow spheres, has also been synthesized for hosting Na ions. In 2012, Tang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0145" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0145_R_d154663148e2024" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 145 - Adv. Energy Mater.">145</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported for the first time the utilization of such a morphology in an HC anode for SIBs. The authors used HTC of glucose in latex templates (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7b</a>). The resulting hollow spheres were interconnected and possessed an internal diameter of ≈125 nm and a thickness of ≈12 nm. Additionally, the (0D) morphology explored for the HC electrodes also includes carbon quantum dots. Xie et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0101" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0101_R_d154663148e2032" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 101 - J. Mater. Chem. A">101</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported carbon dots derived from cellulose by directly drying and then carbonizing (1300-1500 °C) the supernatant (i.e., liquid phase) obtained after the HTC process (0.04 g.mL<sup>−1</sup> cellulose solution at 200 °C for 12 h). The materials exhibited a high specific capacity of 300 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> and enhanced iCE (91%) at 30 mA g<sup>−1</sup>; therefore, they had better performance than the HC materials obtained by pyrolysis of the solid phase resulting from the same HTC.</p>
            
            <p>Depending principally on the synthesis pathway rather than the precursor type, a variety of (1D) morphologies could be obtained, including rods, fibers, nanowires, and tubes. The advantages of these shapes lie in the low volume-to-surface ratio, the short ionic diffusion length, the richness in reactive sites, the reduction of the volume expansion effect, and the improved electrochemical performance for SIB anodes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0150" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0150_R_d154663148e2048" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 150 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">150</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0151" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0151_R_d154663148e2048" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 151 - J. Mater. Chem. A">151</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In this context, various precursors have been used, such as polyaniline<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0116" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0116_R_d154663148e2053" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 116 - Nano Lett.">116</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> polyacrylonitrile,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0152" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0152_R_d154663148e2058" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 152 - Adv. Mater. Technol.">152</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> pyrrole,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0146" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0146_R_d154663148e2064" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 146 - Carbon">146</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> polyvinyl chloride,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0074" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0074_R_d154663148e2069" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 74 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">74</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> natural cotton,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0153" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0153_R_d154663148e2075" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 153 - Adv. Energy Mater.">153</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and corn silk.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0154" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0154_R_d154663148e2080" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 154 - J. Energy Chem.">154</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Wang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0146" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0146_R_d154663148e2085" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 146 - Carbon">146</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> successfully synthesized uniformly shaped cross-linked nanofibers with a diameter of ≈100 nm. To obtain this (1D) structure, the authors used synthetic polypyrrole nanofibers as precursors, followed by carbonization at 600 °C for 2 h under N<sub>2</sub> (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7c</a>). Jiang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0086" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0086_R_d154663148e2096" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 86 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">86</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> showed that HC rods retain the silk-like form of carbonized ramie fibers (700 °C for 3 h, under Ar). To ensure that the fibers maintained their dimensions during the carbonization process, the authors first stabilized them at 200 °C under air, for 1 h. Hence, unwoven, long, and randomly oriented microfibers were obtained with a similar diameter distribution of ≈10 µm (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7d</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0086" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0086_R_d154663148e2105" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 86 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">86</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In a different study, Wang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0147" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0147_R_d154663148e2110" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 147 - Adv. Energy Mater.">147</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared unwoven N-doped porous carbon nanofibers (N-CNF) via an indirect carbonization process of a nanofibrous polymeric precursor made by electrospinning of polyamic acid (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7e,f</a>). Choi et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0078" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0078_R_d154663148e2118" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 78 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">78</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported the synthesis of woven carbon microfibers (PP-CFs) from natural waste silk fabric via a direct pyrolysis process at different temperatures ranging from 800 to 2800 °C (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7g,h</a>). Another strategy to attain the desired morphology (i.e., fibrous) is by using a template. By employing a template of hierarchically porous silica, mesophase pitch was successfully converted into highly linked microfibrous HC<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0148" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0148_R_d154663148e2127" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 148 - Energy Environ. Sci.">148</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> via carbonization (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7i</a>), followed by template removal (i.e., washing).</p>
            
            <p>Hard carbon (2D) structures (e.g., nanosheets, films, nanoflakes, and nanowalls) attract much interest owing to their advantages, e.g., a large surface-to-volume ratio, enhanced electronic transfer, and high ionic diffusion efficiency.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0155" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0155_R_d154663148e2138" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 155 - Small">155</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Previous research implied a variety of precursors to prepare nanosheet structures. For example, corncobs were used<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0086" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0086_R_d154663148e2143" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 86 - Appl. Surf. Sci.">86</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> to synthesize (2D) hard carbon nanosheets via carbonization at 700 °C under an argon atmosphere, Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7j</a>. A similar morphology was obtained by Xia et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0140" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0140_R_d154663148e2152" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 140 - Adv. Mater.">140</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> by using a synthetic polymer obtained by polymerization of aniline monomer with resorcinol and a very low amount of graphene oxide as a structuring agent. Hence, an open structure of HC nanosheets was obtained through carbonization at various temperatures (900 °C to 1100 °C) under an Ar atmosphere.</p>
            
            <p>Concerning the (3D) morphology, usually, the particles have a random-like shape and size, which is often reported for hard carbon. In some cases, meso- and macro-pores can be present. In this context, Ding et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0092" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0092_R_d154663148e2160" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 92 - ACS Nano">92</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> successfully synthesized hard macroporous carbon material with spherical pores using a peat moss pyrolysis process at 1100 °C (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7k</a>). Furthermore, Li et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0149" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0149_R_d154663148e2168" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 149 - Adv. Energy Mater.">149</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized hard carbon with a (3D) macroporous morphology from cork. The authors demonstrated that the microstructure of the material can be altered simply by adjusting the pyrolysis temperature from 800 °C to 1600 °C: the initial geometry of the hexagonal pores was reshaped into rectangular pores (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0007">7l</a>).</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0050">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0050-title">3.2 Hard Carbon Structure</h3>
            
            <p>The HC structure is of prime importance for Na-ion insertion. This can be impacted by several parameters, as will be discussed in this section. X-ray diffraction (XRD), a nondestructive analysis technique, is usually used to obtain structural information about materials on a large scale and thus provide a global overview of the sample's structural features. The diffracted incident X-ray beam provides information on the graphene interlayer distance, crystallinity, impurities, and other valuable structural parameters. The typical HC XRD pattern shows broad diffraction peaks, a sign of a low degree of graphitization, and asymmetric (hk0) crystallographic planes (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0008">8a</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0041" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0041_R_d154663148e2192" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 41 - Adv. Energy Mater.">41</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, there is often a rising background at low two-theta (&lt;20°) due to the presence of fine structural microporosity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0130" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0130_R_d154663148e2197" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 130 - Mater. Today">130</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0008"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/a4815c2c-22e6-44f4-b2ba-864cc576da4c/aenm202303833-fig-0008-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/a4815c2c-22e6-44f4-b2ba-864cc576da4c/aenm202303833-fig-0008-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/1df312c9-183a-4dde-a2ac-c0cec9ae900b/aenm202303833-fig-0008-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/a4815c2c-22e6-44f4-b2ba-864cc576da4c/aenm202303833-fig-0008-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 8<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0008&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Wide-angle XRD diffraction patterns of hard carbons derived from sucrose heated at temperatures ranging between 1000 and 2000 °C. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0041" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0041_R_d154663148e2221" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 41 - Adv. Energy Mater.">41</a></span>], Copyright 2020, John Wiley and Sons. b) Schematic drawing of the hard carbon structure showing the main specific parameters that can be deduced from the XRD diffractograms (interlayer spacing, d<sub>002</sub>, crystallite height, <i>L</i><sub>c</sub> and crystallite length, <i>L</i><sub>a</sub>). Adapted with the permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e2233" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a></span>], Copyright 2018, Elsevier. c) 3D and d) 2D representation of hard carbon structure, as proposed by the authors of this work.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Hard carbon materials have a non-graphitizable and disordered structure, which includes various structural defects, amorphous regions, pseudo-graphitic domains (short turbostratic stacked graphene layers), and nanopores (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0008">8b</a>). The HC structure is very complex, and several 2D<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0023_R_d154663148e2243" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Carbon">23</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0156" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0156_R_d154663148e2243" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 156 - Proceed. Royal Soc. London Series a-Mathemat., Phys. Sci.">156</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and 3D<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0157" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0157_R_d154663148e2248" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 157 - Interdiscipl. Sci. Rev.">157</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0160" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0160_R_d154663148e2248" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 160 - Energy Fuels">160</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> models have been reported in the literature to describe it, as nicely detailed in the review of Passerini et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0130" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0130_R_d154663148e2254" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 130 - Mater. Today">130</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Figures&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0008">8c</a> and&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0008">d</a> show a representation of these HC structures, as proposed by the authors of the present work. Stevens and Dahn's<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0023_R_d154663148e2265" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Carbon">23</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> model is the most accepted one, although improvements are still required. It consists of a mixture of pseudo-graphitic micro-crystallites (short turbostratic stacked graphene layers; sp<sup>2</sup>-hybridized) and amorphous regions (defective graphene layers; sp<sup>3</sup>-hybridized). The pseudo-graphitic regions have lateral dimensions (<i>L</i><sub>a</sub>) of ≈40 Å which are stacked in 2–3 parallel layers, therefore, a crystallite height (<i>L</i><sub>c</sub>) of ≈10–12 nm. Further work showed that the <i>L</i><sub>a</sub> and <i>L</i><sub>c</sub> dimensions can be much larger depending on the synthesis conditions (see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0010">10</a>). Despite the local stacking of pseudo-graphitic domains, the orientation of graphene layers is rather disordered at a larger scale, resulting in nanovoids and pores.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0130" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0130_R_d154663148e2291" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 130 - Mater. Today">130</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Concerning the structural parameters, the so-called d-spacing (d<sub>002</sub>) corresponds to the apparent distance between two graphene layers along the perpendicular (002) direction, as calculated by Bragg's law. The thickness (<i>L</i><sub>c</sub>) and width (<i>L</i><sub>a</sub>) of the pseudo-graphitic nanodomains, also known as crystalline height and length, respectively, can be estimated using (002) and (100), respectively,&nbsp;diffraction peaks by implying the Debye-Scherer formula: <i>L</i><sub>(a,c)</sub> = <i>k</i>  · λ /(FWHM · cos (Θ)) , where k = 1.84 for <i>L</i><sub>a</sub> and 0.9 for <i>L</i><sub>c</sub>; FWHM is the full width at half-maximum intensity, corresponding to each particular diffraction peak; λ is the X-ray wavelength.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0044" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0044_R_d154663148e2318" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 44">44</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Moreover, the average number of stacked graphene layers can be deduced as follows: (<i>L</i><sub>c</sub>/d<sub>002</sub>) + 1.</p>
            
            <p>In general, as the pyrolysis temperature increases (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0008">8a</a>), a shift of the XRD peaks toward higher 2θ diffraction angles is observed along with an increase in intensity. This translates into a decrease in the interlayer distance and an improved structural organization. It is worth mentioning that a larger d<sub>002</sub> space facilitates sodium ion intercalation and improves capacity, as demonstrated by Gomez-Martin et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0045" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0045_R_d154663148e2337" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 45 - Chem. Mater.">45</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0009">9</a> shows an overview of the literature data on the evolution of the d-spacing for various HC-based resources (i.e., biomass, biopolymers, and synthetic polymers) subject to thermal treatment between 600 °C and 2000 °C. In general, at low pyrolysis temperatures, all precursors lead to HCs with large d<sub>002</sub>; however, when the temperature increases, the HCs derived from biomass precursors present higher interlayer spaces (i.e., 4.15 Å at 1000 °C (peanut-shell<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0083" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0083_R_d154663148e2350" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 83 - Renewable Energy">83</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) to 3.55 Å at 1600 °C (spartina alterniflora<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0161" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0161_R_d154663148e2355" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 161 - Sci. Total Environ.">161</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0009">9a</a>) compared to HC from biopolymers (i.e., 4.13 Å at 1000 °C (microcrystalline cellulose<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0083" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0083_R_d154663148e2364" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 83 - Renewable Energy">83</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) to 3.46 Å at 1600 °C (sucrose<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0162" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0162_R_d154663148e2369" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 162 - ACS Cent. Sci.">162</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0009">9b</a>) and synthetic polymers (i.e., 4.17 Å at 1000 °C (resorcinol<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0038" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0038_R_d154663148e2378" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 38 - ChemElectroChem">38</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) to 3.43 Å at 1700 °C (PVC<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0163" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0163_R_d154663148e2383" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 163">163</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>), Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0009">9c</a>). Feng et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0164" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0164_R_d154663148e2392" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 164 - Energy Storage Mater.">164</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> attributed this tendency to the natural presence of heteroatoms (oxygen, nitrogen, and/or sulfur) in the structure of biomass precursors, which create strong covalent crosslinks with carbon.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0009"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/51b61308-4c74-47c5-8bd2-d1e034493a99/aenm202303833-fig-0009-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/51b61308-4c74-47c5-8bd2-d1e034493a99/aenm202303833-fig-0009-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/0da4a7c8-22c4-45d4-932f-c41e4b116521/aenm202303833-fig-0009-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/51b61308-4c74-47c5-8bd2-d1e034493a99/aenm202303833-fig-0009-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 9<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0009&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Evolution of the hard carbon interlayer spacing (d<sub>002</sub>) with the pyrolysis temperature for the different classes of precursors: a) biomasses, b) biopolymers, and c) synthetic polymers. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Interestingly, Qian et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0165" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0165_R_d154663148e2426" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 165 - Adv. Energy Mater.">165</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthesized HC materials by pyrolysis of sulfur-doped polyacrylonitrile at various pyrolysis temperatures (800 to 1200 °C). The authors reported that the increase in pyrolysis temperature triggers the enlargement of d<sub>002</sub> from 3.53 Å to 3.66 Å. This outcome was explained by the fact that a higher temperature is able to promote sulfur binding to the carbon backbone, resulting in an increase in d-spacing. The same finding was reported by Kong et&nbsp;al.,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0166" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0166_R_d154663148e2433" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 166 - Transact. Tianjin Uni.">166</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> where fluorine doping could expand the interlayer distance of commercial hard carbon material from 3.86 Å to above 4.00 Å. Moreover, the presence of some inorganic species might also impact the interlayer space.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e2439" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Furthermore, as the temperature increases, the average thickness (<i>L</i><sub>c</sub>) and width (<i>L</i><sub>a</sub>) of the graphitic nanodomains increase. Among the three categories of precursors, biomass persistently showed the highest values (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0010">10</a>). This tendency is related to the improved graphitization with increasing temperature but also due to the local graphitization induced by the presence of inorganic impurities (Fe, Ca, K, and Si-based) in such materials.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e2458" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e2458" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This leads to the formation of larger graphitic zones and a greater number of stacked graphene layers. For example, Si in grape waste-derived HCs led to a greater number of stacked graphene layers (15-24), in contrast to Si-free asparagus- and potato peel-derived HCs, for which a small number of stacked graphene were observed (&lt;5 sheets).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e2463" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Additionally, for biomass-derived HC materials, we note the wide dispersion of data; see Figure <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0010">10a</a>. The <i>L</i><sub>c</sub> is between ca. 1 nm (for corn silk at 1300 °C<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0154" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0154_R_d154663148e2476" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 154 - J. Energy Chem.">154</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) and ca. 8.1 nm (for ginkgo leaves at 1700 °C<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0167" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0167_R_d154663148e2482" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 167 - Adv. Energy Mater.">167</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>). This can be related to the wide variety of chemical and macromolecular compositions of biomass (i.e., cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin, etc.)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0168" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0168_R_d154663148e2487" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 168 - Biomass, Bioenergy">168</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and the variety of inorganic fractions present (e.g., Na, K, Ca, Mg, Si, etc.).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e2492" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In the case of biopolymers (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0010">10b</a>), the <i>L</i><sub>c</sub> and <i>L</i><sub>a</sub> values are much lower (&lt;≈2.5 nm and ≈6 nm, respectively) and less dispersed compared to those of biomass precursors. Kubota et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0069" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0069_R_d154663148e2507" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 69 - Chem. Mater.">69</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> showed that HC synthesized from sucrose precursor exhibits two crystallite width behaviors: constant <i>L</i><sub>c</sub> values (≈0.7 nm) when the pyrolysis temperature was varied from 700 °C to 1300 °C and a significant increase between 1300 °C and 2000 °C, reaching a value as high as 1.3 nm. Last, for the synthetic polymer-derived HCs (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0010">10c</a>), the values fall between those of biomass and biopolymers. In fact, for polymer precursors, the structures are often made of aromatic units (pitch,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0119" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0119_R_d154663148e2519" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 119 - J. Mater. Chem. A">119</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> phenolic resin<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e2524" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and PET <sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0169" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0169_R_d154663148e2530" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 169 - Carbon">169</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) and/or do not contain oxygen in their composition (polyaniline (PANI),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0116" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0116_R_d154663148e2535" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 116 - Nano Lett.">116</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> polyacrylonitrile (PAN),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0170" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0170_R_d154663148e2541" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 170 - Electrochim. Acta">170</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> polyvinyl chloride (PVC)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0074" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0074_R_d154663148e2546" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 74 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">74</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>). For these reasons, the <i>L</i><sub>c</sub> and <i>L</i><sub>a</sub> values of polymers are higher than those of biopolymers, which are mainly made up of glucose units rich in oxygen (starch,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0171" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0171_R_d154663148e2558" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 171 - Carbon">171</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> chitosan,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0029" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0029_R_d154663148e2563" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">29</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and cellulose<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0031" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0031_R_d154663148e2569" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 31 - J. Energy Chem.">31</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) or aromatic units with rich oxygen groups (lignin<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0030" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0030_R_d154663148e2574" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 30 - Carbon">30</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and tannin<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0172" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0172_R_d154663148e2579" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 172 - Mater. Tod. Chem.">172</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>).</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0010"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/cad876da-5460-44dd-b59c-1437f576bbdb/aenm202303833-fig-0010-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/cad876da-5460-44dd-b59c-1437f576bbdb/aenm202303833-fig-0010-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/f2c6b15d-6bc0-4f58-b533-5473acc525e5/aenm202303833-fig-0010-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/cad876da-5460-44dd-b59c-1437f576bbdb/aenm202303833-fig-0010-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 10<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0010&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Evolution of hard carbon crystallite size along the c-axis (<i>L</i><sub>c</sub>) and the lateral size of graphene (<i>L</i><sub>a</sub>) with the pyrolysis temperature for the different classes of precursors: a) biomasses, b) biopolymers and c) synthetic polymers. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Oxygen-based groups are well known to impede graphitization, thus leading to a larger interlayer space and lower <i>L</i><sub>a</sub> and <i>L</i><sub>c</sub>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0073" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0073_R_d154663148e2622" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 73 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">73</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0173" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0173_R_d154663148e2622" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 173 - Chem. Eng. J.">173</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) is another effective technique for exploring nanoscale aspects of HC structures: graphitization and disorder (number, dimensions, arrangement, and d-spacing of graphene layers), porosity (open and closed pores), and the presence of impurities and defects (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0011">11</a>).</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0011"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/097a0a30-9fb3-48eb-a9ca-20b4be856ac8/aenm202303833-fig-0011-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/097a0a30-9fb3-48eb-a9ca-20b4be856ac8/aenm202303833-fig-0011-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/413d2511-e3b5-4d4d-a2df-c65baf7e17f8/aenm202303833-fig-0011-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/097a0a30-9fb3-48eb-a9ca-20b4be856ac8/aenm202303833-fig-0011-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 11<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0011&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">HR-TEM images of hard carbons from a–c): phenolic resin pyrolysed at different temperatures from 800 to 2000 °C. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0079" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0079_R_d154663148e2654" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 79 - J. Power Sources">79</a></span>], Copyright 2016, Elsevier, d) biopolymer, reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0174" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0174_R_d154663148e2657" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 174 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">174</a></span>], Copyright 2023, American Chemical Society, e) grape waste and f) asparagus peel, reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e2660" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></span>] Copyright 2020, Elsevier.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>The pyrolysis temperature has an important influence on the microstructural properties of HC materials. Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0011">11a–c</a> clearly shows that by increasing the carbonization temperature, the disordered aspect of the HC structure decreases. This disordered appearance is caused by the random packing of curved and disoriented layers of graphene. Hasegawa et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0079" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0079_R_d154663148e2670" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 79 - J. Power Sources">79</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> identified graphene fragments of &lt;1–2 nm at 800 °C (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0011">11a</a>). Upon increasing the temperature from 1200 to 2000 °C, the layered structure becomes more developed (&gt;2 nm), resulting in ≈5 graphene sheets that are encrusted and stacked; see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0011">11b,c</a>. The same behavior was reported by Zhen et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0175" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0175_R_d154663148e2682" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 175 - Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA">175</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> by increasing the pyrolysis temperature from 900 to 1300 °C, using a sucrose precursor. The authors observed a transition from a disordered to a localized ordered structure of HC due to the rearrangement of carbon atoms. Most HCs reveal a similar tendency of structure modification with pyrolysis temperature.</p>
            
            <p>Another interesting structural feature highlighted by HR-TEM is the formation of closed porosity, as presented in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0011">11d</a>. The appearance of closed pores is generated by the local voids created between graphitic and disordered zones. This type of porosity is prevalent when the precursor is pyrolyzed at temperatures greater than 1300 °C.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0023_R_d154663148e2693" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Carbon">23</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Stevens and Dahn<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0023_R_d154663148e2698" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Carbon">23</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> first proposed the model of micropore closure in HC as a function of annealing temperature. According to the authors, an increase in the pyrolysis temperature led to open porosity closure, reorganization of the graphene sheets, and the formation of slightly larger pores between the graphene sheets, known as closed pores. More details about this type of porosity will be given in the next section.</p>
            
            <p>As mentioned above, inorganic impurities have an impact on the HC structure, mainly reducing the d-spacing due to catalytic-induced graphitization (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0011">11e</a>). HR-TEM better highlights these modifications. Ghimbeu's group studied the impact of these impurities on the HC structure by using different biomass precursors (i.e., asparagus peel, potato peel, and grape waste) and a pre- or post-annealing washing step.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e2709" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Notably, grape waste displayed increased graphitization and graphene stacking (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0011">11e</a>). One can note many graphitic zones composed of several stacked graphene layers (15–20) around the impurity particles (black zone, inset Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0011">11e</a>). This phenomenon was explained by the high and persistent Si concentration (Si = 1.9 wt% even after washing), which acts as a catalyst and induces graphitization at high pyrolysis temperatures. The same behavior was observed by Nita et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0154" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0154_R_d154663148e2721" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 154 - J. Energy Chem.">154</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> when using coconut shells, walnut shells, and corn silk precursors. In particular, the HC obtained from corn silk was more graphitized and had a pronounced stacking aspect (10-20 graphene layers). This feature is due to the higher wt% of Si impurities in corn silk, which is three times greater than that in walnut shells and coconut shells (0.85 at.% in corn silk vs. 0.3 at.% in coconut shells vs. 0 at.% in walnut shells). Moreover, Rios et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e2726" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> observed the growth of SiC wires due to the presence of large amounts of Si in grass biomass. Last, Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0011">11f</a> shows numerous spherical white areas related to mesopores in the HC structure, as revealed by HR-TEM. This feature was reported to arise from the elimination of inorganic impurities via washing post-pyrolysis,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e2735" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> which leads to porous free spaces.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0060">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0060-title">3.3 Hard Carbon Porosity</h3>
            
            <p>The textural properties of HC materials, including the pore volume, pore size distribution and architecture, and specific surface area (SSA), are of high importance for improving the performance of electrochemical storage systems. As has been well documented, by reducing the specific surface area, a lower electrode-electrolyte contact surface is achieved, thus improving the iCE<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0027" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0027_R_d154663148e2749" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 27 - Green Energy Environ.">27</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0061" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0061_R_d154663148e2749" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 61 - Nano Materials Science">61</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and the cycling life in SIBs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0029" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0029_R_d154663148e2754" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">29</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0089" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0089_R_d154663148e2754" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 89 - Carbon">89</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Furthermore, porosity has a direct influence on the ionic diffusion pathways and thus the reversible capacity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0028_R_d154663148e2759" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Carbon">28</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Consequently, optimization of this parameter is always needed.</p>
            
            <p>The porosity of a given solid material, particularly a HC, can be divided into open porosity (also known as accessible porosity) and confined pores, which are referred to as closed porosity (inaccessible pores to probe gases) (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0012">12a</a>).</p>
