            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0012"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/c6413ca2-08a4-4c90-bcdb-7b180196ae13/aenm202303833-fig-0012-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/c6413ca2-08a4-4c90-bcdb-7b180196ae13/aenm202303833-fig-0012-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/7ef1c231-b864-49a8-923c-85e80372a4d3/aenm202303833-fig-0012-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/c6413ca2-08a4-4c90-bcdb-7b180196ae13/aenm202303833-fig-0012-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 12<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0012&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Schematic representation of a hard carbon particle illustrating open and closed porosity. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e2793" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></span>], Copyright 2021, Royal Society of Chemistry. b) Gas adsorption isotherms measured at 77 K for all gases except CO<sub>2</sub> (273K) and pore size distribution used to evaluate the open porosity of hard carbon. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0176" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0176_R_d154663148e2798" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - J. Mater. Chem. A">176</a></span>]. Copyright 2021, Royal Society of Chemistry. c) SAXS patterns show the approach used to determine the hard carbon porosity (open and closed). Reprinted under the terms of CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 DEED license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0177" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0177_R_d154663148e2801" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 177 - Energy Storage Mater.">177</a></span>]. Copyright 2019. The authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Adsorption/desorption of a probe gas molecule is the traditional method for investigating open pore structures and for determining the SSA of solid materials (see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0012">12b</a>). In this context, N<sub>2</sub> adsorptive molecules at 77 K are widely used to evaluate the open porosity, namely, the micropores (&lt;2 nm) and the mesopores (2-50 nm), and to determine the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) SSA of HC materials. However, precise characterization of the narrow micropores present in the HC structure (&lt;0.7 nm) is not possible by N<sub>2</sub> due to its large size (inaccessible into tiny pores) and slow diffusion kinetics in the complex structure of HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0176" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0176_R_d154663148e2815" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - J. Mater. Chem. A">176</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> IUPAC recommends Ar as a better alternative to N<sub>2</sub> due to its null quadrupole momentum,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0178" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0178_R_d154663148e2823" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 178 - Pure, Appl. Chem.">178</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> which prevents any interactions between carbon and gas molecules. However, in regards to HCs, Ar is not more effective than N<sub>2</sub> on such complex structures (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0012">12b</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0176" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0176_R_d154663148e2834" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - J. Mater. Chem. A">176</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Instead, CO<sub>2</sub> at 273 K has been revealed to be more suitable for accessing the tiny pores of HC and determining the so-called ultramicroporosity of &lt;0.7 nm (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0012">12b</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e2846" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0176" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0176_R_d154663148e2846" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - J. Mater. Chem. A">176</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This is related to the fast diffusion kinetics of the CO<sub>2</sub> molecule induced by the high adsorption temperature (273 K)&nbsp;compared to N<sub>2</sub> (77K). Additionally, the CO<sub>2</sub> SSA found is significantly higher in most cases, meaning that the probed surface area is gas-dependent, and misleading information can be revealed by using N<sub>2</sub> gas only. CO<sub>2</sub> gas at 273 K cannot be used to characterize pores larger than 2 nm, and therefore, it must be used in complement with another probe molecule. Another drawback of CO<sub>2</sub> is its high quadrupole moment (higher than that of N<sub>2</sub>), making it unsuitable for determining the porosity of materials containing polar sites, due to the possible interactions with CO<sub>2</sub> that improve its adsorption and thus leads to the difficulty of discriminating between the contribution of effective porosity and that of surface chemistry.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0179" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0179_R_d154663148e2869" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 179 - Carbon">179</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Recently, other particular probe molecules, such as O<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub> at 77K, have been reported to be efficiently applied&nbsp;for the evaluation of HC porosity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0176" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0176_R_d154663148e2881" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - J. Mater. Chem. A">176</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The authors revealed that such gases allow one to gain in-depth insight into the existence of pores (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0012">12b</a>) otherwise undetected by the previously mentioned gases (i.e., N<sub>2</sub>, Ar and&nbsp;CO<sub>2</sub>). More precisely, the obtained isotherms show significantly higher adsorbed volumes for both H<sub>2</sub> and O<sub>2</sub> compared to conventional gases. The same was observed when the SSAs were determined, e.g., 279 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> by O<sub>2</sub> vs. 19 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> by N<sub>2</sub> (vs. 113 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> by H<sub>2</sub>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0176" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0176_R_d154663148e2918" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - J. Mater. Chem. A">176</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Ghimbeu and her team concluded that H<sub>2</sub> represents a better alternative to CO<sub>2</sub> to evaluate the narrow ultramicroporosity of HC materials due to both its smaller size and its low quadruple momentum (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0012">12b</a>). On the other hand, the O<sub>2</sub> molecule, which has a larger size but a smaller quadrupole momentum, is the only gas capable of accessing the entire range of pores, that is, ultramicropores (&lt;0.7 nm) and supermicropores (0.7 nm &lt;dp &lt;2.0 nm); thus, it is a suitable candidate for the precise characterization of HC porosity. However, the analysis time is very long (≈5 days) due to the slow diffusion of gas through very narrow pores. Such pores can trap gas molecules that are difficult to desorb, leading to the observed isotherm hysteresis. Furthermore, the specific surface area determined with O<sub>2</sub> is strongly correlated with the irreversible capacity of HC in SIBs, i.e., a higher specific surface area leads to a higher irreversible capacity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0176" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0176_R_d154663148e2935" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - J. Mater. Chem. A">176</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0180" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0180_R_d154663148e2935" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Adv.">180</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Despite these arguments, there is a scarcity of data on the use of O<sub>2</sub> and H<sub>2</sub> gases on HC materials.</p>
            
            <p>As mentioned above, HC porosity is characterized mainly in the literature by the probe molecule N<sub>2</sub> and, second, by CO<sub>2</sub>. <b>Figures</b>&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0013">13</a> and&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0014">14</a> present a general view of the evolution of SSAs&nbsp;of various HCs assessed by the gases mentioned above. The materials are derived from different resources (i.e., biomass, biopolymers, or synthetic polymers) and pyrolyzed at a wide range of temperatures, i.e., 600 to 2000 °C. In general, the SSA decreases with increasing pyrolysis temperature, regardless of the precursor origin. This trend is well known to be related to the reduction in microporosity caused by the reorganization of the hHC microstructure, resulting in the closure of the porosity, particularly above 1000 °C.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0044" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0044_R_d154663148e2960" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 44">44</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> On the other hand, for the same pyrolysis temperature, the SSA values depend on the precursor type, especially at low temperatures (&lt;1200 °C, see Figure <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0013">13</a>).</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0013"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/73dca14f-9263-42dc-9ba3-87f66135c57e/aenm202303833-fig-0013-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/73dca14f-9263-42dc-9ba3-87f66135c57e/aenm202303833-fig-0013-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/b81a472b-cb72-405e-b494-0d2ad0ea703f/aenm202303833-fig-0013-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/73dca14f-9263-42dc-9ba3-87f66135c57e/aenm202303833-fig-0013-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 13<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0013&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Evolution of the BET-specific surface area determined by N<sub>2</sub> adsorption at 77 K, with the pyrolysis temperature for the different classes of precursors: a) biomasses, b) biopolymers, and c) synthetic polymers. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0014"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/d46615af-23ec-4e4e-9384-4e22b8b68281/aenm202303833-fig-0014-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/d46615af-23ec-4e4e-9384-4e22b8b68281/aenm202303833-fig-0014-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/18497b4d-3402-4545-93b2-d694b44f1700/aenm202303833-fig-0014-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/d46615af-23ec-4e4e-9384-4e22b8b68281/aenm202303833-fig-0014-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 14<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0014&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Evolution of the BET-specific surface area, determined by CO<sub>2</sub> adsorption at 273 K, with the pyrolysis temperature for the different classes of precursors: a) biomasses, b) biopolymers, and c) synthetic polymers. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>If we consider the N<sub>2</sub> data reported in the literature, shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0013">13</a>, a wide range of SSA values has been reported, for example, 550 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for glucose HC obtained at 600 °C<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0163" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0163_R_d154663148e3030" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 163">163</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> to 0.4 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for an HC derived from silk waste at 2000 °C.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0078" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0078_R_d154663148e3040" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 78 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">78</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, one can clearly see the above-mentioned trends: decreased SSAs with an increase in the temperature and the importance of the precursor origin for the same annealing temperature. For example, when increasing the carbonization temperature from 800 to 1500 °C, the SSA of mangosteen shell-derived HC decreased from 539 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> to 9 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0025" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0025_R_d154663148e3054" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 25 - ACS Omega">25</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> while that of lignin-derived HC decreased from 125 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> to 15 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>, when the temperature increased from 1000 to 1500 °C.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0181" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0181_R_d154663148e3068" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 181 - Adv. Energy Mater.">181</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Moreover, the structure and chemical composition of the precursors have an important influence on the porosity of the obtained HC. Among the three categories of precursors presented in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0013">13</a>, biomass precursors lead to HC materials with higher surface areas, followed by biopolymers and synthetic polymers. For example, at 1200 °C, different SSA values were reported for the different groups of precursors: 359 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for coconut fiber HC,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0042" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0042_R_d154663148e3082" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 42 - J. Power Sources">42</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> ≈55 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for a lignin HC<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0085" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0085_R_d154663148e3092" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 85 - Carbon">85</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and ≈25 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for a phenolic resin-derived HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0113" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0113_R_d154663148e3102" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 113 - Mater. Chem. Front.">113</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>In addition, for the same category of precursors and the same pyrolysis temperature, the source of the precursor leads to HC materials with very different N<sub>2</sub> SSA values, e.g., biomass category at 1400 °C, lotus seedpod HC has ≈109 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0182" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0182_R_d154663148e3113" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 182 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">182</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> vs. ≈21 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for a peat moss HC,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0092" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0092_R_d154663148e3123" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 92 - ACS Nano">92</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> biopolymer category at 1000 °C, cellulose HC has 539 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0183" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0183_R_d154663148e3130" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 183 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">183</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> vs. 83 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for a microcrystalline cellulose HC,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e3140" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> synthetic polymers at 1400 °C, tire rubber-derived HC has 210 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0184" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0184_R_d154663148e3148" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 184 - J. Power Sources">184</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> vs. ≈3 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for a pitch HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0119" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0119_R_d154663148e3157" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 119 - J. Mater. Chem. A">119</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Wu et&nbsp;al. studied in detail the effect of the chemical composition of HC precursors.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0083" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0083_R_d154663148e3165" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 83 - Renewable Energy">83</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The authors showed that at 1200 °C, the HC produced from lignin has a much lower N<sub>2</sub> SSA (19.7 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>) compared to that of HC derived from cellulose (103.1 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>). The difference was related to the structural features of lignin and cellulose precursors, which are composed of aromatic and nonaromatic rings, respectively. It was concluded that the highly condensed aromatic rings of lignin lead to denser HC structures and thus a lower SSA. The structure of the precursor may also play an important role in the final SSA of the materials. It was shown by Irisarri et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0185" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0185_R_d154663148e3181" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 185 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">185</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> that the pyrolysis of pulp cellulose has a higher N<sub>2</sub> SSA than that of microcrystalline cellulose (87 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> vs. 7 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>) and can further increase it to 115 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> if pulp cellulose is pelletized. The authors attributed the increase in SSA to the by-product gas evacuation which was low during heat treatment through the compact samples.</p>
            
            <p>Furthermore, the presence of impurities in the precursor composition plays an important role in dictating the porosity. Beda et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e3204" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> studied the impact of biomass impurities on HC properties by approaching precursors containing elements, such as Ca, Mg, K, Si, P, and Cl. By performing a post-synthesis washing step, the authors observed that as impurities were removed, the N<sub>2</sub> SSA of HC derived from asparagus peel increased from 7 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (before washing) to 40 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (after washing). However, if washing is performed before synthesis, it has been shown that the SSA can be significantly reduced due to the removal of inorganics that impede the activation of carbon during pyrolysis.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0030" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0030_R_d154663148e3220" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 30 - Carbon">30</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Additionally, the synthesis process (i.e., pretreatment conditions) is an important parameter that must be taken into account to control the texture of HCs. Daher et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0073" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0073_R_d154663148e3227" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 73 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">73</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> demonstrated that a preoxidation treatment at 300 °C, carried out before the pyrolysis of a pitch precursor, leads to different N<sub>2</sub> SSAs compared to direct pyrolysis of the same material. Moreover, when oxidation is performed under different atmospheres (i.e., ambient air, oxygen flow or air flow) and durations (i.e., 3, 12, 48, 72, and 200 h), the porosity of the obtained HC changes as well. In particular, the authors observed that preoxidation under air and varying durations (i.e., 3 h to 200 h) increases the N<sub>2</sub> SSA from 1.5 to 49.7 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. The pyrolysis conditions may also affect the porosity of the obtained carbon. Irisarri et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0186" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0186_R_d154663148e3241" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 186 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">186</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> showed that Ar flow plays a role when sugar is heated at 1100 °C. A low Ar flow rate of 200 mL min<sup>−1</sup> led to a high SSA of 670 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>, while by increasing the flow rate to 1000 mL min<sup>−1</sup>, the SSA could be significantly decreased to 11 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. Guo et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0187" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0187_R_d154663148e3259" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 187 - Electrochim. Acta">187</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> showed that the slow heating rate applied to camphor wood residues has a positive effect to decrease the specific surface area from 111.4 to 3.7 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (for a heating rate of 5 and 0.25 ° C min<sup>−1</sup>, respectively) and to expand the interlayer space. The same observations regarding the SSA were found elsewhere using sucrose, however, the interlayer space decreased with the heating rate.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0095" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0095_R_d154663148e3271" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 95 - Adv. Energy Mater.">95</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Ultrafast heating rate (300 to 500 °C min<sup>−1</sup>) in a short time (one minute) by spark plasma sintering (SPS) proved to be an interesting approach to reduce not only the porosity but also the defects and O-functionalities.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0188" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0188_R_d154663148e3279" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 188 - Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA">188</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In which concern the commercial HCs, the SSA assessed by N<sub>2</sub> is often available as well. It can be seen in Table <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0004">4</a> that commercially available HC possesses a low N<sub>2</sub> SSA, below 10 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>.</p>
            
            <div class="article-table-content" id="aenm202303833-tbl-0002">

                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">
                              <p>96–4</p>

                        <tr>

                              <p>PAC2</p>

                           <td class="center-aligned">86</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">322</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">277</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">[<span><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e10645" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></span>]</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">
                              <p>YHC-1,</p>
                              <p>BSG –Best Graphite</p></td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">5.27</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">89.2</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">–</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">294.6</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">[<span><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0271" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0271_R_d154663148e10695" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 271">271</a></span>]</td>
                           </tr>
                        </tbody>
                     </table>
               </div>
               
               
               <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
            </div>
            
            <p>However, as mentioned before, the porosity of HC is very complex and particular, and the N<sub>2</sub> gas is insufficient to characterize it. Therefore, when CO<sub>2</sub> is approached (Figure <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0014">14</a>), in most cases, the obtained SSAs are higher compared to those obtained by N<sub>2</sub> (Figure <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0013">13</a>). This is related to the presence of very narrow pores, called ultramicropores (&lt;0.7 nm), in the HC structure, which are undetectable by N<sub>2</sub>. For example, for an HC prepared from bagasse biomass, an SSA of 337 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> was found by CO<sub>2</sub>, and only 19 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> was found by N<sub>2</sub>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e10736" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Similar trends were observed among the biopolymers (i.e., 16.2 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> by CO<sub>2</sub> vs. 6.9 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> by N<sub>2</sub> for a catechu extract-derived HC<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0189" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0189_R_d154663148e10754" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 189 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">189</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) and the synthetic polymers (i.e., 394 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> SSA by CO<sub>2</sub> vs. 131 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> by N<sub>2</sub> for a phenolic resin-derived HC<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0185" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0185_R_d154663148e10773" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 185 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">185</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>).</p>
            
            <p>As in the previous case (i.e., N<sub>2</sub> gas), CO<sub>2</sub> SSA is influenced by both the source of the precursor and the pyrolysis temperature. In general, regardless of the precursor origin, the CO<sub>2</sub> SSA decreases with increasing temperature, as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0014">14</a>. Several reports in the literature highlight this trend. For a carbonized cellulose-derived HC between 1000 and 1600 °C, the CO<sub>2</sub> SSA decreases from 406 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> to 380 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (at 1000 °C) to 255 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> to 40 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> and 3 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (at 1600 °C).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e10814" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The same trend was reported when using an eco-friendly phenolic resin heated between 1100 and 1700 °C to obtain the HC, where the CO<sub>2</sub> SSA decreased from 273 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> to ≈21 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup><sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0032" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0032_R_d154663148e10829" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 32 - Carbon">32</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>.</p>
            
            <p>In addition to the pyrolysis temperature, the precursor source used to prepare the HC material can be detrimental to the CO<sub>2</sub> SSA of the materials. This is very well illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0014">14</a>, among all three categories of precursors, when the pyrolysis temperature is constant. For example, for biomass precursors at 1000 °C, sugarcane leads to an HC with 525 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> CO<sub>2</sub> SSA,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0124" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0124_R_d154663148e10850" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 124 - J. Energy Chem.">124</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> miscanthus HC to 438 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0190" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0190_R_d154663148e10859" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 190 - Energies">190</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and wheat straw HC to 257 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0190" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0190_R_d154663148e10869" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 190 - Energies">190</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> while an argan-derived HC leads to a low CO<sub>2</sub> SSA of only 7.7 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup><sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0024" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0024_R_d154663148e10880" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 24 - J. Mater. Chem. A">24</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>. Similar trends can be observed between biopolymer HCs (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0014">14b</a>) and synthetic polymer-derived HCs (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0014">14c</a>). Especially for the latter category, at low pyrolysis temperatures (e.g., 700 °C), the CO<sub>2</sub> SSAs are quite dispersed and strongly dependent on the precursor type.</p>
            
            <p>Despite the fact that CO<sub>2</sub> gas allows a more detailed characterization of the porosity of HCs, the use of this gas is rather limited, as shown from the data presented in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0014">14</a>, compared to the N<sub>2</sub> data in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0013">13</a>.</p>
            
            <p>As mentioned above, along with the open porosity, closed porosity is present, as well. At high temperatures, the HC framework reorganizes and favors the growth of microcrystalline structures. The pseudo-graphitic planes become mobile and align with neighboring layers, leading to the formation of more stacked layers and micropore coalescence. This induces the closing of certain open pores, thus forming the so-called closed pores.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0023_R_d154663148e10909" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Carbon">23</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This model explaining the formation of closed HC porosity is known as the ‘falling cards’ model, as proposed by Stevens and Dahn.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0023_R_d154663148e10914" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Carbon">23</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The same model first explained the decrease in porosity based on CO<sub>2</sub> adsorption isotherms, as illustrated in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0015">15a</a>. At low temperatures (≈900 °C), the micropores are considered type 1, which means that they are fully accessible by CO<sub>2</sub>. For temperatures higher than 900 °C, several types of micropores coexist in hard carbon depending on the pyrolysis temperature. For intermediate temperatures (&lt;1400 °C), the pores partially close, leading to micropores with an ‘ink bottle’ shape (called type 2). Due to narrow pore openings, CO<sub>2</sub> diffusion is more difficult. Finally, at higher temperatures (&gt;1400 °C), the pore openings become narrower and close off (type 3), impeding gas molecules from diffusing inside these restricted closed pores.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0015"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/5166b137-d231-4aee-8af4-25da7d13a064/aenm202303833-fig-0015-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/5166b137-d231-4aee-8af4-25da7d13a064/aenm202303833-fig-0015-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/470672a0-5874-467c-9c34-e756ce025897/aenm202303833-fig-0015-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/5166b137-d231-4aee-8af4-25da7d13a064/aenm202303833-fig-0015-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 15<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0015&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Model of micropore closure in sucrose-derived hard carbon showing open micropores (Type 1), partially closed micropores (Type 2), and fully closed micropores (Type 3) proposed by Buiel et&nbsp;al., Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0023" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0023_R_d154663148e10951" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Carbon">23</a></span>], Copyright 1999, Elsevier. b) SAXS patterns and c) schematic representation of the pore structure evolution during thermal pyrolysis of activated anthracite, at different temperatures. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0192" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0192_R_d154663148e10954" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 192 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">192</a></span>], Copyright 2022, John Wiley and Sons. d) Evolution of closed pore volume with the true density of HC derived from cork. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0149" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0149_R_d154663148e10957" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 149 - Adv. Energy Mater.">149</a></span>], Copyright 2019, John Wiley and Sons. e) Closed pores generated by varying the amount of ethanol in the synthesis. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0193" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0193_R_d154663148e10960" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 193 - ACS Energy Lett.">193</a></span>], Copyright 2019, American Chemical Society. f) Evolution of the closed porosity and He density vs. pyrolysis temperature of different precursors.<sup>[</sup><span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0029" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0029_R_d154663148e10964" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">29</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e10964" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0174" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0174_R_d154663148e10964" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 174 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">174</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0189" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0189_R_d154663148e10964" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 189 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">189</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>As such closed porosity cannot be assessed by gas adsorption, other techniques have been employed in the literature. SAXS (small-angle X-ray scattering) is an interesting tool for investigating the HC texture.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0063" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0063_R_d154663148e10973" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 63 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">63</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0177" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0177_R_d154663148e10973" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 177 - Energy Storage Mater.">177</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In particular, it provides valuable information on the closed porosity, as well as other information. Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0012">12c</a> presents a typical SAXS profile of HC, where the intensity is a function of a scattering vector (<i>q</i>). Such a profile exhibits two major characteristics: a shoulder shape and a continuous increase in intensity by decreasing q. From low- to mid-ranges and then to high q ranges, the morphological (i.e., shape), microstructural (microporosity) and structural characteristics of HC materials can be explored.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0177" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0177_R_d154663148e10983" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 177 - Energy Storage Mater.">177</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, SAXS is restricted only to determining the average pore size, and highly customized equipment is required to establish the distribution of closed porosity in terms of size, volume, and/or surface area.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0191" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0191_R_d154663148e10989" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 191 - Adv. Energy Mater.">191</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>With the help of SAXS, Wang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0192" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0192_R_d154663148e10996" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 192 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">192</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> revealed the influence of carbonization temperature on closed porosity in anthracite-prepared HCs. When increasing the temperature from 700 to 1500 °C, an increase in the closed pore volume from 0.05 to 0.12 cm<sup>3</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> and a pore size from 1.74 to 2.37 nm was observed by SAXS (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0015">15b</a>). The evolution of porosity with pyrolysis temperature, is schematically represented as illustrated in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0015">15c</a>. Furthermore, the appearance of closed porosity was accompanied by a decrease in He density from 2.05 g cm<sup>−3</sup> (700 °C) to 1.77 g cm<sup>−3</sup> (1500 °C), as reported by the same authors.</p>
            
            <p>Li et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0149" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0149_R_d154663148e11019" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 149 - Adv. Energy Mater.">149</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> observed the same tendency in a cork biomass HC produced at different pyrolysis temperatures. Based on SAXS, TEM, and pycnometry analyses, increasing the carbonization temperature from 800 to 1600 °C results in the following modifications: i) larger closed pores (from 3.47 to 4.50 nm), ii) a higher volume of closed pores (from 0.03 to 0.29 cm<sup>3</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>) and iii) a lower He density (from 2.11 to 1.36 g cm<sup>−3</sup>). The authors also observed that an increase in the volume of closed pores leads to a decrease in the true density of HC, as shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0015">15d</a>.</p>
            
            <p>Nevertheless, other strategies can be used to tune the closed pores. For example, Zhou et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0194" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0194_R_d154663148e11037" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 194 - Susmat">194</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared HC from rosewood (pre-chemically treated or not) at 1100 °C and found that the chemical treatment led to a larger volume of closed pores compared to the untreated HC (i.e., 0.055 cm<sup>3</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> vs. 0.039 cm<sup>3</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>). The higher volume of closed pores was related to the breakdown of the fibrous structure of the precursor (i.e., the elimination of hemicellulose/lignin and the partial hydrolysis of cellulose in an alkaline medium), which resulted in the development of closed pores with thinner walls. For the same purpose, Meng et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0193" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0193_R_d154663148e11051" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 193 - ACS Energy Lett.">193</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used phenol-formaldehyde resin and ethanol to generate closed pores in HC and found the optimal ethanol fraction of 33% to obtain the highest number of closed pores (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0015">15e</a>).</p>
            
            <p>Complementary to SAXS, the closed porosity ratio (R<sub>CP</sub>) can be estimated considering the HC He density (d<sub>He</sub>) and the total open pore volume (V<sub>OP</sub>) determined by nitrogen adsorption, via the following equation: R<sub>CP</sub> (%) = (1/d<sub>He</sub> –1/2.26)/(V<sub>OP</sub> + 1/d<sub>He</sub>)&nbsp;×&nbsp;100, where 2.26 represents the density of graphite.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0195" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0195_R_d154663148e11077" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 195">195</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0015">15f</a> shows the evolution of the closed porosity and He density with the pyrolysis temperature for several precursors, as studied by Ghimbeu et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0029" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0029_R_d154663148e11087" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">29</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e11087" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0174" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0174_R_d154663148e11087" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 174 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">174</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0189" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0189_R_d154663148e11087" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 189 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">189</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Indeed, the general tendency of the closed porosity is to increase with the pyrolysis temperature, while the He density shows the opposite behavior. However, the precursor itself is as important as the temperature. If 1500 °C is taken as an example, the closed porosity varies from 7.6% for starch rice<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0174" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0174_R_d154663148e11092" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 174 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">174</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> to 19.23% for phenolic resin spheres<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e11098" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and to 41.04% for chestnut polyphenol.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0189" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0189_R_d154663148e11103" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 189 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">189</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> These differences might be explained by the different chemical compositions, structures, and porosities of these materials.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0070">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0070-title">3.4 Hard Carbon Chemical Composition/Surface Chemistry</h3>
            
            <p>In addition to structural and textural features, a comprehensive understanding of the surface chemistry of HC materials is crucial, given that electrolyte-HC electrode interactions determine the electrochemical performance. In particular, HC materials have several surface functional groups. They are mainly composed of oxygen-based functional groups, such as hydroxyl (−OH), carboxyl (R−COOH), ether (–R–O–R–) and carbonyl (CO), which are inherently formed on all HCs due to oxygen present in the parent precursor used or due to air exposure. Likewise, other groups based on N, S, and F may exist within the HC structure. They are derived from precursor composition and/or external sources used to modify the material chemistry.</p>
            
            <p>In this context, techniques such as X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and temperature-programmed desorption coupled with mass spectrometry (TPD-MS), often complemented by elemental analysis (EA), are widely used for HC surface chemistry evaluation.</p>
            
            <p>It is pertinent to note that, because of the structural complexity and heterogeneous aspect of HC, it is highly advised to combine the above approaches for better surface characterization, which can help optimize HC anode synthesis and, therefore, electrochemical performance. XPS is a useful technique to investigate the chemical composition of HC surfaces (≈10 nm) and is commonly used to investigate the hybridization state of carbon atoms and oxygen atoms on HC surfaces, the presence of impurities, and chemical bonds.</p>
            
            <p><b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0016">16</a> presents the amount of O and C in different classes of hard carbon precursors with increasing temperatures of thermal carbonization. Clearly, as the pyrolysis temperature increases, the oxygen content decreases, while the carbon content increases for all materials. This behavior is assigned to the removal of oxygenated species that leads to a reduction in the amount of C sp<sup>3</sup> and defect sites,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0196" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0196_R_d154663148e11130" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 196 - J. Mater. Chem. A">196</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and therefore, an increase in C sp<sup>2</sup> carbon. Of note, elemental analysis and XPS can show different concentrations of elements, due to the higher penetration depth of EA compared to XPS (i.e., few µm vs. few nm). However, as mentioned by Zhang et&nbsp;al.,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e11138" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> the difference in O content on the surface and in the bulk may reveal the presence of oxygen gradient through the material.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0016"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/fa1de280-6ff7-4795-87fc-0505aa18089b/aenm202303833-fig-0016-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/fa1de280-6ff7-4795-87fc-0505aa18089b/aenm202303833-fig-0016-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/9f666b93-9599-4d43-8d8d-1328883043d5/aenm202303833-fig-0016-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/fa1de280-6ff7-4795-87fc-0505aa18089b/aenm202303833-fig-0016-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 16<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0016&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Hard carbon chemical composition: modification of the amount of oxygen and carbon with the pyrolysis temperature for the different classes of precursors: a) biomasses, b) biopolymers, and c) synthetic polymers. Most values were obtained by XPS or EA, where indicated. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>As shown in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0016">16</a>, biomass-derived HCs generally show a lower C content compared to carbons derived from biopolymers and synthetic polymers, which could be related to their higher inorganic impurities content and/or the lower initial carbon content present in the precursor structures. For example, Rios et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e11173" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0190" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0190_R_d154663148e11173" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 190 - Energies">190</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> studied a wide palette of 25 biomass precursors that were grouped into three categories according to their main inorganic impurities: Ca for woody type, Si for grass-based ones, and K for agricultural precursors. For HC derived from wood (e.g., orchard apple, beechwood, and scot pine bark) and agricultural waste (e.g., corncob, papaya seed, and tamarind seed), the authors noted a high purity of C (&gt;92 weight-moisture-free (wmf) %) and an ash content between 0.3 and 7.5 wmf %. However, most of the grass-based HCs studied (e.g., triticale, reed canary grass, and wheat straw) have a higher ash content (up to 24.8 wmf %), resulting in a lower purity of C (73.5–95.3 wmf %). This high ash content combined with a low C amount proved to be detrimental to the electrochemical performance delivered by the HC anode material.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e11178" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0190" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0190_R_d154663148e11178" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 190 - Energies">190</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>However, Zhang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0091" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0091_R_d154663148e11185" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 91 - RSC Adv.">91</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> noted that a washing step could be advantageous for improving the carbon content of HC derived from pinecones. Important removal of impurities (e.g., Mg, P, S, K, Ca, and Si) was observed after washing the carbon with a solution of KOH for 3 h and HCl for 5 h. This resulted in a carbon content increase from 90.88 to 94.43 wt%, while the oxygen level decreased from 7.82 to 5.57 wt%. However, washing is only a partial solution as the main role of the inorganic impurities is played during the synthesis as it influences the structure of the HC itself (catalytic effect…), as explained above. In this direction,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0030" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0030_R_d154663148e11190" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 30 - Carbon">30</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> washing with hot water was proposed on pre-carbonized lignin materials at low temperatures, and an increase in the C content with a simultaneous decrease in the amount of impurities was observed compared to unwashed HCs. This allowed the authors to enhance both the iCE and the capacity delivered and to improve the long-term cycling behaviour.</p>
            
            <p>In addition, Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0016">16</a> shows that regardless of the source category, C and O concentrations vary in opposite ways and are dependent on precursors, when the pyrolysis temperature is identical. For example, at 1400 °C, beechwood biomass<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e11201" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> has ≈85 at.% C vs. ≈97 at.% for shaddock peel biomass,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0197" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0197_R_d154663148e11206" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 197 - J. Mater. Chem. A">197</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> while for O, lower values are observed (≈15 at.% vs. ≈3 at.%). The same behavior is observed among the biopolymers. For example, at 1500 °C, catechu tannin<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0189" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0189_R_d154663148e11212" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 189 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">189</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> contains 86 at.% C (and ≈11 at.% of O) compared to ≈98 at.% for starch<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0198" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0198_R_d154663148e11217" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 198 - J. Power Sources">198</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (and ≈1 at.% O). Regarding the synthetic precursors, although less data are available in the literature, the same tendency was observed. For example, at 1600 °C, the percentage of C ranges from ca. 93 at.% (PET<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0169" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0169_R_d154663148e11222" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 169 - Carbon">169</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) to ≈98 at.% (leonardite humic acid<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0199" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0199_R_d154663148e11228" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 199 - Carbon">199</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>). As expected, the O content is very low as well, i.e., ≈7 at.% (PET) and ≈2 at.% (leonardite humic acid).</p>
            
            <p>Functional groups other than oxygen-based groups have been investigated in the literature to boost the delivered capacity. For example, HC containing P-based functional groups was synthesized by Hong et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0200" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0200_R_d154663148e11236" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 200 - J. Mater. Chem. A">200</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> by using pomelo peels treated with phosphoric acid. However, the authors conclude that P-containing functional groups negatively affect sodium ion storage because of the dissolution of such groups in the electrolyte. Consequently, the obtained iCE was very low (27%), as was the capacity (181 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> at 200 mA g<sup>−1</sup> after 220 cycles). In another work,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0201" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0201_R_d154663148e11245" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 201 - J. Mater. Chem. A">201</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> it was shown that electrochemical performance depends on the type of P-functional group, which could be modified with an increase in the pyrolysis temperature (500 to 1000 °C) from P<span class="icomoon"></span>O to P<span class="icomoon"></span>C and P<span class="icomoon"></span>P bonds. The P-C groups proved to be the most efficient groups because they preserve a large interlayer space. Although the reversible capacity was high (379.3 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> at 100 mA g<sup>−1</sup>), the iCE was very low (≈30%). Improvement in the iCE of P-doped carbons was achieved by Alvin et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0202" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0202_R_d154663148e11255" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 202 - Chem. Eng. J.">202</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> by heating the materials at a higher temperature (1300 °C), allowing the suppression of micropores and defects, reaching 72% iCE (vs. 69% for the undoped HC). An increase in the plateau capacity was also observed and was attributed to the enlargement of d<sub>002</sub> due to P doping: 183 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for the undoped HC to up to 223 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> P-doped HC.</p>
            
            <p>A different approach involved N-doping by employing various nitrogen precursor sources to prepare HC. Therefore, Romero-Cano et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0203" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0203_R_d154663148e11270" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 203 - Electrochim. Acta">203</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used precursors of grapefruit peels and impregnation with urea and melamine, followed by pyrolysis at 600 °C to achieve N functionalization. On the basis of the XPS results, the presence of common nitrogen functional groups (i.e., NH<sub>2</sub>, pyridine-N, and quaternary-N) was observed in different proportions. The impregnation of urea leads to the formation of a complementary N-group, i.e., pyridine-N-oxide. Wang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0204" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0204_R_d154663148e11277" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 204 - Sustain. Energy Fuels">204</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared N-doped HC from polyimide separators recovered from spent LIBs. The films were first washed with acetone to remove any impurities and then annealed at temperatures between 800 and 1300 °C. The obtained materials possessed between 2 and 3.5 at.% N. However, the reversible capacity delivered in SIBs is rather low (190 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at a current density of 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup>) and the iCE is &lt;50%.</p>
            
            <p>Doping HCs with different dopants can also be achieved by introducing different acids (e.g., H<sub>3</sub>PO<sub>4</sub>, H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, or H<sub>3</sub>BO<sub>3</sub>) in the synthesis process, followed by pyrolysis at 1100 °C. Li et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0205" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0205_R_d154663148e11304" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 205 - Adv. Energy Mater.">205</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared P, S, B-doped HCs through such an approach, to study the storage mechanism of Na-ions. They observed that the doping process brings modification to both the interlayer distance and the defect concentration of HCs. Another strategy to obtain doped materials is to mix the HC with the dopant powder or with a compound containing the dopant. Muruganantham and co-workers<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0206" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0206_R_d154663148e11309" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 206 - Electrochim. Acta">206</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> prepared N- and S-doped HC by using a two-step synthesis procedure. First, mango peel was pyrolyzed at 1000 °C and washed with an acidic solution. Second, the obtained HC was ground with sulfur powder and hexamethylenetetramine (C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>12</sub>N<sub>4</sub>), then treated at 800 °C for 2 h under Ar. As a result, the d-spacing of the N, S- doped HC increased to 0.48 nm compared to the pristine HC (0.38 nm).</p>
            
            <p>Therefore, XPS provides useful information about chemical surface species and their states. However, XPS spectra deconvolution and interpretation are highly challenging and require advanced knowledge to correctly identify the chemical species present on the HC surface.</p>
            
            <p>To strengthen carbon surface analysis investigations, TPD-MS is a complementary advanced tool to probe the nature and quantify oxygen function groups and active surface area (ASA, more details in Section&nbsp;<a class="sectionLink scrollableLink" href="#aenm202303833-sec-0100">3.5.2</a>) in HC materials. Briefly, the fundamental principle of the analysis is to heat the carbon under a secondary vacuum and record the spectra of desorbed gases (i.e., CO, CO<sub>2</sub>, H<sub>2</sub>O, and H<sub>2</sub>) as by-products of the decomposition of functional groups, using quadrupole mass spectrometry.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0207" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0207_R_d154663148e11335" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 207 - Anal. Chem">207</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Although this technique has been widely used by several groups for activated carbon characterization,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0208" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0208_R_d154663148e11341" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 208 - Carbon">208</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0210" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0210_R_d154663148e11341" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 210 - Carbon">210</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> only one group<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e11346" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e11346" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported results on various HCs.</p>
            
            <p>The evaluation of CO and CO<sub>2</sub> gases is of high importance because they offer valuable information on the different functional groups present, according to the release temperature, as presented in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0017">17a</a>. CO<sub>2</sub> desorbs at rather low temperatures (&lt;500 °C) from various oxygen-containing functional groups, such as carboxylic, anhydride, and lactone groups. Instead, CO is desorbed at higher temperatures (&gt;500 °C) from oxygen-containing functional groups, such as carbonyl, phenol, ether, and quinone groups.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0154" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0154_R_d154663148e11363" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 154 - J. Energy Chem.">154</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0211" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0211_R_d154663148e11363" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 211 - J. Analyt., Appl. Pyrolysis">211</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0212" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0212_R_d154663148e11363" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 212 - Carbon">212</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> When the two types of groups are summed (i.e., CO+CO<sub>2</sub>), the CO<sub>x</sub> groups can be obtained to provide a global view of the O-based functionalities of HC.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0017"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/1a719389-f3fa-4f8b-bbbb-8c5323d3a91a/aenm202303833-fig-0017-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/1a719389-f3fa-4f8b-bbbb-8c5323d3a91a/aenm202303833-fig-0017-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/f816d537-640f-46f6-ad24-3736f75dc6f1/aenm202303833-fig-0017-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/1a719389-f3fa-4f8b-bbbb-8c5323d3a91a/aenm202303833-fig-0017-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 17<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0017&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">(a) Oxygen-based functional groups evolved from the carbon surface and their decomposition at different temperatures in CO and CO<sub>2</sub> groups, as proposed by the authors of this work; (b) Desorbed amount of CO<sub>x</sub> derived from the thermal decomposition of oxygen-functional groups during the TPD-MS experiment, from hard carbon materials obtained by different precursors pyrolyzed at various temperatures. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0017">17b</a> shows that the amount of CO<sub>x</sub> varies greatly with the type of precursor and the annealing temperature. One can observe a higher amount of CO<sub>x</sub> for some biomass-derived HCs (e.g., potato (≈2.5 mmol g<sup>−1</sup>) and asparagus (≈1.5 mmol g<sup>−1</sup>)), which is highly related to the presence of metallic carbonates,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e11415" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> as revealed by the presence of unusual CO<sub>2</sub> and CO peaks at both low (≈300 °C) and high (500–800 °C) desorption temperatures. In fact, the amount of CO<sub>x</sub> was shown to be decreased by 13% and 50% for asparagus and potato HCs, respectively, by washing the HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e11424" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The same behavior was reported by Conder et&nbsp;al.,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0029" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0029_R_d154663148e11430" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">29</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> where HCl treatment of chitosan-derived HC led to a reduction in CO<sub>x</sub> desorbed molecules compared to the untreated sample (from 0.07 to 0.03 mmol g<sup>−1</sup>). Apart from these 2 HCs, the materials presented in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0017">17b</a> possess CO<sub>x</sub> amounts that are lower than 1 mmol g<sup>−1</sup>, and biopolymers stand out for the lowest values. Some synthetic polymers (PAN) present a very low amount of CO<sub>x</sub>-based groups because of their chemical composition, which does not contain oxygen. A similar result was reported for a commercial HC, named PAC-2 (Aekyung Petrochemical), which released a low amount of CO<sub>x</sub>, i.e., 0.07 mmol g<sup>−1</sup>, however, neither the precursor used nor the synthesis conditions are available.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e11453" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>In addition to precursor type, the pyrolysis temperature has an important impact on the control of HC functionality. For the same precursor origin (cellulose, phenolic resin, etc.), the increase in temperature leads to a reduction in the amount of CO<sub>x</sub>, which was proven to be favorable for electrochemical performance, improved iCE, and reversible capacity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e11463" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e11463" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Another efficient strategy approached in the literature to reduce the amount of CO<sub>x</sub> is a washing step involving either acid or water, which can be performed prior to or after annealing treatment.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0029" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0029_R_d154663148e11470" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 29 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">29</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0030" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0030_R_d154663148e11470" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 30 - Carbon">30</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e11470" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0080">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0080-title">3.5 Hard Carbon Structural Defects</h3>
            
            <p>As mentioned in the Introduction, HCs have a disordered and non-graphitizing structure, including curved and randomly aligned graphene sheets with a microporous texture. In particular, distinct Na-ion storage properties (e.g., specific reversible capacity and stability<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e11484" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e11484" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0213" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0213_R_d154663148e11484" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 213 - J. Mater. Chem. A">213</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) can be obtained despite the identical structure of the HC precursors, as a result of tuning the defect concentration.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0214" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0214_R_d154663148e11489" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 214 - Small">214</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Consequently, an in-depth investigation of these defects is crucial for electrochemical applications.</p>
            
            <p>Various defects could be present in the HC structure, including Stone–Wales (SW) defects, mono-, di-, and/or multiple vacancies, and line defects. These defects are also known as intrinsic defects or self-doping defects. Stone–Wales (SW) defects are caused by the rearrangement of the carbon lattice, in which the rotation (90°) of two π-bonded carbon atoms in the same plane leads to the formation of carbon polygons other than hexagonal rings, such as heptagons or pentagons,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0215" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0215_R_d154663148e11497" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 215 - Mater. Today">215</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0216" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0216_R_d154663148e11497" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 216 - Phys. Rev. B">216</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> as shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0018">18a</a>.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0018"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/5b2262d7-7b61-417c-b1ed-6ddaa1de0110/aenm202303833-fig-0018-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/5b2262d7-7b61-417c-b1ed-6ddaa1de0110/aenm202303833-fig-0018-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/366c1e07-c147-499e-a838-28ac37b871e5/aenm202303833-fig-0018-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/5b2262d7-7b61-417c-b1ed-6ddaa1de0110/aenm202303833-fig-0018-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 18<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0018&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Different types of defects present in the hard carbon structure: Stone–Wales defect a), mono-vacancy b), di-vacancy c), line defect d). Reprinted from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0215" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0215_R_d154663148e11527" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 215 - Mater. Today">215</a></span>] under the terms of CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 DEED license.Copyright 2015, The Authors.Published by Elsevier.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Vacancy defects are another type of natural crystal imperfection that belongs to the point defect group and originates from the absence of carbon atoms from the ideal graphene lattice. When one carbon atom is missing, a pentagon and an octagonal ring appear, the latter presenting a dangling carbon bond (unsaturated atomic valence of C); see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0018">18b</a>.</p>
            
            <p>However, the di-carbon vacancy may or may not have a dangling carbon bond; see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0018">18c</a>. It should be noted that dangling carbon bonds are very reactive and may serve as sites for the functionalization of HC structures.
