Line defects are HC imperfections caused by vacancy defects.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0215" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0215_R_d154663148e11543" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 215 - Mater. Today">215</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> As the name suggests, they occur in the carbon atom plane as aligned point defects with or without dangling bonds;<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0217" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0217_R_d154663148e11548" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 217 - Phys. Rev. B">217</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> see Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0018">18d</a>. Edge defects can also be present in HC, considering that the graphene layer is terminated by edge atoms that are free or passivated with hydrogen atoms. Edges in the zigzag or armchair direction are commonly observed and are very reactive.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0218" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0218_R_d154663148e11557" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 218 - RSC Adv.">218</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Regarding the effect of defects on electrochemical behavior, Olsson et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0214" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0214_R_d154663148e11565" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 214 - Small">214</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> demonstrated, through DFT simulations, that sodium ion storage may be considerably affected, positively and negatively, by structural defects. The authors showed that the presence of defective sites may increase the adsorption of Na<sup>+</sup> and improve the sodiation process. The same observations were confirmed by Wang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0219" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0219_R_d154663148e11572" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 219 - ChemElectroChem">219</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> for lithium-ion batteries. Furthermore, Yoon et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0220" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0220_R_d154663148e11578" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 220 - Npj Computat.Mater.">220</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> suggested that a high concentration of defects may result in a high capacity for sodium batteries. Interestingly, for the anode–electrolyte contact and the sodiation phenomena, the location of defect sites is crucial and should be fully considered. On the negative side, highly energetic defective sites might result in a metal trapping effect, resulting in poor electrochemical performance.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0214" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0214_R_d154663148e11583" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 214 - Small">214</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> These results show that controlling the nature and location of defects is critical to achieving improved electrochemical performance.</p>
            
            <p>The most common characterization techniques for studying the structural defects in HCs are Raman spectroscopy and TPD-MS. Both of these techniques give different but complementary information. Raman spectroscopy provides qualitative information on the internal organization of the carbon and the degree of disorder (thorough <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio), while TPD-MS provides quantitative information on the total number of active sites (comprising in-plane and edge defects) present in the HC structure by determining the active surface area (ASA).</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0090">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="aenm202303833-sec-0090-title">3.5.1 Probing Local Carbon Structure with Raman Spectroscopy</h4>
               
               <p>Raman spectroscopy is a local and non-destructive chemical examination technique that offers comprehensive information regarding the structure of HC and is commonly used as a structural analysis auxiliary to XRD and TEM. Raman spectroscopy has proven to be the most sensitive method for investigating the disorder in sp<sup>2</sup> of diverse carbon structures, making it an essential technique for characterizing HC materials. In a typical HC Raman spectrum, two important peaks are identified, D and G, in the visible wavelength range. The G band (referring to graphite) is located at ≈1600 cm<sup>−1</sup> and relative to the in-plane optical phonon modes of carbon with a sp<sup>2</sup> hybridized atomic orbital (C−C).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0221" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0221_R_d154663148e11611" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 221 - Solid State Commun.">221</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0222" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0222_R_d154663148e11611" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 222 - Phys. Rev. B">222</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The D-band, located at ≈1350 cm<sup>−1</sup>, is the result of the breathing modes of carbon rings.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0221" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0221_R_d154663148e11619" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 221 - Solid State Commun.">221</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0222" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0222_R_d154663148e11619" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 222 - Phys. Rev. B">222</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This band, known as the disorder band, appears exclusively when the carbon ring is adjacent to a defective zone (sp<sup>3</sup> carbon).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0223" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0223_R_d154663148e11626" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 223 - J. Phys.-Condens.Matter">223</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The area/intensity ratio of D and G bands (<i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub>) can be used as an indicator of the level of disorder/defects in HCs. In other words, this parameter is related to the ratio of sp<sup>3</sup> and sp<sup>2</sup> carbon. Importantly, the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio is dependent on the laser excitation frequency, especially the sp<sup>2</sup> carbon, which might affect the observed results.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0224" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0224_R_d154663148e11651" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 224 - Philos. Trans. R. Soc. A.">224</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0225" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0225_R_d154663148e11651" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 225 - Nano Lett.">225</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Moreover, different ways of calculating the ratio are reported in the literature, making a fair comparison of the available data difficult: i) by implying the area under the peaks, ii) by implying the intensity of the peaks, iii) using the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio, and iv) using the I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>D</sub>+I<sub>G</sub> ratio or even FWHM<sub>D</sub>/FWHM<sub>G</sub>. The area under the peaks is more accurate and recommended since it considers peak width.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0222" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0222_R_d154663148e11674" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 222 - Phys. Rev. B">222</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0226" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0226_R_d154663148e11674" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 226 - Carbon">226</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <p><b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0019">19</a> shows the variation in the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio with temperature for HC derived from various precursors. The <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio decreases as the pyrolysis temperature increases, regardless of the precursor source. However, for a few materials heat-treated below 1000 °C, the trend is the opposite, i.e., macadamia,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0065" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0065_R_d154663148e11698" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 65 - Nano Energy">65</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> soybean roots,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0227" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0227_R_d154663148e11703" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 227 - Carbon">227</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> cellulose,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0031" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0031_R_d154663148e11709" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 31 - J. Energy Chem.">31</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and phloroglucinol spheres.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e11714" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This is caused by the structural changes during the thermal treatment that occur in two distinct regimes: i) the initial pyrolysis phase (600–1000 °C) in which the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio increases often due to the release of precursor heteroatoms and ii) the “pseudo-graphitization” phase (&gt;1000 °C) in which the I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> ratio usually decreases as the temperature rises, which is related to carbon ordering (sp<sup>2</sup>) enhancement.</p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0019"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/437a0884-bdc7-4f7c-b480-064e8c62403f/aenm202303833-fig-0019-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/437a0884-bdc7-4f7c-b480-064e8c62403f/aenm202303833-fig-0019-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/38019465-024f-44e0-aa7a-c89b8c3284bf/aenm202303833-fig-0019-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/437a0884-bdc7-4f7c-b480-064e8c62403f/aenm202303833-fig-0019-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 19<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0019&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Evolution of the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio with pyrolysis temperature for the different classes of precursors: a) biomasses, b) biopolymers and c) synthetic polymers. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               <p>Qiu et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0046" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0046_R_d154663148e11764" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 46 - Adv. Energy Mater.">46</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported that increasing the pyrolysis temperature of cellulose from 900 to 1500 °C yields HC with a decrease in the (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>D</sub>+I<sub>G</sub>) ratio from 0.65 to 0.58, further confirming the reduction in defect content. Yang et&nbsp;al. confirmed<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0198" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0198_R_d154663148e11776" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 198 - J. Power Sources">198</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> the same behavior. When increasing the pyrolysis treatment from 900 to 1700 °C, a clear decrease in <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> from 1.35 to 1.04 was observed for spherical HC derived from starch. Furthermore, Xiao et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0228" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0228_R_d154663148e11788" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 228 - Adv. Energy Mater.">228</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> showed that the pyrolysis rate may have a significant effect on the growth of carbon planes. The authors indicated that the (I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>D</sub>+I<sub>G</sub>) ratio of HC prepared from sucrose at 1300 °C was reduced from 0.76 to 0.65 as the pyrolysis ramp decreased from 5 °C min<sup>−1</sup> to 0.5 °C min<sup>−1</sup>. This result was attributed to the formation of integrated hexagonal carbon rings with lower defective basal planes at a low pyrolysis rate. In addition, Wang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0229" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0229_R_d154663148e11804" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 229 - Rare Met.">229</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> demonstrated that acidic treatment (e.g., H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>) can reduce the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio from 2.7 to 2.1 for HC produced from Platanus biomass. Marino et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0082" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0082_R_d154663148e11820" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 82 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">82</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> investigated the impact of several atmospheres (Ar, N<sub>2</sub>, and Ar/H<sub>2</sub>) on the properties of HC derived from lignin-based bio-waste. The authors deconvoluted the Raman spectra according to the procedure of Sadezky et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0226" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0226_R_d154663148e11830" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 226 - Carbon">226</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and found that the A<sub>D3</sub>/A<sub>G</sub> ratio was smaller when HC was treated under a reducing atmosphere (Ar/H<sub>2</sub>), suggesting fewer adsorbed molecules on the surface.</p>
               
               <p>In addition to the temperature and synthesis conditions, the precursor source used has an impact on the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio. In Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0019">19</a>, slightly higher <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratios can be seen when biomass precursors are used to prepare HC compared to those of biopolymers and synthetic polymers. This is mainly a result of the high impurity content and the presence of heteroatoms in biomass precursors. The latter has an impact on the degree of graphitization and sometimes leads to heterogeneous structures (disordered and highly graphitized).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0102" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0102_R_d154663148e11860" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 102 - J. Environ. Chem. Eng.">102</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e11860" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In such cases, the acquisition of Raman spectra in different zones is needed, as is the analysis of second-order Raman peaks, such as the 2D (also called G′) peak (≈2700 cm<sup>−1</sup>), which provides information on the graphitized regions.</p>
               
               <p>Heteroatom doping (P,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0205" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0205_R_d154663148e11871" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 205 - Adv. Energy Mater.">205</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> B,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0230" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0230_R_d154663148e11876" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 230 - J. Mater. Chem. A">230</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> S,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0231" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0231_R_d154663148e11881" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 231 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">231</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> N,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0232" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0232_R_d154663148e11887" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 232 - Electrochim. Acta">232</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> F,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0093" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0093_R_d154663148e11892" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 93 - J. Phys. Chem. C">93</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> etc.) can be used to intentionally alter the local structure of HCs, with the aim of enhancing the electrochemical storage capability in SIBs. Recently, Li et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0205" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0205_R_d154663148e11898" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 205 - Adv. Energy Mater.">205</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> examined the effects of P, B, and S heteroatoms on the turbostratic nanodomains of a HC derived from sucrose. Compared to undoped HC (1.30 ratio), phosphorus doping increased the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio to 1.39, boron presence led to a decrease in the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio to 1.15, and S doping led to a similar result as boron (1.18 ratio). These findings were consistent with the structural TEM observations. When P heteroatoms are introduced, smaller or more curved graphene sheets appear, while B drives the appearance of large areas of graphitic layers.</p>
               
               <p>Regarding the effect on the electrochemical performance, P and S doping led to an increase of the reversible capacity delivered: 359&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for P-HC and 328 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for S-HC, compared to 283 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for the pristine HC. In the case of B-doped HC, the capacity observed was very low, 147 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, along with a low iCE of 36% only. The authors linked the high-energy in-plane “defect” sites inside turbostratic nanodomains to the poor performance. Agrawal et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0232" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0232_R_d154663148e11927" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 232 - Electrochim. Acta">232</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> also observed an increase in the disordering of the HC structure after nitrogen doping. Moreover, the authors stated that such an increase may facilitate the reaction sites for the Na ion. Indeed, the electrochemical performance delivered by the doped materials confirmed this assumption. The reversible capacity improved from 205 to 266 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for N-doped micron-sized HC and from 230 to 286 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for N-doped nano-sized HC. An improvement was observed for the iCE, as well. Similarly, Wu et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0230" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0230_R_d154663148e11937" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 230 - J. Mater. Chem. A">230</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> observed that doping HC with B heteroatoms (based on glucose precursor) increases the degree of disorder from 2.66 (undoped HC) to 3.05 <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio. Contrary to the previous study, Wu and co-authors found that B doping increases the reversible capacity delivered by the HC in the first cycle, from ≈175 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> (pristine HC) to 230 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> (B doped HC).</p>
               
               <p>Fluorine, a highly electronegative element, also proved to be an efficient dopant to tune the HC structure and lower the energy barrier for Na<sup>+</sup> insertion.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0233" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0233_R_d154663148e11958" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 233 - RSC Adv.">233</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Kong et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0166" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0166_R_d154663148e11963" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 166 - Transact. Tianjin Uni.">166</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported a pretreatment method (4 h in a reacting stove under F<sub>2</sub>/N<sub>2</sub> gas) for F doping to induce more defects in the HC structure. By varying the reaction temperature from 50 °C to 150 °C, the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio increased from 1.01 (undoped HC) to 1.07 for the HC doped at 150 °C. Other similar strategies imply the use of multiple dopants (typically two, (N/S,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0234" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0234_R_d154663148e11980" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 234 - Energy">234</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> S/P,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0235" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0235_R_d154663148e11985" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 235 - Appl. Sci.-Basel">235</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and B/P<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0236" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0236_R_d154663148e11990" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 236 - Electrochem. Commun.">236</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) to obtain a synergistic effect, but this route is rather rarely approached. For instance, Qin et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0237" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0237_R_d154663148e11996" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 237 - Carbon">237</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> developed HC from corn stalks and doped it with both nitrogen and phosphorus. As revealed by the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio, this strategy led to a higher number of structural defects with values of&nbsp;1.69 for N/P-doped HC vs. 1.56 for undoped HC.</p>
               
               <p>As shown from these examples, it is complicated to compare the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> absolute values from different articles. Due to the different ways of calculating them, only their tendency can be compared. According to the findings presented above, the final <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> value is strongly influenced by the pyrolysis conditions (i.e., temperature, heating rate, atmosphere, dopants, etc.), as well as the HC resources used.</p>
               </section>
            
            <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0100">
               
               <h4 class="article-section__sub-title section3" id="aenm202303833-sec-0100-title">3.5.2 Active Surface Area&nbsp;(ASA) Determined by TPD-MS</h4>
               
               <p>Raman analysis is an essential technique for the structural investigation of HCs, but the evaluation of defects based on the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio is qualitative only, and in addition, it does not take into account microporosity-induced defects. Moreover, the multiple ways of calculating the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio make the comparison of the results difficult. A powerful approach to derive the quantitative evaluation of HC defects/active sites is the determination of the active surface area (ASA) by TPD-MS, which is associated with chemically accessible and reactive sites that allow covalent bonds.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0238" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0238_R_d154663148e12045" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 238 - J. Phys. Chem. B">238</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> More precisely, ASA includes the areas of different carbon edge planes and the defects (i.e., dislocations, vacancies, point defects, and Stone–Wales defects).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0239" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0239_R_d154663148e12050" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 239 - J. Phys. Chem">239</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0240" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0240_R_d154663148e12050" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 240 - J. Mater. Chem. A">240</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> To distinguish it from the total specific surface area (TSA, called also SSA), one should consider that SSA determined by gas adsorption comprises both the basal planes and the edge planes/defects (ASA), as illustrated in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0020">20a</a>. To assess the ASA, the surface of HC that was previously “cleaned” (oxygen-based functional groups removed under a secondary vacuum), was exposed to oxygen chemisorption (300 °C). The newly formed surface oxygenated groups were quantified by TPD-MS, and the active surface area was determined. More precisely, ASA formula considers the amount of CO and CO<sub>2</sub> desorbed during TPD-MS (up to 950 °C) and the area of an edge carbon site, assuming that: i) the effective area of a carbon atom edge is 0.083 nm<sup>2</sup>, ii) the edge carbons lie in the (100) plane, and that iii) only one bond is formed between oxygen and the edge carbon.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e12066" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0180" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0180_R_d154663148e12066" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Adv.">180</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
                  <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0020"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/00dbc798-0022-4038-8dcb-32cfe5f51235/aenm202303833-fig-0020-m.jpg"><picture>
                           <source srcset="/cms/asset/00dbc798-0022-4038-8dcb-32cfe5f51235/aenm202303833-fig-0020-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/a2794b4f-3196-4697-a449-f31f159f95f2/aenm202303833-fig-0020-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/00dbc798-0022-4038-8dcb-32cfe5f51235/aenm202303833-fig-0020-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                        <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 20<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0020&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                        </div>
                        <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Schematic representation of a hard carbon crystallite showing the total surface area (TSA- related to basal/edge planes and defects) and active surface area (ASA – related to edge planes and defects). Reproduced under the terms of CC BY-NC 3.0 DEED license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0180" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0180_R_d154663148e12089" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Adv.">180</a></span>], Copyright 2022, The Authors, Published by Royal Society of Chemistry. b) Active surface area obtained by oxygen chemisorption and subsequent TPD-MS analyses on hard carbon materials obtained at different pyrolysis temperatures. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                     </figcaption>
                  </figure>
               </section>
               <p>Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0020">20b</a> presents an overview of the data available in the literature on ASA for HC materials. This technique is very particular, and few laboratories have it available. One may observe that ASA is highly influenced by both pyrolysis temperature and precursor origin, with the reported ASA values between ≈53 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (potato peel at 1300 °C<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e12106" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) and 0.36 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (polyacrylonitrile at 2800 °C<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e12116" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>). In general, as the pyrolysis temperature increases, the ASA of HCs decreases, as is the case for cellulose precursors<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e12121" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (from 44 to 1 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> when the temperature varied from 1000 to 1600 °C) or phenolic resin spheres<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e12131" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> (from ≈12 to 1.3 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> when temperature increased from 1300 to 1600 °C). In effect, high-temperature pyrolysis can minimize the number of active sites in the material by minimizing structural imperfections and promoting the formation of pseudo-graphitic nanodomains. These findings were confirmed by Zhang et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e12141" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> using a polyacrylonitrile polymer as a HC nanofiber precursor. When the pyrolysis temperature was increased from 950 to 2800 °C, the ASA value was significantly reduced from 23 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> to 0.36 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. The authors attribute this tendency to the increase in structural organization, which is possible at high pyrolysis temperatures (≥ 2000 °C), as sustained by the TEM micrographs.</p>
               
               <p>Moreover, the values of ASA depend greatly on the precursor type since each material has a unique composition and a particular structure. For example, precursors exempt from oxygen result in lower ASA values, i.e., 0.6 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for polyacrylonitrile<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e12161" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> versus 17 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for phenolic resin<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0185" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0185_R_d154663148e12171" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 185 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">185</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> rich in oxygen functionalities, with both treated at 1500 °C. The gap in ASA induced by the precursors can reach ≈98% at low temperatures (&lt;1400 °C) when comparing a biomass (≈53 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for potato<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e12181" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) with a synthetic polymer (≈1.2 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for polyacrylonitrile<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e12190" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) heat treated at a similar temperature (≈at 1300 °C)). This difference tends to decrease at high temperatures (&gt;1500 °C). For example, the series of biopolymers treated at 1500 °C present ASAs between 7.1 and 1.3 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0115" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0115_R_d154663148e12200" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 115 - J. Mater. Chem. A">115</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0174" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0174_R_d154663148e12200" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 174 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">174</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
               
               <p>Since each material has unique structural and chemical composition features, this wide range of ASA values demonstrates that this parameter is an intrinsic property of each material. Ghimbeu's team noted that for the same pyrolysis temperature (i.e., 1400 °C), the existence of heteroatoms in the structure of HC precursors (e.g., N, S) leads to higher ASA values (i.e., 21.8 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for TCA phenolic resin), in contrast to precursors that include only oxygen (i.e., 3.3 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> for phenolic resin spheres).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0180" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0180_R_d154663148e12215" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Adv.">180</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> This observation is in line with the Raman studies presented above showing an increase in the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio for doped carbon materials. A significant impact of metal-based impurities present on the structure of the precursors on ASA values was also highlighted.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e12227" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Such metal impurities might induce the formation of metallic oxides during O<sub>2</sub> chemisorption, which further reacts with carbon during the TPD-MS measurement, releasing important amounts of additional CO<sub>x</sub> gas. To address this issue, a washing treatment prior to or after pyrolysis was proposed,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e12237" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and it proved to be efficient in certain cases. For example, the ASA value of an HC produced from potato peel waste was reduced from 52.6 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> to 43.3 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> when washing was performed after heat treatment and to 11.5 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> when washing was done prior to heat treatment.</p>
               
               <p>The determination of ASA for HC is essential in terms of understanding and optimizing Na storage in HC anodes. Recently, it was shown that there is a strong correlation between the active surface area and the irreversible capacity observed in the first cycle.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0180" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0180_R_d154663148e12259" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Adv.">180</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> More precisely, when the ASA is reduced, the initial irreversible capacity decreases considerably, which makes this HC feature of great interest.</p>
               </section>
            </section>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0110">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202303833-sec-0110-title">4 Relationship Between Hard Carbon Properties and Electrochemical Performance</h2>
         
         <p>The electrochemical performance of hard carbon-based electrodes is closely dependent on the structural, chemical, textural, and morphological features of the active material. Thus, by altering the properties of the HC, it is possible to significantly enhance reaction kinetics, ion transport, Coulombic efficiency, and the battery's cycle life. However, in addition to HC features, testing conditions (e.g., electrode formulation, presence of additives, electrolyte formulation, current rate, etc.) can also significantly influence the performance of the material. To our knowledge, for the evaluation of the electrochemical performance of battery materials at the laboratory scale, no international standardization exists, contrary to other characterization techniques. Therefore, it is very difficult to compare the results of one study with another. Nevertheless, some rough tendencies between the properties of a wide range of HCs available in the literature and the electrochemical performance delivered by those materials were observed and are discussed in the following sections. The presented correlations are based on existing knowledge of the electrochemical performance (e.g. iCE and reversible capacity) and the physical-chemical characteristics that have a major influence on these electrochemical parameters, as shown in Tables <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2</a>, <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0003">3</a> and <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0004">4</a>.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0120">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0120-title">4.1 N<sub>2</sub> SSA Influence on iCE</h3>
            
            <p><b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0021">21</a> presents the influence of N<sub>2</sub> SSA on the iCE, for a wide range of HC materials reported in the literature. The HCs were grouped on the basis of the precursor origin, namely, biomasses, biopolymers, and synthetic polymers, as in the previous sections. In general, it can be observed that regardless of the precursor, lower N<sub>2</sub> SSA values are more favorable to obtaining a higher iCE %. However, this tendency is less visible in the case of biomass-derived HCs. Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0021">21a</a> presents the results for biomass-derived HC materials. To some extent, the tendency of iCE to increase with the decrease in N<sub>2</sub> SSA is observed, especially within the same series of precursors, for example, date palm pulp, mangosteen shell, sugarcane bagasse, etc. However, for low N<sub>2</sub> SSA values (&lt;20 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>), very different iCE values are observed for HC materials prepared with different precursors. i.e., ≈40% (for grapefruit peels and ginko leaves) vs. ≈80% (for beechwood HC) and ≈85% (for mangosteen shells). This might be due to the fact that for some materials the available surface area cannot be fully assessed by N<sub>2</sub> gas, therefore, the material surface is underestimated.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0176" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0176_R_d154663148e12316" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - J. Mater. Chem. A">176</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Another reason can be that other parameters may affect iCE. In this direction, biomass-derived HCs are known to have very rich surface chemistry (heteroelements) and chemical composition (inorganic minerals), a feature that has been shown to have a significant influence on the iCE, along with porosity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e12322" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e12322" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Moreover, the active surface area of the materials also has a major impact on the iCE delivered by the materials, as shown elsewhere.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0180" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0180_R_d154663148e12327" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Adv.">180</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0021"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/9310b3b4-413c-4828-99a8-085474a1cbbf/aenm202303833-fig-0021-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/9310b3b4-413c-4828-99a8-085474a1cbbf/aenm202303833-fig-0021-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/cbde4078-2ea2-44a2-8447-1b5132b10a31/aenm202303833-fig-0021-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/9310b3b4-413c-4828-99a8-085474a1cbbf/aenm202303833-fig-0021-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 21<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0021&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Initial Coulombic Efficiency as a function of the N<sub>2</sub> SSA for the 3 types of precursors: a) Biomass, b) Biopolymers, and c) Synthetic polymers. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>In the case of biopolymers and synthetic polymers, Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0021">21b,c</a>, the relationship between iCE and N<sub>2</sub> SSA is more obvious. A significant decrease in the iCE is observed for the HCs having high N<sub>2</sub> SSA. For example, Zhong et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0272" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0272_R_d154663148e12366" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 272 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">272</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported an iCE value of only 23% for a glucose-derived HC having an N<sub>2</sub> SSA of 475.9 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. On the contrary, a high iCE of ≈85% was reported for materials with low N<sub>2</sub> SSA (below 10 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>), i.e., mimosa and myrobalan tannin HCs,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0189" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0189_R_d154663148e12385" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 189 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">189</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> cellulose-derived HC,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0083" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0083_R_d154663148e12390" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 83 - Renewable Energy">83</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> glucose-based HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0228" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0228_R_d154663148e12395" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 228 - Adv. Energy Mater.">228</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The high iCE of some biopolymer HCs can be explained by the chemical composition of precursors which contain fewer impurities than biomass ones, and therefore the surface chemistry of HCs affects less the iCE. Furthermore, for synthetic polymers that are rather pure precursors (no inorganics) and have low oxygen content, the correlation between iCE and N<sub>2</sub> SSA is less impacted by other physicochemical parameters. This might also explain why the best correlation between iCE and N<sub>2</sub> SSA was obtained for this category of precursors (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0021">21c</a>).</p>
            
            <p>However, if one considers a particular precursor, it is rather difficult to find a linear correlation between iCE and SSA, since there are so many other parameters that impact the iCE, e.g., <i>d</i>-spacing, ultramicroporosity (which is not accessible by N<sub>2</sub>), surface chemistry, electrochemical testing conditions, etc. For example, Li. et&nbsp;al. developed HCs with different N<sub>2</sub> SSAs, from pitch and lignin.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0119" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0119_R_d154663148e12417" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 119 - J. Mater. Chem. A">119</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The authors reported an iCE of 82% for an HC with an N<sub>2</sub> SSA of 4.3 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> and only 75% iCE for an HC with a very similar N<sub>2</sub> SSA (4.5 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>). Furthermore, a similar iCE value (74%) was found for an HC with a significantly higher N<sub>2</sub> SSA than the previous HCs, 34.7 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. Therefore, the linear trend between iCE and N<sub>2</sub> SSA is not present in several cases due to other factors. For example, the authors mentioned the high degree of crystallinity, which might lead to Na<sup>+</sup> trapping between the graphene layers with narrow interlayer distances. Another reason may be the fact that the overall porosity cannot be accessed by N<sub>2</sub> adsorption, as explained in Section&nbsp;<a class="sectionLink scrollableLink" href="#aenm202303833-sec-0060">3.3</a>. No correlation was observed between iCE and N<sub>2</sub> SSA, however, when using O<sub>2</sub> gas, an increase in iCE was noticed with the decrease in O<sub>2</sub> SSA.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0176" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0176_R_d154663148e12458" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 176 - J. Mater. Chem. A">176</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In fact, later on, the same authors showed a linear relationship between iCE and O<sub>2</sub> SSA by using several types of carbons.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0180" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0180_R_d154663148e12466" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Adv.">180</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> They pointed out as well, that narrow pores (ultra-micropores) are the most responsible for the decrease in iCE. For the commercial HCs reported in the literature which present low SSAs, a high iCE is reported in general, superior to 80%. Nevertheless, an iCE as high as 92% was reported for a Kuranode HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0269" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0269_R_d154663148e12471" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 269 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">269</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0270" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0270_R_d154663148e12471" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 270">270</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0130">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0130-title">4.2 Active Surface Area Influence on iCE</h3>
            
            <p>The active surface area has been reported to be involved in irreversible electrochemical reactions and therefore has a significant impact on the iCE. <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0022">22a</a> resumes the correlation between iCE and ASA obtained based on all articles in the literature reporting both these parameters, no matter the category of precursor. Generally, it can be seen in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0022">22a</a> that higher ASA values are unfavorable for iCE, in a similar way as for N<sub>2</sub> SSA. Furthermore, the same tendency is observed for each individual category of precursors (biomass, biopolymers, or synthetic polymers).</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0022"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/2e4b967c-0138-4ff9-aa62-0dfcd485e88a/aenm202303833-fig-0022-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/2e4b967c-0138-4ff9-aa62-0dfcd485e88a/aenm202303833-fig-0022-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/5f386eca-2856-4ef6-99c1-532a87b9563f/aenm202303833-fig-0022-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/2e4b967c-0138-4ff9-aa62-0dfcd485e88a/aenm202303833-fig-0022-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 22<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0022&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Initial Coulombic efficiency&nbsp;as a function of ASA for the three classes of precursors. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>. b) Relationship between iCE and ASA. Adapted under the terms of CC BY-NC 3.0 DEED license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0180" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0180_R_d154663148e12517" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Adv.">180</a></span>], Copyright 2022, The Authors, Published by Royal Society of Chemistry.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Only PAN-derived HC deviates from this trend, and this is only when the ASA values are very low, namely below 1 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>, and correspond to very high annealing temperatures, 2200–2800 °C. This can be explained by the structural characteristics of these materials, which exhibit very small interlayer distances, for example, 0.343 nm at 2800 °C, values very close to those of graphite (0.335 nm).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e12528" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The authors reported that such low values of d<sub>002</sub> significantly reduce the plateau capacity gain and favor Na<sup>+</sup> trapping between the graphene layers, thus inducing a low iCE.</p>
            
            <p>When the materials are heat-treated at lower temperatures, i.e., 1200–1500 °C, and the physicochemical parameters are not drastically impacted, the correlation between iCE and ASA is maintained. Ghimbeu's group, which is among the few to analyze the ASA parameter on HCs, recently highlighted its importance on iCE (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0022">22b</a>). The authors could evidence, by employing different precursors (i.e., biopolymers or synthetic polymers) or annealing temperatures (1300–1600 °C), that the irreversible capacity is reduced, therefore, the iCE is improved, when ASA values are diminished.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0180" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0180_R_d154663148e12544" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 180 - Energy Adv.">180</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0140">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0140-title">4.3 Ash Content Influence on Electrochemical Performance</h3>
            
            <p>Another parameter that was observed to have an impact on the iCE is the ash content of the materials. This parameter is particularly evaluated for biomass-derived HCs, with <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0023">23</a> summarizing the articles that report this feature. Although the number of papers reporting it is limited, a nice linear trend with iCE can be observed (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0023">23a</a>). Regardless of the precursor, higher wmf % negatively impacts iCE. This can be explained by the involvement of “ash” in different undesirable reactions. On the one hand, inorganics can affect the properties of materials during synthesis, e.g., an increase of SSA (for Na, K, Ca-based), local graphitization (for K, Ca, Fe, and Si-based), growth of nanostructures (Si-based), a decrease of electronic conductivity (all impurities),<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0030" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0030_R_d154663148e12565" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 30 - Carbon">30</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e12565" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0137" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0137_R_d154663148e12565" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 137 - Sustai. Mater., Technol.">137</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> which favor the electrolyte decomposition, Na-ion trapping, etc. On the other hand, the inorganic impurities can also interact with the electrolyte leading to its decomposition and, in some cases, to its dissolution. It is worth mentioning that the better trend observed in this case might be related, to a certain extent, to the similar electrochemical conditions used for all the materials (e.g., electrode and electrolyte formulation, current density, and cycling regime), since all materials are reported by the same research group.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e12571" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0023"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/0fd0e3be-d535-4f10-b9c0-19f8fb63f901/aenm202303833-fig-0023-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/0fd0e3be-d535-4f10-b9c0-19f8fb63f901/aenm202303833-fig-0023-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/af6ee042-946d-4cf4-a08d-5fe82bb05c06/aenm202303833-fig-0023-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/0fd0e3be-d535-4f10-b9c0-19f8fb63f901/aenm202303833-fig-0023-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 23<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0023&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Initial Coulombic efficiency and b) specific reversible capacity as a function of the ash content for the biomass precursors. The graphs were built based on the Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e12594" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a></span>].</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Not only iCE is impacted by the ash content, but so is the reversible capacity delivered by the materials. Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0023">23b</a> shows that when the percentage of “ash” increases, the obtained reversible capacity decreases significantly. Rios et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0135" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0135_R_d154663148e12604" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 135 - Fuel Process. Technol.">135</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> illustrated very well this trend by using a wide number and types of precursors. The authors reported a reversible capacity of ≈300 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for a sunflower seed HC with an ash content of 3.2 wmf %, 256 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for a papaya seed HC with an ash content of 6.7 wmf % and only ≈170 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for a rice husk HC with an ash content as high as 14.7 wmf %. The latter behavior is explained by a reduced carbon content in the materials when the ash wmf % is high, and by the nature of impurities (Si and Ca-based) which graphitized the carbon and led to the growth of SiC whiskers and the decrease in the graphitic interlayer space. This induces a limited capacity delivered by the material.</p>
            
            <p>From a more general point of view, the authors concluded that the HC derived from woody and agriculture biomass precursors presents a low content of inorganic ash in their precursor (0.8 wmf % for Beechwood to 6.7 wmf % for Papaya seeds) and very good performance (iCE ≈85% and capacity of ≈300 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for Beechwood). On the contrary, the HC obtained with grassy biomass presents a higher amount of ash (2.8 wmf % for Miscanthus to 14.6 wmf % for rice husk) and lower performance. Although among the three classes of biomass, the ash composition is similar (i.e., Na, K, Ca, Mg, Si, and Fe), their total amounts and proportions are significantly different. HCs with lower impurity concentrations, and therefore higher carbon contents, limit irreversible reactions with the electrolyte and promote electrode conductivity, improving electrochemical performance (i.e., reversible capacity ≈300 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and iCE ≈85%). The HCs rich in Si and Ca lead to the worse performance.</p>
            
            <p>Because the ash content proves to have an important influence on the electrochemical performance of HC materials, its determination should be considered mandatory for all HC materials. Currently, this is determined on limited HC materials, mainly biomass-based ones, although biopolymers and synthetic polymers might also contain.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0030" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0030_R_d154663148e12626" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 30 - Carbon">30</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Commercial HC technical sheets do not provide such information either, despite its high interest.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0267" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0267_R_d154663148e12631" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 267">267</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0268" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0268_R_d154663148e12631" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 268">268</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0270" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0270_R_d154663148e12631" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 270">270</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0150">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0150-title">4.4 Interlayer Space Influence on the Specific Reversible Capacity</h3>
            
            <p>The distance between layers (d<sub>002</sub>) is an important characteristic of HC, directly involved in the storage mechanism of Na<sup>+</sup>, and is often linked to the capacity delivered by the materials. <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0024">24</a> summarizes the influence of the value of d<sub>002</sub> on the reversible capacity, among the three categories of precursors: biomass, biopolymers, and synthetic polymers. First, it can be noticed that there is a wide range of d<sub>002</sub> values reported in the literature, i.e., 3.4 Å – 4.2 Å, corresponding to reversible capacities comprised between a few mAh g<sup>−1</sup> (14 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for a grapefruit peel HC)<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0203" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0203_R_d154663148e12663" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 203 - Electrochim. Acta">203</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> and 430 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> (shaddock peel HC).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0197" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0197_R_d154663148e12671" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 197 - J. Mater. Chem. A">197</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Second, no general trend can be observed, but some particularities are present for each category of precursors.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0024"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/c119f9e0-85f0-4e18-b58c-98faf895002e/aenm202303833-fig-0024-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/c119f9e0-85f0-4e18-b58c-98faf895002e/aenm202303833-fig-0024-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/b1d77d4f-84e5-4a07-a77d-08ca64e7cb88/aenm202303833-fig-0024-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/c119f9e0-85f0-4e18-b58c-98faf895002e/aenm202303833-fig-0024-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 24<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0024&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Specific reversible capacities as a function of the interlayer spacing, d<sub>002</sub> for the 3 types of precursors: a) Biomass, b) Biopolymers, and c) Synthetic polymers. The graphs were built based on the references presented in Tables&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0002">2–4</a>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>In the case of biomass-derived HC (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0024">24a</a>), most of the interlayer distance values are between 3.7 Å and 3.9 Å while the reversible capacity delivered is mainly between 250 and 300 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. For HCs derived from biopolymers presented in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0024">24b</a>, the points are very randomly located, especially for materials with a d<sub>002</sub> value superior to 3.9 Å, for which the reversible capacity varies between 75 and 361 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>.</p>
            
            <p>For HC derived from synthetic polymers, although the points presented in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0024">24c</a> are highly dispersed, a bell-curve trend can be depicted. The highest reversible capacities are obtained for materials with a d-spacing between 3.7 Å and 3.9 Å, while outside these limits, materials tend to deliver lower reversible capacities. This can be due to either the steric effects (d<sub>002</sub> &lt;3.7 Å) or the low conductivity (d<sub>002</sub> &gt;3.9 Å).</p>
            
            <p>This difficulty in establishing correlations between d<sub>002</sub> and the reversible capacity can be related to a certain extent to the fact that the Na<sup>+</sup> storage mechanism relies on several phenomena including adsorption into the porosity, interactions with the surface chemistry (e.g., functional groups, active surface area) and intercalation between the graphene sheets. Each particular phenomenon can be attributed to a certain region of the galvanostatic curve, as will be detailed in the next chapter.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0160">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0160-title">4.5 N<sub>2</sub> Specific Surface Area Influence on the Specific Reversible Capacity</h3>
            
            <p>In addition to the distance between graphene layers, HC porosity is involved in Na<sup>+</sup> storage mechanisms and several authors reported that it correlates with the specific capacity delivered by certain HC anodes. For example, Bommier et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0028_R_d154663148e12746" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Carbon">28</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used sucrose to prepare HCs with a wide range of N<sub>2</sub> SSAs, implying two strategies: different pyrolysis temperatures and CO<sub>2</sub> activation at various temperatures and time durations. N<sub>2</sub> adsorption revealed SSA values between 25 and 1410 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. When the reversible capacity was correlated with the surface area (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0025">25a</a>), a linear trend (<i>R</i><sup>2</sup> = 0.84) showing that a lower SSA leads to an important increase in the reversible capacity delivered by the materials was found. In the same study, the authors revealed an interesting correlation between the reversible capacity and the so-called unexposed carbon atoms (not involved in the surface area).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0028_R_d154663148e12772" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Carbon">28</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> It was shown that the HC materials exhibit the best performance when the highest percentages of unexposed carbon atoms are present, for example, 335 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for 98.4% unexposed carbon atoms (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0025">25b</a>). The authors attributed these observations to the fact that exposed carbons may act as nucleation sites favoring SEI, a passivation layer that limits the access of Na<sup>+</sup> to the carbon structure.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0025"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/cb31e65d-5940-4d58-84d6-b290f77c685d/aenm202303833-fig-0025-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/cb31e65d-5940-4d58-84d6-b290f77c685d/aenm202303833-fig-0025-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/1bf8e33e-8200-42a0-9808-7b9a1ea074d2/aenm202303833-fig-0025-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/cb31e65d-5940-4d58-84d6-b290f77c685d/aenm202303833-fig-0025-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 25<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0025&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Linear and natural logarithm transformed models plotting the reversible capacity as a function of N<sub>2</sub> SSA, b) Reversible capacity vs. logit transform of the percentage of the unexposed carbon atoms. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0028" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0028_R_d154663148e12805" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Carbon">28</a></span>], Copyright 2014, Elsevier c) Reversible capacity vs. N<sub>2</sub> SSA for biopolymers-based HCs using references presented in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0003">3</a>.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Despite these findings, when we tried to represent the reversible capacity as a function of N<sub>2</sub> SSA, for the three categories of precursors, biomass, biopolymers, and synthetic polymers, a trend could hardly be observed, the points being very scattered. Rather a random trend was noticed among the commercial HCs, as well (Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0004">4</a>). Despite their low N<sub>2</sub> SSA (&lt;10 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>), the reversible capacity reported varies between 214 and 295 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>.</p>
            
            <p>Only in the case of biopolymer-derived HC, some tendency could be observed, as presented in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0025">25c</a>. To some extent, it can be seen that the reversible capacity increases when the N<sub>2</sub> SSA is lower, as previously reported by Bommier et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0028" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0028_R_d154663148e12839" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 28 - Carbon">28</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The trend is particularly observed when the sucrose precursor is used to prepare the HCs, while for the other precursors, the distribution is rather random. This might be due to the fact that for certain precursors that undergo specific heat treatments, other HC parameters play an important role in the capacity delivered by the materials. For example, Beda et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e12844" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported that N<sub>2</sub> SSA provides a very poor correlation (<i>R</i><sup>2</sup> = 0.3) with the capacity delivered by several HCs prepared from phenolic resins, heat-treated at different temperatures. Other parameters such as electrode porosity, d<sub>002</sub> distance, or CO<sub>2</sub> SSA were found to affect the material's capacity more.</p>
            
            <p>In a different paper, Gomez-Martin and co-authors<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0045" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0045_R_d154663148e12862" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 45 - Chem. Mater.">45</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> showed that the interlayer distance correlates well with the reversible capacity, in particular with the flat plateau region, while Meng et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0193" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0193_R_d154663148e12867" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 193 - ACS Energy Lett.">193</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> improved the HC reversible capacity through closed porosity tuning. In particular, it was found that the capacity of the plateau region is increasing with the percentage of closed porosity. Therefore, it has been reported to be more appropriate to correlate HC properties with either the sloping or the plateau capacity, instead of the reversible capacity delivered by HC materials.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0170">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0170-title">4.6 Different Hard Carbon Properties Influence on Plateau/Sloping Capacity</h3>
            
            <p>Several authors have studied the impact of different HC properties (e.g., d<sub>002</sub>, <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub>, closed porosity, etc.) on both the sloping and flat plateau capacity regions. <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0026">26</a> gathers the most important findings reported in the literature in this direction. Gomez-Martin et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0045" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0045_R_d154663148e12895" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 45 - Chem. Mater.">45</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported a direct correlation between d-spacing and plateau capacity when using HC derived from olive stones, heat-treated between 800 and 2000 ° C.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0045" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0045_R_d154663148e12900" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 45 - Chem. Mater.">45</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> One can see in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0026">26a</a> that the plateau capacity increases with the d<sub>002</sub> value, the best performance being obtained for the material pyrolyzed at 1400 °C. When the temperature increases further to 2000 °C, the capacity decreases progressively, due to the decrease in d<sub>002</sub>. Therefore, a temperature between 1400–1600 °C seems ideal to achieve the highest capacity. Escamilla-Pérez et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0174" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0174_R_d154663148e12913" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 174 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">174</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> reported a similar trend (<i>R</i><sup>2</sup> = 90), only that in this case the authors could show the importance of precursor origin instead of the annealing temperature (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0026">26b</a>). It was found that for a series of HCs derived from biopolymers, heat-treated at the same temperature (i.e., 1500 °C), the capacity gained in the plateau region is more important when the d-spacing is enlarged.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0026"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/8ede1791-9e06-4baa-b208-b0b39dd75c5f/aenm202303833-fig-0026-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/8ede1791-9e06-4baa-b208-b0b39dd75c5f/aenm202303833-fig-0026-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/aa9512e7-d8a3-490e-a72f-706832d02bb6/aenm202303833-fig-0026-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/8ede1791-9e06-4baa-b208-b0b39dd75c5f/aenm202303833-fig-0026-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 26<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0026&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Correlation between the plateau capacity and the graphitic interlayer spacing,d<sub>002</sub>. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0045" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0045_R_d154663148e12946" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 45 - Chem. Mater.">45</a></span>], Copyright 2019, American Chemical Society. Relationship between the plateau capacity of different HCs and b) d<sub>002</sub> and c) closed porosity. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0174" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0174_R_d154663148e12951" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 174 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">174</a></span>], Copyright 2023, American Chemical Society. d) Plot of the sloping capacity vs. the <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e12961" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></span>], Copyright 2015, American Chemical Society. e) Correlations between sloping capacity and the total amounts of CO<sub>x</sub> groups (desorbed during TPD measurements) and ASA and f) Evolution of different hard carbons characteristics vs. sloping and plateau capacities and the annealing temperature of a cellulose-derived HC. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e12966" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a></span>], Copyright 2018, Elsevier.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
