            <p>Also important, the same study revealed that the closed porosity of the material can impact the capacity of the plateau. Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0026">26c</a> shows that the limited presence of closed porosity is beneficial to the gain of capacity in the low voltage plateau region (<i>R</i><sup>2</sup> = 0.88). Other authors found an opposite trend, that is, an increase in plateau capacity with closed pores.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0273" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0273_R_d154663148e12979" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 273 - J. Power Sources">273</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The reason for the discrepancy is related to the properties of the materials synthesized under very different conditions (precursors and temperature) and the indirect quantification of closed porosity via He density/gas adsorption and SAXS, which both present their own limitations. From a more general point of view, there is still no consensus on the closed-pore contribution to the plateau region, as will be detailed later in the storage mechanism part.</p>
            
            <p>In which concerns the sloping capacity, a relationship was found vs. the degree of the disorder (<i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio), as reported by Bommier et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e12993" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> A linear trend can be seen in Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0026">26d</a> (<i>R</i><sup>2</sup> = 0.9) showing that the sloping capacity increases with increasing <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio. The degree of disorder was found to decrease as the annealing temperature increased. Therefore, a lower temperature ensures better capacity. Other authors tried to link the sloping capacity with the active sites (ASA), and oxygen surface functional groups (CO<sub>x</sub>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0040" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0040_R_d154663148e13014" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 40 - Nano Energy">40</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0026">26e</a> shows that the sloping capacity is dependent on both the parameters mentioned above. For the selected HCs (derived from cellulose), higher capacity is gained in the sloping region when materials possess more active sites and CO<sub>x</sub> groups. The same authors collected all the physicochemical properties of the HCs (i.e., structure, porosity, and surface chemistry) and presented them as a function of sloping and plateau capacity (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0026">26f</a>). The sloping capacity was found to be directly proportional to the active surface area (ASA), the surface functional groups (CO<sub>x</sub>), and the micropore volume determined by CO<sub>2</sub> gas adsorption (V<sub>micro</sub> CO<sub>2</sub>). On the contrary, the plateau capacity shows an inversely proportional trend with the sloping capacity and therefore increases while the HC's above-mentioned parameters decrease. Thus, the highest plateau capacity is achieved when the materials are exempted from porosity, surface groups, and active sites and when the d<sub>002</sub> interlayer spaces correspond to the HC obtained between 1400 and 1600 °C (≈0.37 nm).</p>
            
            <p>It should be mentioned that most of the works report the gravimetric capacity of HC materials, and only a limited number of works deal with the volumetric capacity. This parameter is very important when the HC is placed in a real SIB since its volume must be reduced as much as possible. One detailed work on this topic showed that the volumetric capacity depends on a few parameters, the most important being the electrode porosity after calendaring, and lower porosity inducing higher volumetric capacity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0098" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0098_R_d154663148e13041" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 98 - J. Mater. Chem. A">98</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> It was shown that the porosity of the electrode after calendaring can be linearly decreased by increasing the interlayer space. Other factors affecting volumetric capacity were found to be intrinsic HC porosity and particle size. Contrary to what was expected, the tapped density did not impact the volumetric capacity.</p>
            </section>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0180">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202303833-sec-0180-title">5 Sodium Storage Mechanisms in Hard Carbons</h2>
         
         <p>The Na storage mechanism for HC is still controversial and under debate.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13056" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0274" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0274_R_d154663148e13056" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 274 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">274</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0279" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0279_R_d154663148e13056" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 279 - Materials Advances">279</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The interpretation may differ, depending on the different employed carbon precursors. The choice of the precursor (e.g., different varieties of biomass, biopolymers, synthetic precursors, etc.) for HC synthesis plays a critical role in their electrochemical performance due to the difference in the carbon microstructure as well as variations in biomass chemical composition and inorganic impurities present in the precursors.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0280" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0280_R_d154663148e13061" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 280 - Energies">280</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Additionally, the interpretation of the mechanism may differ from one characterization technique to another due to the different probing time scales, bulk and surface sensitivities, and HC microstructures.</p>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0190">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0190-title">5.1 Sodium Storage Mechanism</h3>
            
            <p>As mentioned earlier, assigning and interpreting a particular process to a certain potential range is still a matter of debate. During the sodiation of HCs, four different types of processes are expected: adsorption, intercalation, pore filling, and electrolyte decomposition (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0027">27</a>). Adsorption of Na<sup>+</sup> ions can take place at the HC surface, defect sites, or heteroatoms. Intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> ions into the graphitic layers is expected. The formation of clusters or pooling of Na atoms takes place in the pores of the HCs, filling the open as well as closed pores. Finally, electrolyte decomposition on the carbon surface occurs during initial sodiation, leading to the formation of the solid-electrolyte interphase (SEI) and irreversibly trapping a portion of the Na inventory.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0027"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/02ff010c-9e94-4e94-89bf-ca21884fdc61/aenm202303833-fig-0027-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/02ff010c-9e94-4e94-89bf-ca21884fdc61/aenm202303833-fig-0027-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/672f652f-1a53-4f63-9b05-5166d969d818/aenm202303833-fig-0027-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/02ff010c-9e94-4e94-89bf-ca21884fdc61/aenm202303833-fig-0027-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 27<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0027&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic representation of all possible Na-ion storage mechanisms, as proposed by the authors of this work.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>As both adsorption and filling occur in the pores, it is important to emphasize that the kinetics of both processes are highly dependent on the type of porosity. Adsorption takes place in the open-type porosity, characterized by a capacitive-dominant behavior often associated with the sloping region of charge/discharge curves. In contrast, pores filling occurs in closed pores through a diffusion-dominant process resulting in the formation of quasi-metallic Na clusters, occurring in the low-voltage plateau region of the charge/discharge curves, as proposed by some others.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0191" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0191_R_d154663148e13105" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 191 - Adv. Energy Mater.">191</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0281" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0281_R_d154663148e13105" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 281 - Adv. Mater.">281</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, there is no full agreement on this fact.</p>
            
            <p>Unlike the surface-controlled capacitive adsorption process at the surface of open pores, Na<sup>+</sup> storage in closed pores is regarded as a diffusion-dominant process, as bulk diffusion is essential for Na<sup>+</sup> ion to access the closed pores in HC, corresponding to the plateau region in the charge/discharge curves. However, some disparities appear in the research community, whether Na appears in an ionic or metallic state during pore filling.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0191" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0191_R_d154663148e13117" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 191 - Adv. Energy Mater.">191</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In addition, it is not well understood how Na<sup>+</sup>ions or Na clusters are filling the closed pores because these pores are inaccessible to gases and liquids.</p>
            
            <p>The study by Kim et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0281" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0281_R_d154663148e13127" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 281 - Adv. Mater.">281</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> observed that a multitude of bulk-chemisorbed ions occupied nanometer-scale closed pores surrounded by graphitic domains (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0028">28a</a>). At ≈0 V, weakly chemisorbed ions are released from the defective surface, resulting in a two-phase clustering process within the ion-saturated inner surfaces of the closed pores. The clustering reaction is constrained by the closed pore volume. The disorder parameter (<i>f</i><sub>a</sub>) values obtained from SAXS, associated with the shape and order of closed pores, indicated a transition from a random two-phase mixture to randomly spread globular pores with increasing annealing temperature. This transition disrupted Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion into the overall closed pores, leading to limited plateau capacities, particularly at higher annealing temperatures. This is a very insightful observation, which might suggest that the closed pore filling mechanisms are different, depending on the HC annealing temperatures, and might explain to some extent the contradictory results observed between different works using different materials.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0028"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/8b156fa5-d841-4929-8474-f837c711a6f4/aenm202303833-fig-0028-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/8b156fa5-d841-4929-8474-f837c711a6f4/aenm202303833-fig-0028-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/f7281118-e6bc-4a32-8011-083931eda9db/aenm202303833-fig-0028-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/8b156fa5-d841-4929-8474-f837c711a6f4/aenm202303833-fig-0028-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 28<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0028&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Schematics of the sodium storage mechanism based on the microstructural changes of the HC by thermal annealing: 1) bulk chemisorption and 3) clustering. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0281" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0281_R_d154663148e13164" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 281 - Adv. Mater.">281</a></span>], Copyright 2023, John Wiley and Sons; b) Schematic illustration of the transformation of accessible closed pores. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0282" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0282_R_d154663148e13167" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 282 - Chem. Mater.">282</a></span>], Copyright 2022, American Chemical Society; and c) Schematic representation of the microstructure and the storage of Na<sup>+</sup> ions in closed pores for HCs synthesized at different pyrolysis temperatures. The circles represent closed pores whereas the black lines represent graphene layers. The blue scale represents the extent to which the pores are filled with sodium ions; white indicates empty pores while dark blue indicates fully filled pores. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0283" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0283_R_d154663148e13172" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 283 - Adv. Mater.">283</a></span>], Copyright 2023, John Wiley and Sons.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>The study of Yuan et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0282" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0282_R_d154663148e13179" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 282 - Chem. Mater.">282</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> corroborates the metallic nature of Na during pore filling. Ex situ XPS analysis was employed to examine the binding state of sodium in pitch-derived HC. The Na 1s spectrum for PHC1400 exhibited a stronger peak at 1071.7 eV, shifting to a higher binding energy during discharge to 0.01 V. This indicates the presence of quasi-metallic clusters, serving as evidence for sodium filling in closed pores.</p>
            
            <p>The reversible transformation of the Na 1s spectrum during desodiation confirms the reversibility of closed pore filling. However, the authors propose that not all closed pores offer effective active sites for Na storage, and the accessibility of closed pores depends on diffusion through graphite domains. The size of pseudo-graphite domains, rather than interlayer spacing, plays a significant role in determining whether or not Na<sup>+</sup> ions can enter closed pores. Increased pseudo-graphite domain size reduces channels for Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion, making closed pores less accessible (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0028">28b</a>). However, in many cases, the increase in the lateral size of pseudo-graphitic layers (<i>L</i><sub>a</sub>), is accompanied by the decrease of interlayer space (see Figures&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0009">9</a> and&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0010">10</a>), therefore, both parameters might impact the closed-pore filling.</p>
            
            <p>Meanwhile, Iglesias et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0283" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0283_R_d154663148e13207" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 283 - Adv. Mater.">283</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> report that the nature of Na during pore filling is highly dependent on the pyrolysis temperature. At lower pyrolysis temperatures, smaller pores fill preferentially, while higher temperatures lead to preferential filling of medium-sized pores. They propose the pore-filling mechanism proceeds in sequential steps: Na adsorption to defect sites in pore walls, followed by cluster growth. Higher defect concentration in lower temperature HC favors smaller pore filling, maintaining mainly ionic Na character. Only when this is done, does the filling of larger pores occur, leading to the formation of small clusters. For high-temperature obtained HC, where the defect concentration is lower, the medium-sized pores fill first and have an increased pseudo-metallic sodium character. The authors conclude that the defect concentration and pore characteristics influence Na cluster size and storage capacity (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0028">28c</a>).</p>
            
            <p>Bearing this in mind, the Na storage mechanism can be classified into four distinctive models currently accepted in the Na battery community (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0029">29</a>).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0058" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0058_R_d154663148e13223" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 58 - Prog. Energy">58</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0279" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0279_R_d154663148e13223" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 279 - Materials Advances">279</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Before describing the individual models, it should be noted that electrolyte decomposition and subsequent SEI formation are not included in the mechanism since they are not associated with charge storage processes. However, the formation of a stable and robust SEI is essential for the satisfactory performance of HCs.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0029"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/3a216dc3-1508-45db-b96b-85164e22e7ee/aenm202303833-fig-0029-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/3a216dc3-1508-45db-b96b-85164e22e7ee/aenm202303833-fig-0029-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/0f769058-fb69-47bd-af07-45c0a408cf74/aenm202303833-fig-0029-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/3a216dc3-1508-45db-b96b-85164e22e7ee/aenm202303833-fig-0029-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 29<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0029&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Na storage mechanism divided into four distinctive models: a) intercalation-filling process, b) adsorption-intercalation process, c) adsorption-filling process, and d) three-stage process. Reprinted under Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0058" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0058_R_d154663148e13247" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 58 - Prog. Energy">58</a></span>]. Copyright 2020, The Authors. Published by IOPscience.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>The first model can be described as the intercalation-filling process. Within this model, the sloping region is attributed to Na<sup>+</sup> ion intercalation into graphitic layers. The plateau region is due to Na atom insertion into the HC micropores.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0020" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0020_R_d154663148e13256" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 20 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">20</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0284" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0284_R_d154663148e13256" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 284 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">284</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The second model can be described as the adsorption-intercalation process. In the sloping region, the possible storage sites for the adsorption of Na<sup>+</sup> ions are the HC surface, defect sites, and edges of graphite-like domains or heteroatoms, whereas in the plateau region, intercalation into the graphitic layers takes place.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0092" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0092_R_d154663148e13263" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 92 - ACS Nano">92</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0116" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0116_R_d154663148e13263" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 116 - Nano Lett.">116</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The third model can be designated as the adsorption-filling process. Within this model, Na<sup>+</sup> ions are adsorbed to the surface/defects/edges/heteroatoms in the sloping region, and Na atoms fill the closed pores in the plateau region.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e13271" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0153" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0153_R_d154663148e13271" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 153 - Adv. Energy Mater.">153</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The last and fourth model can be described as a three-stage process. In this model, the galvanostatic curve is divided into three reaction regions. In the sloping region, Na<sup>+</sup> ions are adsorbed to the surface/defects/edges/heteroatoms; in the plateau region, Na<sup>+</sup> ions intercalate into the graphitic layers; and at the end of the plateau close to the cut-off voltage, Na atoms fill the closed pores.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13281" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Most of the literature agrees with the model by Stevens and Dahn dedicated to alkali metals.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0020" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0020_R_d154663148e13289" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 20 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">20</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0023" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0023_R_d154663148e13289" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 23 - Carbon">23</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0284" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0284_R_d154663148e13289" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 284 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">284</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The model was mainly based on in situ XRD, small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS), and wide-angle X-ray scattering (WAXS) data. Stevens and Dahn proposed a model consisting of a two-stage Na<sup>+</sup> ion insertion mechanism (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0030">30a,b</a>) as part of a broader structural model known as the “house of cards” or “falling cards” model. Stevens and Dahn distinguished two regions on the electrochemical potential curve, namely, the sloping region at potentials higher than 0.1 V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup> and the plateau region at potentials lower than 0.1 V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>. According to the model, the sodium ions are inserted between nearly parallel layers of carbon in the sloping region, followed by pore filling in the plateau potential region.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0284" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0284_R_d154663148e13307" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 284 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">284</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> From a structural point of view, Stevens and Dahn described the HCs as a combination of pseudo-graphitic sp<sup>2</sup> hybridized nanodomains (2 to 3 graphene layers according to the “house of cards” model,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0284" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0284_R_d154663148e13315" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 284 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">284</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> up to 5 layers according to other literature<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0046" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0046_R_d154663148e13320" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 46 - Adv. Energy Mater.">46</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0202" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0202_R_d154663148e13320" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 202 - Chem. Eng. J.">202</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) and sp<sup>3</sup> hybridized amorphous regions (vacancies, Stone–Wales defects).</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0030"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/9bc7c26b-7471-4ae2-9aaa-6c4d0ff0970e/aenm202303833-fig-0030-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/9bc7c26b-7471-4ae2-9aaa-6c4d0ff0970e/aenm202303833-fig-0030-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/79bc55a7-c08f-4741-9bb3-852f192bc0b8/aenm202303833-fig-0030-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/9bc7c26b-7471-4ae2-9aaa-6c4d0ff0970e/aenm202303833-fig-0030-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 30<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0030&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Representative sketch of the falling card model. Reproduced by permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0284" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0284_R_d154663148e13346" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 284 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">284</a></span>]. Copyright 2000, IOP Publishing Ltd, b) galvanostatic curve representing falling card model. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13349" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></span>], Copyright 2015 American Chemical Society. c) ex situ XRD for hard carbon electrodes at different potentials and d) ex situ SAXS for hard carbon electrodes at different potentials. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0285" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0285_R_d154663148e13352" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 285 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">285</a></span>]. Copyright 2011, John Wiley &amp; Sons and e) operando <sup>23</sup>Na solid-state NMR. Reprinted under the terms of CC BY 3.0 DEED license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0286" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0286_R_d154663148e13357" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 286 - Chem. Commun.">286</a></span>], Copyright 2016, The Authors, Published by Royal Society of Chemistry.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>The intercalation-filling model was further supported by Komaba et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0285" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0285_R_d154663148e13364" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 285 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">285</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> using ex situ XRD (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0030">30c</a>) to observe that the (002) reflection peak shifts to a lower angle when the HC is sodiated up to 0.1 V. They discussed that the interlayer distance increases during the sodiation process, which proves that the insertion of the charge carriers inside the graphitic domains occurs in the sloping region. Furthermore, ex situ SAXS (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0030">30d</a>) was used on a sodiated sample below 0.2 V. SAXS revealed a decrease in scattering intensity at ≈0.03 to 0.07 Å<sup>−1</sup> originating from the HC nanopores. This decrease is attributed to the Na<sup>+</sup> ions inserted into the nanovoids within the lower potential range.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0284" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0284_R_d154663148e13380" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 284 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">284</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0285" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0285_R_d154663148e13380" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 285 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">285</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Additionally, it was assumed that sodium storage at a low potential (5 mV), close to the metal deposition, would result in sodium clustering with the metallic character of the Na<sup>+</sup> ions. This metallic pooling was proven by Stratford et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0286" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0286_R_d154663148e13387" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 286 - Chem. Commun.">286</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> using operando <sup>23</sup>Na solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (ssNMR). Based on operando <sup>23</sup>Na ssNMR, they proposed a two-stage mechanism (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0030">30e</a>). The sloping region, where ionic Na<sup>+</sup> ions are formed, consists of charge localization near defects. They claim that the defects are responsible for larger interplanar distances, and therefore, insertion may commence in this sloping region, which is associated with charge localization. This was further supported by pair distribution function (PDF) data, which indicates that turbostratically disordered graphene-like fragments affect the interlayer arrangements. At low potentials, where a plateau is present due to intercalation and Na pooling, they observed a quasi-metallic nature of Na ions or atoms as clusters with domains of coherence lengths superior to 10 Å (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0030">30e</a>). Surprisingly, using the same technique for ex situ measurements with electron paramagnetic resonance, the quasi-metallic sodium environment was not detected in closed nanopores at the end of discharge (0 V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>). They proposed that this discrepancy between operando and ex situ NMR results could arise due to the extreme reactivity of sodiated HC.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0287" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0287_R_d154663148e13408" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 287 - J. Power Sources">287</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Morita et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0288" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0288_R_d154663148e13413" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 288 - Carbon">288</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> disproved this hypothesis by showing that extracted sodiated electrodes show reversible desodiation when mounted in a fresh cell. Another possible explanation for this disparity could be that the near-metallic state of sodium in the micropores is in the metastable phase. Operando ssNMR is sensitive toward metastable states occurring during cycling, which would not otherwise be detected by ex situ experiments since the Na metal could have disappeared before the HC electrode was collected for characterization.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0289" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0289_R_d154663148e13418" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 289 - J. Am. Chem. Soc.">289</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Complementary works using <sup>23</sup>Na NMR technique to understand the Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage are nicely gathered in the review of Gotoh.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0290" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0290_R_d154663148e13428" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 290 - Batteries Supercaps">290</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>These findings and contradictions make the plateau region difficult to ascribe to a process with full certainty, and more models have been suggested.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0020" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0020_R_d154663148e13435" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 20 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">20</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13435" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e13435" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0092" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0092_R_d154663148e13435" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 92 - ACS Nano">92</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0153" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0153_R_d154663148e13435" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 153 - Adv. Energy Mater.">153</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0278" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0278_R_d154663148e13435" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 278 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">278</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0291" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0291_R_d154663148e13435" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 291 - Nano Lett.">291</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0292" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0292_R_d154663148e13435" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 292 - ACS Energy Lett.">292</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The “falling cards” model based on the intercalation–adsorption model did not take into account the presence of defects, heteroatoms, and/or functional groups at the edges of graphite-like domains, as storage sites for sodium at high voltages. These defects vary from surface dangling bonds at the edge of the turbostratic nanodomains (TNDs) to monovacancies, divacancies, Stone–Wales defects, and curvatures in graphene sheets with the presence of sp<sup>3</sup>-linking carbons that connect the randomly oriented nanodomains.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13442" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The apparent contradiction between several reports proposing that Na<sup>+</sup> ion pore filling occurs first and then a pooling mechanism against adsorption followed by interlayer intercalation indicates that both mechanisms of intercalation and pore filling could occur simultaneously at the plateau region.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0293" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0293_R_d154663148e13450" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 293 - Adv. Energy Mater.">293</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>To fill the missing gaps in the “falling cards” model, a three-stage model was proposed (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0031">31</a>). It consists of defect adsorption of Na<sup>+</sup> ions in the sloping region, whereas the plateau region is characterized by Na<sup>+</sup> ion intercalation into the graphitic layers, followed by pore filling in the nanopores at lower voltage ranges prior to sodium plating. This model was suggested by Bommier et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13466" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> when a sucrose source was pyrolyzed at different temperatures. They suggested that the sloping capacity increases due to the higher defect concentration expressed by the integrated <i>I</i><sub>D</sub>/<i>I</i><sub>G</sub> ratio when a linear relationship was reported between the sloping of the capacity and the concentration of the defects (see Figure <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0026">26d</a>). The high sloping capacity was attributed to the HC that contains the highest defect concentration. Other supplementary techniques were used to investigate the sodiation mechanism, namely, the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) and ex situ XRD measurements. The former was used to prove that the storage mechanism changes in the lower voltage range before reaching the cut-off potential. Meanwhile, the latter was used to investigate the change in the graphitic layer stacking during the sodiation/desodiation process. From the GITT data, it was reported that the diffusion associated with the sloping potentials is much faster than in the plateau region, which confirms that the initial sodiation happens on readily accessible sites of amorphous carbon edges. When further sodiation takes place at lower voltages, the Na<sup>+</sup> ions will diffuse inside the graphitic layers. This step is considered energetically demanding since Na<sup>+</sup> ions have to overcome the repulsive charge gradient from the previously bound Na<sup>+</sup> ions to the TND edges, to finally intercalate between the graphitic sheets. Therefore, adsorption on the defect sites occurs at higher potential values prior to intercalation. Based on the same aforementioned techniques, the sodiation mechanism was extensively investigated for the plateau region. They deduced that the steep drop in the diffusivity, as well as the reversible expansion and contraction of the d-spacing for a voltage window from 0.2 to 0.01 V vs. Na/Na<sup>+</sup>, are indicators of the intercalation process. The observed GITT measurements from 0.05 V to the cut-off voltage suggested that the sodiation of the charge carriers at the plateau region could not be attributed to the sole intercalation process between the graphitic sheets. The measurements show that the diffusivity values increase, described as a U-turn-like reversal shape, below 0.05 V instead of being continuously low upon sodiation. This was explained by the fact that the binding energy at the nanodomain edges becomes weaker in the low potential range. Due to the higher kinetics, the pore-filling mechanism is more favored compared to intercalation.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0031"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/aa2fdeeb-8129-47a7-9213-b84071126b5f/aenm202303833-fig-0031-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/aa2fdeeb-8129-47a7-9213-b84071126b5f/aenm202303833-fig-0031-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/677ad22e-2deb-4bb0-8600-77e20678cde7/aenm202303833-fig-0031-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/aa2fdeeb-8129-47a7-9213-b84071126b5f/aenm202303833-fig-0031-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 31<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0031&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Ex situ XRD patterns for different sodiation and desodiation conditions, b) d-spacing plots, c) galvanostatic curve for the three-stage process. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13509" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></span>], Copyright 2015, American Chemical Society, d–g) schematic illustration of the improved three-stage process, a so-called microstructure-dependent mechanism (“adsorption – intercalation/filling” hybrid mechanism). Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0293" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0293_R_d154663148e13512" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 293 - Adv. Energy Mater.">293</a></span>], Copyright 2022, John Wiley &amp; Sons.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>This hypothesis was further corroborated using the ex situ XRD technique (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0031">31a,b</a>), which does not show any expansion/contraction of the two adjacent graphene layers close to the cut-off potential. Therefore, the last storing mechanism is attributed to the pore-filling process that occurs at a very low potential (Figure <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0031">31c</a>), close to the metal plating, which takes place at –0.02 V vs. Na/Na<sup>+ 43</sup>.</p>
            
            <p>More recently, based on new findings<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0293" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0293_R_d154663148e13531" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 293 - Adv. Energy Mater.">293</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> an improved three-stage process, the so-called microstructure-dependent mechanism (“adsorption-intercalation/filling” hybrid mechanism), was proposed (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0031">31d–g</a>). It was suggested that interlayer intercalation and closed pore filling concurrently contributed to the plateau region of the HC. Cao et&nbsp;al. concluded that if HC has abundant pseudo-graphitic nanodomains, intercalation is the main driving force in the plateau, and pore filling occurs at the end of discharge (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0031">31e</a>). On the other hand, if the HC is rich in micropores, the plateau capacity is due to micropore filling and few-layer intercalation (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0031">31g</a>).</p>
            
            <p>An alternative multistage storage mechanism concept was recently suggested based on in situ Raman scattering, density functional theory (DFT), and band structure calculations.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0292" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0292_R_d154663148e13548" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 292 - ACS Energy Lett.">292</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> According to the research group,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0292" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0292_R_d154663148e13553" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 292 - ACS Energy Lett.">292</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> sodium insertion into HC occurs in four different stages (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0032">32</a>). First, adsorption on defects and reactive surface sites takes place at the very beginning of sodiation. Second, the intercalation takes place initially at defect sites between the layers, followed by the filling of the remaining layers up to a maximum amount of NaC<sub>24</sub> in terms of stoichiometry, which theoretically results in 93 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> of gravimetric capacity at the sloping region. Finally, in the plateau region, Na<sup>+</sup> ion pooling into nanopores takes place. The authors<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0292" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0292_R_d154663148e13570" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 292 - ACS Energy Lett.">292</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> suggested that defects are essential to initiate sodium insertion and that the obtained capacity in the sloping region depends on the defect concentration with a maximum amount of NaC<sub>24</sub>. Additionally, excessive defect concentration has a detrimental effect because the activation barriers for sodium diffusion increase close to the defect sites. They speculated that this could be one of the reasons for the irreversible capacity of trapping the adsorbed sodium. Finally, it is suggested that the plateau capacity depends on the nanopores, therefore, optimization of the HC pore structure and volume could result in an increase in capacity.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0032"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/0dd75c84-f876-4392-b875-7961f60f9a03/aenm202303833-fig-0032-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/0dd75c84-f876-4392-b875-7961f60f9a03/aenm202303833-fig-0032-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/a167efca-b4bd-433b-be9d-eeecf75d5006/aenm202303833-fig-0032-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/0dd75c84-f876-4392-b875-7961f60f9a03/aenm202303833-fig-0032-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 32<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0032&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic representation of the multistage storage mechanism concept: adsorption on surface sites (black), filling of defects in graphitic layers (orange), filling of the layers (red), and adsorption on nanopores (light blue). Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0292" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0292_R_d154663148e13597" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 292 - ACS Energy Lett.">292</a></span>], Copyright 2018, American Chemical Society.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>This type of model was also reported by Titirici et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0274" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0274_R_d154663148e13604" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 274 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">274</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> when HC structures were synthesized using hydrothermal treatment of glucose with citric acid as a catalyst and further carbonized at different temperatures ranging from 1000 to 1900 °C. In this study, the electrode volume expansion during cycling was investigated using in situ electrochemical dilatometry (ECD) as a novel technique to investigate sodium ion storage. They found that the volume expansion of the electrode is more significant in the sloping region compared to the plateau. Based on this result, the authors hypothesized that in the sloping region, adsorption of Na<sup>+</sup> ions on the disordered graphene layers occurs. Consequently, Na<sup>+</sup> ion adsorption leads to material expansion. Following adsorption, intercalation into graphene layers with suitable spacing takes place, forming a low-voltage plateau. Finally, in the plateau region, Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage dominates over pore filling.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0274" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0274_R_d154663148e13616" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 274 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">274</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> More recently, it has been shown by in operando SAXS measurements that closed pore filling and intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> occur simultaneously in the plateau region.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0283" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0283_R_d154663148e13623" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 283 - Adv. Mater.">283</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Apparently, not all pores are filled, suggesting that plateau capacities can still be improved.</p>
            
            <p>A detailed understanding of the mechanism processes (<b>Table</b> <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0005">5</a>) as well as establishing a potential dependence of these processes upon sodiation is crucial for the development of advanced and high-performance HC anodes. However, it appears that during studies of the Na storage mechanism, discrepancies arise due to the large variety of HCs and the different processing parameters used. Even with the same characterization techniques, contradictory results are obtained: Zhang and Bommier both performed in situ XRD measurements and obtained different results. Zhang produced carbon nanofibers derived from a PAN precursor and did not observe any shifts in the position of the (002) peak.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0075" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0075_R_d154663148e13636" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 75 - Adv. Energy Mater.">75</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Meanwhile, Bommier produced sucrose-based HCs and observed notable shifts in the position of the (002) peak.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13641" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Therefore, a consensus on one absolute Na storage mechanism in HCs appears hardly achievable. Instead, research should focus on generalizing the Na storage mechanism based on the various microstructures that can be obtained by the pyrolysis process. Below is a descriptive table (Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0005">5</a>) overviewing the aforementioned references that used different techniques to decipher and shape the Na<sup>+</sup> ion storage models.</p>
            
            <div class="article-table-content" id="aenm202303833-tbl-0005">
               
               
               
               
               <header class="article-table-caption"><span class="table-caption__label">Table  5.
                    </span>Different storage mechanisms reported by several studies.</header>
