                           <td rowspan="2" class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">
                              <p>Three stages</p>
                              <p>Process</p></td>
                           
                           <td class="left-aligned">Sloping: adsorption onto defect sites</td>
                           
                           <td rowspan="2" class="left-aligned">Raman spectroscopy,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13820" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0293" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0293_R_d154663148e13820" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 293 - Adv. Energy Mater.">293</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Neutron PDF,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13825" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> GITT,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13830" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0293" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0293_R_d154663148e13830" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 293 - Adv. Energy Mater.">293</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> ex situ XRD half-cell testing,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0043" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0043_R_d154663148e13836" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 43 - Nano Lett.">43</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> operando SAXS<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0283" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0283_R_d154663148e13841" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 283 - Adv. Mater.">283</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="left-aligned">Plateau: intercalation, followed by pore filling</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td rowspan="2" class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">
                              <p>Multi stages</p>
                              <p>Process</p></td>
                           
                           <td class="left-aligned">Sloping adsorption on defect sites. Insertion between the layers followed by filling up of the layers</td>
                           
                           <td rowspan="2" class="left-aligned">in situ Raman scattering,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0292" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0292_R_d154663148e13866" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 292 - ACS Energy Lett.">292</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> DFT band structure calculations,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0292" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0292_R_d154663148e13871" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 292 - ACS Energy Lett.">292</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> in situ ECD<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0274" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0274_R_d154663148e13876" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 274 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">274</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="left-aligned">Plateau adsorption on pore walls, followed by metal pooling</td>
                           </tr>
                        </tbody>
                     </table>
               </div>
               
               
               <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
            </div>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0200">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0200-title">5.2 Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI)</h3>
            
            <p>While the determination of the Na storage mechanism is of paramount importance, an in-depth understanding of another process is indispensable in the formulation of HCs. This process is the decomposition of the electrolyte at the carbon surface, resulting in the formation of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI). It is one of the most important parameters concerning anodic materials in general, as it determines the amount of active material consumed in the initial sodiation step and tailors/determines the subsequent stable cycling.</p>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element">The concept of SEI formation was first proposed by Peled in 1979.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0294" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0294_R_d154663148e13903" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 294 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">294</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> He proposed that a passivation layer is formed on the surface of the alkali/alkaline metal, composed of insoluble products, because of side reactions upon contact of the metal with the electrolyte solution. According to Peled, the SEI possesses the properties of a solid electrolyte, acting simultaneously as an ionic conductor and an electronic insulator, hence the name “solid-electrolyte” interphase. Even at that time, nearly 50 years ago, Peled stated that a proper anodic SEI is the key to the operation of nonaqueous batteries, which remains true even today.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0294" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0294_R_d154663148e13908" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 294 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">294</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Research on SEI formation in Li-ion batteries has received enormous attention. Meanwhile, research on SEI formation in Na-ion batteries started&nbsp;at the beginning of the previous decade, concurrent with intensive research on HCs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0295" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0295_R_d154663148e13913" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 295 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">295</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> As in the case of other cell components, especially cathode materials, one would expect that the chemistry of SEI formation is analogous for both systems. However, the phenomenon of SEI formation is very distinctive from one system to another due to the different physical and chemical properties of Li<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> ions, including the ionic radius, solvent energy, and redox potential.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0296" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0296_R_d154663148e13923" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 296 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">296</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In general, an ideal SEI must satisfy several demands such as:<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0297" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0297_R_d154663148e13929" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 297 - ACS Energy Lett.">297</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>
               
               <ol start="1" class="">
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>Acting as an electronically insulating material to prevent continuous electrolyte decomposition;</p>
                     </li>
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>Good ionic conductivity to facilitate the transport of Na<sup>+</sup>;</p>
                     </li>
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>Allow desolvation of Na<sup>+</sup>;</p>
                     </li>
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>Being insoluble in the cell operation environment prevents continuous degradation.</p>
                     </li>
                  </ol>
            </div>
            
            <p>The process of SEI formation can be divided into four parts, <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0033">33</a>. Initially, solvated Na<sup>+</sup> transport from the bulk electrolyte to the outer surface of the electrode. Thereafter, the Na<sup>+</sup> ions desolvate and migrate to the surface of the electrode. In the next step, a portion of Na<sup>+</sup> is consumed to form the SEI layer through an irreversible reaction. Finally, the remaining ions are able to pass through the formed layer and insert into the host electrode.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0298" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0298_R_d154663148e13973" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 298 - Adv. Mater.">298</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0033"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/21851582-6035-4521-8ffd-58745d94a06f/aenm202303833-fig-0033-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/21851582-6035-4521-8ffd-58745d94a06f/aenm202303833-fig-0033-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/4af6f074-b88c-4782-b4b2-f75d55a552a7/aenm202303833-fig-0033-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/21851582-6035-4521-8ffd-58745d94a06f/aenm202303833-fig-0033-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 33<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0033&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Transfer of Na<sup>+</sup> from the bulk electrolyte through the SEI layer to the host electrode. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0298" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0298_R_d154663148e13998" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 298 - Adv. Mater.">298</a></span>]. Copyright 2017, John Wiley and Sons.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Several authors performed XPS analysis of cycled HC electrodes and concluded that the SEI is composed of a mixture of inorganic (NaF, NaCl, Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3,</sub> and Na<sub>2</sub>O) and organic (alkali carbonates, carboxylates, carbonyls, ethers, and epoxides) compounds.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0127" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0127_R_d154663148e14011" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 127 - ChemElectroChem">127</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0285" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0285_R_d154663148e14011" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 285 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">285</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0299" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0299_R_d154663148e14011" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 299 - ChemElectroChem">299</a>-<a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0303" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0303_R_d154663148e14011" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 303 - Chem. Mater.">303</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Some authors have also reported the formation of sodium ethylene dicarbonate (NEDC) as the main decomposition product of carbonate-based solvents.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0301" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0301_R_d154663148e14017" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 301 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">301</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0302" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0302_R_d154663148e14017" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 302 - J. Electroanal. Chem.">302</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> However, the SEI composition is closely connected to the choice of electrolyte. The majority of electrolytes used in SIBs are based on sodium salts, such as NaClO<sub>4</sub>, NaPF<sub>6</sub>, and NaTFSI, dissolved in carbonate-based organic solvents, such as ethylene carbonate (EC), propylene carbonate (PC), dimethyl carbonate (DMC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0127" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0127_R_d154663148e14026" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 127 - ChemElectroChem">127</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0301" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0301_R_d154663148e14026" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 301 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">301</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0304" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0304_R_d154663148e14026" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 304 - Energy Environ. Sci.">304</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Furthermore, additives, such as fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) and vinyl carbonate (VC), have been added to improve the SEI stability.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0301" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0301_R_d154663148e14032" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 301 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">301</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0305" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0305_R_d154663148e14032" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 305 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">305</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Eshetu et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0300" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0300_R_d154663148e14037" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 300 - Nano Energy">300</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> studied the influence of different salt anions on SEI formation. They found that the degradation of electrolyte salt dictates the composition of the inorganic species in the SEI. Additionally, they showed that the thickness of the SEI is dependent on the salt anion. In this regard, NaClO<sub>4</sub>-based electrolytes form thicker SEIs and NaPF<sub>6</sub>- and NaTFSI-based electrolytes form thinner SEI layers. On the other hand, in another work, Eshetu et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0017" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0017_R_d154663148e14047" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 17 - ChemSusChem">17</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> showed that the composition of organic species is highly dependent on the reduction of linear carbonates, particularly DEC and DMC.</p>
            
            <p>Reports suggest that the solubility of the SEI in Na-ion batteries is more severe because the SEI components are mainly unstable organometallic compounds that are highly soluble in organic electrolytes. The continuous dissolution of the SEI leads to increased self-discharge of the cell. Moreover, the dissolution of the SEI exposes the carbon surface to the electrolyte, leading to further electrolyte degradation. The ensuing growth of the SEI additionally consumes the active material, leading to low Coulombic efficiencies in the subsequent cycles. Therefore, the solubility, morphology, structure, and composition of the SEI layer were studied by several techniques, as seen in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0034">34</a>.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0034"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/e249db4b-fe82-48ee-bfb8-5734110fd02a/aenm202303833-fig-0034-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/e249db4b-fe82-48ee-bfb8-5734110fd02a/aenm202303833-fig-0034-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/87149bee-e89c-4de6-842a-20c87743c677/aenm202303833-fig-0034-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/e249db4b-fe82-48ee-bfb8-5734110fd02a/aenm202303833-fig-0034-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 34<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0034&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Representation of SEI layer at the surface of HC and the main techniques used to determine its properties, as proposed by the authors of this work.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Mogensen et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0297" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0297_R_d154663148e14083" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 297 - ACS Energy Lett.">297</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> studied SEI dissolution on high-surface-area SuperP anodes via galvanostatic cycling combined with prolonged pause periods (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0035">35a</a>). They compared the charge capacities of the last cycle before the pause period and the second cycle following the pause period. In this way, they were able to monitor the static stability of the SEI without influences from volume expansion and polarization. From the rate of self-discharge, they were able to calculate the amount of capacity lost due to SEI dissolution. They concluded that in cells with Na-metal electrodes, the capacity loss amounted to ≈80% of the overall cell capacity compared to only 20% capacity loss for cells with Li-metal electrodes (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0035">35a</a>).</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0035"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/42c71779-5cb2-454d-91e6-1361225ad894/aenm202303833-fig-0035-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/42c71779-5cb2-454d-91e6-1361225ad894/aenm202303833-fig-0035-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/0b7095c4-ec5b-4aa8-b04c-b97962553e77/aenm202303833-fig-0035-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/42c71779-5cb2-454d-91e6-1361225ad894/aenm202303833-fig-0035-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 35<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0035&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Comparison of SEI dissolution in Na- and Li-based cells. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0297" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0297_R_d154663148e14116" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 297 - ACS Energy Lett.">297</a></span>], Copyright 2016, American Chemical Society. b) Effect of different solvents on the consumed capacity for SEI formation and c) effect of different solvents on the SEI dissolution rate. Reprinted under the terms of CC BY 4.0 DEED license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0306" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0306_R_d154663148e14119" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 306 - Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.">306</a></span>].Copyright 2020, The Authors, Published by Wiley-VCH GmbH.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Additionally, synchrotron-based hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (HAXPES) was performed on the SuperP electrode cycled in a Na-half cell after a prolonged period of pause (72 h or 168 h). From the obtained data, they observed a decrease in SEI thickness, indicating the dissolution of the SEI when in contact with the electrolyte. Ma et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0306" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0306_R_d154663148e14126" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 306 - Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.">306</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> adopted a similar protocol to study the SEI solubility in different solvents; 1M NaPF<sub>6</sub> was employed as the electrolyte salt in different solvents, namely, PC, EC:PC, and EC:DEC, and they concluded that EC:PC consumed the least capacity for SEI formation, while PC consumed the most (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0035">35b</a>). However, EC:DEC exhibited the lowest SEI dissolution rate, while PC again exhibited the worst performance (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0035">35c</a>). Finally, the solubilities of Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and NaF and their lithium analogs in PC and EC:DEC were studied by ICP‒OES. The solubilities of sodium inorganic compounds are an order of magnitude higher than those of their lithium analogs.</p>
            
            <p>Solutions to mitigate continuous SEI growth ranging from adapted cycling protocols, rational electrode design, and electrolyte additives, have already been explored.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0307" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0307_R_d154663148e14147" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 307 - Small">307</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Among them, the addition of sacrificial compounds to the electrolyte is the most attractive option, and understanding the effect of electrolyte additives on the formation of the SEI is crucial in the quest to mitigate its continuous growth. The most well-known and studied electrolyte additive is fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC). Komaba et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0295" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0295_R_d154663148e14152" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 295 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">295</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> were the first to report the benefits of FEC addition in Na-ion batteries. They showed that the addition of 2 wt% FEC to a solution of 1M NaClO<sub>4</sub> in PC results in more stable long-term cycling (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0036">36a</a>, curve b in inset). However, when increasing the amount of FEC to 10 wt%, a detrimental effect was observed as the electrochemical performance decreased. Finally, they concluded that other additives, such as difluoroethylene carbonate (DFEC) and vinylene carbonate (VC), do not improve cycling stability. Rather, a decrease in the reversible capacity of HC electrodes was observed. Since then, several research groups have followed this example and studied the effect of FEC in Na-ion batteries. However, contradictory reports have arisen on its effect on the performance of HCs. Dahbi et&nbsp;al. showed that the addition of 0.5 wt% FEC to a solution of 1M NaPF<sub>6</sub> in PC and PC:EC increases the iCE and improves the long-term cycling stability (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0036">36b</a>, curves a and b). Using HAXPES, they concluded that similar chemical species are formed at the HC surface independent of the FEC addition. However, they claimed that with the addition of FEC, a more desirable passivation layer formed, simultaneously suppressing the accumulation of decomposition products of PC and NaPF<sub>6</sub> at the HC surface.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0299" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0299_R_d154663148e14174" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 299 - ChemElectroChem">299</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The same observations were corroborated by Fondard et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0301" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0301_R_d154663148e14179" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 301 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">301</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> They studied the effect of the addition of small amounts of FEC and DMCF on the cycle life and SEI composition. Improved cycle life was observed with the addition of FEC, while the DMCF addition did not provide any improvements (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0036">36c</a>). The electrolyte with FEC formed an SEI with increased amounts of sodium ethylene dicarbonate (NEDC) and NaF. They postulated that NEDC is the principal Na<sup>+</sup> conducting species. Meanwhile, the increased amount of NaF leads to better cycling stability, yet its exact role is still unclear. They hypothesized that an increased amount of insoluble species, such as NaF, stabilizes the SEI and limits the solubility of other compounds. On the other hand, Ponrouch et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0308" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0308_R_d154663148e14190" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 308 - Electrochem. Commun.">308</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> observed increased polarization and lower iCE when 2 wt% FEC was added to a mixture of 1M NaClO<sub>4</sub> in PC:EC (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0036">36d</a>). Dugas et&nbsp;al.,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0305" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0305_R_d154663148e14200" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 305 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">305</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> however, postulated that the detrimental effects of FEC arise from the kinetic limitations of the Na metal electrode rather than the HC. With the addition of 3 wt% FEC to the mixture of 1M NaPF<sub>6</sub> in EC:DMC, increased impedance was observed in Na symmetrical cells, leading to larger overpotentials and less stable stripping/deposition processes (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0036">36e</a>). When performing electrochemical measurements with HC electrodes, a slight increase in irreversible capacity was observed with the FEC electrolyte. Nevertheless, they claimed that overall, the addition of FEC is beneficial because it limits Na reactivity toward the electrolyte via the growth of a passivation layer. This was further confirmed by gas chromatography‒mass spectrometry (GC‒MS) and gas evolution experiments, where it was shown that FEC decomposed prior to other solvents, and no EC and DMC decomposition products were detected.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0036"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/360fc793-8441-456b-b98e-583368971424/aenm202303833-fig-0036-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/360fc793-8441-456b-b98e-583368971424/aenm202303833-fig-0036-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/292c9ba2-7908-42b4-9ac5-aca2c5d6192e/aenm202303833-fig-0036-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/360fc793-8441-456b-b98e-583368971424/aenm202303833-fig-0036-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 36<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0036&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Improved cycle life and stability with FEC addition: a) reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0295" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0295_R_d154663148e14230" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 295 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">295</a></span>] Copyright 2011, American Chemical Society. b) reprinted with permission form Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0299" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0299_R_d154663148e14233" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 299 - ChemElectroChem">299</a></span>]. Copyright 2016, John Wiley and Sons, c) reprinted under the terms of CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 DEED license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0301" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0301_R_d154663148e14236" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 301 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">301</a></span>], Copyright 2020, The Authors, Published by IOPscience. d) lower iCE and increased polarization in FEC electrolyte. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0308" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0308_R_d154663148e14239" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 308 - Electrochem. Commun.">308</a></span>] Copyright 2013, Elsevier and e) increased polarization in FEC electrolyte during stripping/deposition of Na symmetrical cells. Reprinted under the terms of CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 DEED license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0305" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0305_R_d154663148e14242" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 305 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">305</a></span>], Copyright 2016, The Authors, Published by IOPscience.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Other reports also suggest that the main reason for capacity fading in Na-ion batteries is not the degradation of HC electrodes but rather the reactivity of the Na metal electrode toward the electrolyte. Indeed, the work performed by Iermakova et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0309" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0309_R_d154663148e14250" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 309 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">309</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> showed that cycling of Na symmetrical cells presents large overpotentials, resembling the behavior of diffusion-limited processes (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0037">37a</a>). Meanwhile, stripping/deposition measurements of Li symmetrical cells exhibit low polarization and smooth curves. Moreover, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of Na electrodes were taken upon immersion for 24 h and after CV measurements. Rough surfaces were observed, and large particles detaching from the substrate were observed after CV measurements.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0037"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/538658e0-15d0-4632-b2da-37bc66b8bcbb/aenm202303833-fig-0037-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/538658e0-15d0-4632-b2da-37bc66b8bcbb/aenm202303833-fig-0037-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/09734ea6-0389-4fcf-b404-f1541c445f8b/aenm202303833-fig-0037-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/538658e0-15d0-4632-b2da-37bc66b8bcbb/aenm202303833-fig-0037-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 37<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0037&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Large overpotentials of Na–Na symmetrical cells in carbonate-based electrolyte. Reprinted under the terms of CC BY-NC-ND 4.0 DEED license Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0309" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0309_R_d154663148e14280" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 309 - J. Electrochem. Soc.">309</a></span>], Copyright 2015, The authors, Published by IOPscience, b) diffusivity values with the fresh Na metal electrode. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0310" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0310_R_d154663148e14283" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 310 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">310</a></span>]. Copyright 2016, John Wiley and Sons, c) surface of the Na metal electrode after the 1st cycle and d) surface of the Na metal electrode after the 16th cycle. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0311" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0311_R_d154663148e14286" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 311 - Electrochim. Acta">311</a></span>], Copyright 2020, Elsevier.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Bommier et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0310" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0310_R_d154663148e14293" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 310 - Adv. Mater. Interfaces">310</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> studied the effect of cell component degradation after prolonged cycling. Upon GITT measurements, they observed that the diffusivity values almost completely recovered when a fresh Na counter electrode was introduced (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0037">37b</a>). Moreover, 95% of the starting capacity was also achieved. From this, they concluded that the capacity fading was not due to the HC electrodes. Finally, they soaked the Na metal in a carbonate-based electrolyte for three months and afterward performed Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR). They observed that the SEI formed without electrochemical cycling, showing the instability of Na metal electrodes in conventional carbonate electrolytes.</p>
            
            <p>Mandl et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0311" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0311_R_d154663148e14304" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 311 - Electrochim. Acta">311</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> studied the evolution of the SEI formed on the Na metal surface throughout cycling. They observed the disappearance of different compounds over the first five cycles of ex situ XPS measurements. This was additionally corroborated with SEM imaging, where—spherical particles were observed on the surface after the first cycle (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0037">37c</a>) and were not observed in the subsequent cycles (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0037">37d</a>). The observed changes in morphology and surface chemistry indicate the formation of an unstable SEI.</p>
            
            <p>Computational simulations of SEI formation have also been performed to support the experimental data and better understand its formation mechanism. Takenaka et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0312" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0312_R_d154663148e14318" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 312 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interf.">312</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> used a hybrid Monte Carlo (MC)/molecular dynamic (MC) method or the so-called Red Moon method to simulate SEI formation at a carbon anode in an electrolyte with and without the addition of FEC (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0038">38</a>). They observed that the FEC electrolyte forms a smoother and thinner SEI layer (3.9 nm compared to 5.7 nm without FEC). The SEI layer is also more compact and dense, preventing solvent molecules from reaching the carbon surface and effectively suppressing electrolyte decomposition. They concluded that the effect of FEC can be described by the modification of elementary chemical reaction processes during SEI formation and the suppression of unstable film growth. Continuing the work from Takenaka, Bouibes et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0312" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0312_R_d154663148e14328" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 312 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interf.">312</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> studied the effect of the amount of FEC added to the electrolyte. The red moon method showed increased SEI structural stability when a small amount of FEC was added via the reduction of dissolved reaction products into the bulk electrolyte. By increasing the FEC amount, the film growth became more unstable due to the suppression of organic dimer formation. Yildirim et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0313" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0313_R_d154663148e14334" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 313 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interf.">313</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> performed DFT calculations of the ion diffusion characteristics of LiF and NaF. The calculations showed high diffusion barriers for both compounds, explaining the kinetic limitations affecting the rate performance of batteries. Additionally, the ionic conductivity of NaF is several orders of magnitude lower than that of LiF. Nevertheless, the conductivities of both LiF and NaF are significantly lower than that of Li<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>, highlighting that various SEI components present different conductivities. Ionic conductivity values of Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> could not be obtained from the literature. The high diffusion barriers obtained from DFT calculations of the ion diffusion characteristics of different SEI components were further corroborated by Soto et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0298" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0298_R_d154663148e14348" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 298 - Adv. Mater.">298</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0038"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/68ad2b25-4a12-4a51-800b-44beaa2727b2/aenm202303833-fig-0038-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/68ad2b25-4a12-4a51-800b-44beaa2727b2/aenm202303833-fig-0038-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/b6199aaf-c3f3-4cc4-818d-1019f9e9e3ff/aenm202303833-fig-0038-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/68ad2b25-4a12-4a51-800b-44beaa2727b2/aenm202303833-fig-0038-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 38<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0038&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Computational simulation of SEI film formation on a carbon anode surface in a NaPF<sub>6</sub>-PC electrolyte: a) without FEC and b) with FEC. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0312" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0312_R_d154663148e14373" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 312 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interf.">312</a></span>], Copyright 2018, American Chemical Society.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Enabling swift Na<sup>+</sup> ions transport and ensuring the stability of the electrode/electrolyte interface are key considerations of electrolyte design in SIBs. The formation of a stable SEI relies on the precise compatibility of electrolyte and electrode materials. The choice of solvents, additives, and electrode components plays a pivotal role in determining the phase interface's stability. Components such as solvents, additives, and electrode constituents significantly influence the electrochemical performance of HC, such as iCE, rate performance, cycling stability, and safety. However, conventional electrolytes suffer from drawbacks like high volatility, flammability, a limited electrochemical window, susceptibility to moisture and temperature, and safety concerns. Thus, current battery research emphasizes the identification of optimal electrolyte formulations to mitigate interface reactions and simultaneously enhance cell performance and safety.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0300" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0300_R_d154663148e14382" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 300 - Nano Energy">300</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Optimal electrolyte characteristics in battery systems include i) high ionic conductivity, ii) a wide electrochemical window, and iii) non-reactivity with cell components. The adoption of ethylene carbonate in electrolytes emerges as a favored approach to enhance the overall conductivity of solvent mixtures, resulting in batteries exhibiting enhanced electrochemical performance. A comprehensive review of the literature underscores the prevalence of ethylene carbonate in electrolytes, utilized in binary or ternary mixtures with other solvents.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0314" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0314_R_d154663148e14390" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 314 - Infomat">314</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>The prospect of conducting a meta-analysis, consolidating electrochemical performance data from various papers into a broader study on electrolytes, faces challenges. Parameters such as the specific HC material used, the selection of electrolytes, and variations in electrochemical characterization protocols differ substantially across different research papers, posing significant challenges to achieving a comprehensive analysis.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0307" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0307_R_d154663148e14397" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 307 - Small">307</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>While uncertainties persist regarding the ideal electrolyte characteristics, a handful of studies have attempted to elucidate this area. One noteworthy early exploration into electrolyte selection was conducted by Ponrouch et&nbsp;al. in 2012,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0304" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0304_R_d154663148e14404" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 304 - Energy Environ. Sci.">304</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> encompassing a diverse range of solvents. Through systematic assessments of parameters such as potential windows, thermal stability, and cycling stability, the researchers found that EC:PC emerged as a favorable electrolyte solvent (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0039">39a</a>). Interestingly, the choice of NaClO<sub>4</sub> or NaPF<sub>6</sub> as an electrolyte salt made little difference (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0039">39b</a>). The authors further fine-tuned the choice of an optimal solvent to EC<sub>0.45</sub>:PC<sub>0.45</sub>:DMC<sub>0.1</sub>, complemented by a Na salt (Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0039">39c</a>). According to their findings, this ternary mixture exhibited high ionic conductivity, minimized ion pairing, low viscosity, and most notably, facilitated the formation of a well-suited solid electrolyte interface layer.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0315" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0315_R_d154663148e14433" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 315 - Energy Environ. Sci.">315</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0039"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/af6ee800-6831-48a7-989a-2601acc504e6/aenm202303833-fig-0039-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/af6ee800-6831-48a7-989a-2601acc504e6/aenm202303833-fig-0039-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/a5d5f8ad-ca3d-44a6-bc9d-c678c516058e/aenm202303833-fig-0039-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/af6ee800-6831-48a7-989a-2601acc504e6/aenm202303833-fig-0039-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 39<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0039&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">a) Cycling stability of HC electrodes in 1M NaClO<sub>4</sub> and various solvent mixtures. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0304" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0304_R_d154663148e14458" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 304 - Energy Environ. Sci.">304</a></span>]. Copyright 2012, John Wiley and Sons; b) Rate capability of HC electrodes using different electrolytes. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0315" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0315_R_d154663148e14461" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 315 - Energy Environ. Sci.">315</a></span>] Copyright 2013, John Wiley and Sons; and c) Cycling stability of HC electrodes with 1M NaPF<sub>6</sub> and 1M NaClO<sub>4</sub> in EC: PC-based electrolytes. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0304" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0304_R_d154663148e14469" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 304 - Energy Environ. Sci.">304</a></span>]. Copyright 2012, John Wiley and Sons.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>The abovementioned choice of electrolyte and the subsequent SEI formation strongly influence some key electrochemical properties of HCs such as rate capability, cycling stability, and self-discharge.</p>
            
            <p>In general, HCs do not achieve satisfactory rate capabilities as evident from Figure&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0039">39c</a>. The subpar rate performance (compared to graphite in LIBs) is ascribed to a substantial reduction in plateau capacity under high current densities, where elevated overpotentials compel the batteries to reach the cut-off voltage prematurely before achieving full sodiation. As discussed earlier, the plateau capacity stems from either the intercalation or the pore-filling mechanism, both intricately governed by the diffusion process of Na<sup>+</sup> ions. The larger size of Na<sup>+</sup> ions hinders the kinetic process, leading to slower diffusion, thereby adversely affecting the rate performance of HCs.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0275" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0275_R_d154663148e14485" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 275 - Energy Environ. Sci.">275</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0316" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0316_R_d154663148e14485" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 316 - J. Mater. Chem. A">316</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Additionally, the transport properties of Na<sup>+</sup> ions through the SEI are heavily contingent on the ionic conductivity of the formed SEI. The ionic conductivity is further dependent on the thickness and composition of the SEI, both properties closely linked to the chosen electrolyte.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0317" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0317_R_d154663148e14493" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 317 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">317</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>Concurrently, the cycling stability of HC materials proves to be challenging, particularly for carbons with a high plateau capacity.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0318" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0318_R_d154663148e14501" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 318 - J. Mater. Chem. A">318</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The capacity loss observed in the charge/discharge cycle does not arise from the irreversible destruction of the microstructure, given the tightly cross-linked internal structure of HC. Research by Hu et&nbsp;al.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0067" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0067_R_d154663148e14506" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 67 - Energy Storage Mater.">67</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> demonstrated that the capacity is restored upon the renewal of the electrolytes. Therefore, the cycling stability of HC is predominantly influenced by the stability of the electrolyte/electrode interface, closely tied to the composition of the electrolytes.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0317" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0317_R_d154663148e14511" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 317 - Adv. Funct. Mater.">317</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The instability of the SEI can result in continuous electrolyte decomposition, leading to a pronounced capacity loss during cycling. SEI instability arises from the decomposition of Na salt and solvents at low voltage, generating a highly soluble and unstable organic-rich SEI layer.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0319" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0319_R_d154663148e14517" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 319 - ACS Energy Lett.">319</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Furthermore, high dissolution rates of the SEI contribute to pronounced self-discharge of the cell.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0306" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0306_R_d154663148e14522" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 306 - Angew. Chem. Int. Ed.">306</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0297" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0297_R_d154663148e14522" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 297 - ACS Energy Lett.">297</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The research performed on SEI formation in Na-ion batteries is still scarce compared to Li-ion batteries, limiting our understanding of the interfacial processes taking place during cell operation. An in-depth understanding of the effect of individual SEI components is crucial for designing novel electrolytes to prevent dissolution and cracking of the SEI layer and improve rate performance and cycling stability.</p>
            </section>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0210">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202303833-sec-0210-title">6 HC Full Cell Test Performance</h2>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0220">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0220-title">6.1 HC Full Cell Test Performance</h3>
            
            <p>The electrochemical characterization of HC is first carried out in a half cell (versus Na metal) at low current rates permitting full sodiation/desodiation. Identifying the HC's first sodiation capacity and the reversible capacity provides preliminary insights to establish an adequately balanced full cell.</p>
            
            <p>After mounting the full cell, which comprises a cathode as the working electrode and HC as the counter electrode, electrode–electrolyte interphases are formed (<b>Figure</b>&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0040">40</a>). The solid electrolyte interface (SEI) forms at the anode of Na-ion batteries, and the cathode–electrolyte interface (CEI) forms at the cathode of Na-ion batteries (formation cycles) and is critical in maintaining the long-term cycling/lifetime of the full cell. The HC performance is crucial since the applied current during formation can vary from that used during capacity characterization. This means that the HC kinetics and rate capability are detrimental to this step.</p>
            
            <p>Several HCs can perform well in half cells vs. Na-metal (as in specific capacity and irreversible capacity loss). However, they can fail to provide proper electrochemical performance in full-cell configurations. The latter can be due to the poor rate capability performance of the HC, the heat generation as it passes through resistive elements induced by the SEI and the HC itself, the instability of the SEI (leading to its ongoing formation), the poor mechanical adhesion of the electrode (due to the nature of the HC), and finally a poor long-term cyclability due to plating and the degradation of the HC structure.</p>
            
            <p>Engineering HC electrodes as a function of the required application can provide solutions for either high-power density and or high-energy-density. In addition, electrode porosity, calendering, and mechanical adhesion can ensure different application requirements.</p>
            
            <p><b>Table</b> <a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0006">6</a> illustrates the performance of different HCs synthesized from different precursors at a lab-scale or commercial level, with varying cathode technologies available, which are well reported. The reversible capacity of the HC was identified versus Na-metal. However, in a full cell with various cathode active materials, the irreversible capacity differs, and this is mainly attributed to factors, including the nature of the electrolyte and its additives and hence the SEI layer, the rate of formation of the interphases, the temperature of formation, and the balancing of the cell.</p>
            
            <div class="article-table-content" id="aenm202303833-tbl-0006">
               
               
               
               
               <header class="article-table-caption"><span class="table-caption__label">Table  6.
                    </span>Hard carbon anode material testing with varying cathode technologies, electrolytes, and current rates.</header>

                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Kuranode HC</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">330</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Na<sub>2</sub>Fe[Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">169</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">EC<sub>47.5</sub>/DEC<sub>47.5</sub> + 5% FEC + 1M NaClO<sub>4</sub></td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">C/10</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Presodiated HC<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0330" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0330_R_d154663148e15497" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 330 - ACS Appl. Energy Mater.">330</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Swagelok cells</td>
                           </tr>
                        
                        <tr>
                           
                           <td class="right-bordered-cell left-aligned">Shaddock Peels HC</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">280</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Na<sub>2</sub>Fe<sub>4</sub>[Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>3</sub></td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">125</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">EC<sub>45</sub>/DEC<sub>455</sub> + 10% FEC + 1M NaClO<sub>4</sub></td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">2C</td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Presodiated HC<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0331" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0331_R_d154663148e15541" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 331 - ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces">331</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></td>
                           
                           <td class="center-aligned">Coin cells</td>
                           </tr>
                        </tbody>
                     </table>
               </div>
               
               
               
               <div class="article-section__table-footnotes">
                  <ul>
                     <li id="aenm202303833-tbl6-note-0001" class="footNotePopup__item" title="Footnote 1"><span class="number">* </span>Commercial HC used by TIAMAT</li>
                  </ul>
               </div>
               <div class="article-section__table-source"></div>
            </div>
            
            <p>As noticed in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0006">6</a>, the majority of HC characterization was carried out in coin cells (half-cells versus Na-metal) and then balanced with a counter electrode for full cell testing (2 or 3 electrodes). The coin cell testing can be carried out at low current rates or by adding a constant voltage step at low potential (HC plateau) to ensure full sodiation. Due to the coin cell's intrinsic high resistance, high current rates would lead to a high polarization and undervaluation of the HC specific capacity.</p>
            
            <p>The battery format plays a significant role in the overall cell resistance, and moving from coin cells to pouch cells to cylindrical cells and prismatic cells, this overall resistance decreases respectively. The resistance decrease is related to the battery format rather than the active materials used. Hence, the HC-specific capacity can be attained in all battery formats if the right current rate/cycling program is applied.</p>
            
            <p>Finally, the various cathode active materials reported in Table&nbsp;<a class="tableLink scrollableLink" title="Link to table" href="#aenm202303833-tbl-0006">6</a> are divided into three sections: polyanionic cathode materials, layered/transition metal oxide cathode materials, and Prussian blue analogs—this variety of cathode materials have different specific capacities, average voltages, densities, and cycling stabilities. In Section <a class="sectionLink scrollableLink" href="#aenm202303833-sec-0230">6.2</a>, we discuss different company strategies that principally use other cathode materials for diverse applications.</p>
            </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0230">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0230-title">6.2 Applications of SIBs in Real-Life Devices</h3>
            
            <p>Rechargeable batteries are omnipresent since they are the sole wireless energy providers in smartphones, laptops, and other portable electronic devices, along with powering electric and hybrid electric vehicles (electric vehicles and hybrid electric vehicles).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0332" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0332_R_d154663148e15586" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 332 - Energy Storage Mater.">332</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> For SIBs, the abundance of materials is an unequivocal reason why sodium ions are attractive as charge carriers in rechargeable batteries for various applications. Furthermore, the main driver of the sodium-ion market is the increasing demand for clean energy with increasing greenhouse gas emissions worldwide.</p>
            
            <p>The application of SIBs in real-life devices can be divided into two principal axes: stationary energy storage and transport applications. The stationary application's success results from the higher cost assurances provided by SIBs and the operation of the battery at extreme temperatures. The realization of SIBs in stationary energy storage is in response to several intrinsic weaknesses of SIBs when compared to LIBs; Na has three times the atomic weight of Li and has a 300 mV higher redox potential, so the energy density of Na-ion technology is at least 30% lower compared to that of Li-ion technology.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0333" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0333_R_d154663148e15594" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 333 - Joule">333</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <p>The never-ending increase in electricity demand and electrical energy storage (wind and solar photovoltaic power) is likely to drive a large part of the sodium-ion market (the projected stationary storage demand for solar and wind renewable energy by 2030 accounts for 50% of the total electricity generation in several countries).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0334" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0334_R_d154663148e15601" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 334">334</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> Stationary storage includes storage systems in industrial and residential environments and/or telecommunications networks and data center power supplies (backup energy), as shown in <b>Figure</b>&nbsp;<a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0041">41</a>.</p>
            
            <p>The reasonably medium charge rates required for stationary applications (residential, commercial, industrial), principally as emergency power supplies and off-grid power consumption, are governed mainly through high-energy-density cathode materials (layered oxide cathode materials<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0009" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0009_R_d154663148e15614" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 9 - Chem. Rev.">9</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) or long-cycle life and low-cost cathode materials (Prussian Blue (PB)).<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0336" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0336_R_d154663148e15619" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 336 - Nat. Commun.">336</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The sodium-ion prototyping and fabrication of mobile/automotive or stationary energy storage take similar formats to that of lithium-ion batteries (pouch, cylindrical, and prismatic cells), as shown in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0042">42</a>.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0040"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/7b332428-dfef-4723-8b0b-35ac49203784/aenm202303833-fig-0040-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/7b332428-dfef-4723-8b0b-35ac49203784/aenm202303833-fig-0040-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/1717f029-028b-4726-a998-0aedcdedf6f0/aenm202303833-fig-0040-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/7b332428-dfef-4723-8b0b-35ac49203784/aenm202303833-fig-0040-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 40<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0040&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">Schematic representation of a Na-ion battery full cell showing the main components, as proposed by the authors of this work.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Furthermore, SIBs show possible automotive applications and can govern several transport applications. High-power density cathode materials (polyanionic cathode materials<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0315" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0315_R_d154663148e15653" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 315 - Energy Environ. Sci.">315</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup>) and a long cycle life ensure automotive applications. Furthermore, high-power SIBs can be assembled in a 48 V battery pack for mild hybrid vehicle (MHEV) applications or used in nonautomotive applications, such as power tools (cylindrical cells), as illustrated in <b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0043">43</a>.</p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0041"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/312ba6ea-0f5d-4dfc-bc80-72a701256de3/aenm202303833-fig-0041-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/312ba6ea-0f5d-4dfc-bc80-72a701256de3/aenm202303833-fig-0041-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/ff2168f1-b93b-45d3-bff7-32a6488b1780/aenm202303833-fig-0041-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/312ba6ea-0f5d-4dfc-bc80-72a701256de3/aenm202303833-fig-0041-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 41<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0041&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">A 1 MWh SIB-based energy storage system put into operation by HiNa Battery Technology Co., Ltd. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0335" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0335_R_d154663148e15682" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 335">335</a></span>], Copyright HiNa Battery Technology Co., Ltd.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Other solutions can be provided by combining SIBs and LIBs, such as those announced by Contemporary Amperex Technology Co., Ltd. (CATL) (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0044">44</a>). The former is an AB battery pack solution that integrates sodium-ion and lithium-ion cells into one pack. The cathode material used and presented by CATL is a Prussian white cathode material.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0340" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0340_R_d154663148e15694" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 340">340</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0042"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/957375de-9d53-4b2c-86b6-fe862e30e3d8/aenm202303833-fig-0042-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/957375de-9d53-4b2c-86b6-fe862e30e3d8/aenm202303833-fig-0042-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/3b999892-4f62-4282-a3cd-c47d4e7411ff/aenm202303833-fig-0042-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/957375de-9d53-4b2c-86b6-fe862e30e3d8/aenm202303833-fig-0042-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 42<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0042&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>
                     <div class="figure__caption figure__caption-text">High-energy density Na-ion batteries provided by Faradion (pouch, prismatic, and cylindrical formats). Reprinted with permission from Ref. [<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0337" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0337_R_d154663148e15717" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 337">337</a></span>]. Copyright Faradion.</div>
                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <p>Finally, and for the first time, sodium-ion batteries in electric vehicles (Sehol E10X test vehicles) were revealed in China by HiNA Battery Technology Co., Ltd. (February 2022). The test vehicle (<b>Figure</b> <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0045">45</a>) is equipped with a battery pack with a capacity of 25 kWh and an energy density of 120 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>. This model has a range of 252 km and supports fast charging from 3C to 4C. The battery pack uses cells with an energy density of 140 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0341" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0341_R_d154663148e15733" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 341">341</a>, <a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0342" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0342_R_d154663148e15733" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 342">342</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
            
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0043"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/9ab83f58-4f4f-4aaa-9e78-eb63c66697c9/aenm202303833-fig-0043-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/9ab83f58-4f4f-4aaa-9e78-eb63c66697c9/aenm202303833-fig-0043-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/c6622d01-62ee-4cde-a470-bdf1ea85777c/aenm202303833-fig-0043-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/9ab83f58-4f4f-4aaa-9e78-eb63c66697c9/aenm202303833-fig-0043-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 43<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0043&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>

                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0044"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/35c55249-c771-4e7b-b8d5-2443e8f6a417/aenm202303833-fig-0044-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/35c55249-c771-4e7b-b8d5-2443e8f6a417/aenm202303833-fig-0044-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/5545e146-2957-4e00-9bb1-24284088b38e/aenm202303833-fig-0044-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/35c55249-c771-4e7b-b8d5-2443e8f6a417/aenm202303833-fig-0044-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 44<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0044&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>

                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
            <section class="article-section__inline-figure">
               <figure class="figure" id="aenm202303833-fig-0045"><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/a3f5c900-8542-49ba-aa69-00d918d841e5/aenm202303833-fig-0045-m.jpg"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/a3f5c900-8542-49ba-aa69-00d918d841e5/aenm202303833-fig-0045-m.jpg" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image" src="/cms/asset/801ed920-1e29-4b49-abf6-c4a8fba5fb69/aenm202303833-fig-0045-m.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/a3f5c900-8542-49ba-aa69-00d918d841e5/aenm202303833-fig-0045-m.jpg" alt="Details are in the caption following the image" title="Details are in the caption following the image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><figcaption class="figure__caption">
                     <div class="figure__caption__header"><strong class="figure__title">Figure 45<span style="font-weight:normal"></span></strong><div class="figure-extra"><a href="#" class="open-figure-link">Open in figure viewer</a><a href="/action/downloadFigures?id=aenm202303833-fig-0045&amp;partId=&amp;doi=10.1002%2Faenm.202303833" class="ppt-figure-link"><i aria-hidden="true" class="icon-Icon_Download"></i><span>PowerPoint</span></a></div>
                     </div>

[<span class="figureLink bibLink tab-link"><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0341" class="figureLink bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0341_R_d154663148e15804" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 341">341</a></span>].
