                  </figcaption>
               </figure>
            </section>
         </section>
         
         <section class="article-section__sub-content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0240">
            
            <h3 class="article-section__sub-title section2" id="aenm202303833-sec-0240-title">6.3 History of SIB Enterprises</h3>
            
            <div class="paragraph-element">Several enterprises are producing HC on a large scale using different precursors. As this topic was well reviewed recently in the literature,<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0037" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0037_R_d154663148e15817" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 37 - J. Energy Storage">37</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> we focus the last part of this review on the SIB enterprises. Over time, some SIB entreprises such as spin-offs from universities and academic work were created, some are companies developing only SIBs, and others are already LIB producers. Some enterprises declared bankruptcy and sold/gave up their patents, while others are still active as will be described below:

               <ol start="1" class="">
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>Aquion Energy (2008): Aquion Energy was established in 2008 as a spin-off from Carnegie Mellon University. Their battery was based on a sodium titanium phosphate anode, a manganese dioxide cathode, and a sodium perchlorate electrolyte. The company filed for bankruptcy in 2017 after receiving government and private loans. That property was sold to the Chinese manufacturer Julyine-Titans, who gave up most of their Aquion patents.</p>
                     </li>
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>Faradion (2011): Faradion was established in 2011 by Dr Jerry Barker, Dr Chris Wright, and Ashwin Kumaraswamy. Faradion is a subsidiary of Reliance Industries, India. Faradion's SIB cell design uses a HC anode and a lamellar oxide cathode with a liquid electrolyte. The company's pouch cells have energy densities comparable to commercial lithium-ion batteries (160 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup> at the cell level) with a rate performance up to 3C. The SIB claimed to have 1000 cycles (80% depth of discharge). In 2021, Faradion announced a collaboration and licensing deal with AMTE Power.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0337" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0337_R_d154663148e15833" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 337">337</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> On December 5, 2022, Farradion installed the first nationwide sodium-ion battery in New South Wales, Australia.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0343" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0343_R_d154663148e15838" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 343">343</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
                     </li>
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>TIAMAT (2012): TIAMAT is a spin-off from the sodium-ion task force of the CNRS/CEA established in 2012 and its H2020-EU project (646433), called NAIADES. The scientific board of TIAMAT includes leaders in academic research on energy storage materials (Prof. Jean-Marie Tarascon, Prof. Christian Masquilier, Prof. Patrice Simon, Dr Laurence Croguennec, and Dr Mathieu Morcrette). Two-generation SIBs were developed at TIAMAT in different formats (18650 cylindrical format, prismatic cells, and pouch cells). Generation 1 cathode materials are based on polyanion materials with achieved energy densities of 100 Wh to 120 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0338" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0338_R_d154663148e15849" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 338">338</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> The high power density and long lifetime cyclability (5000 cycles to 80% and 10000 cycles to 70% capacity at high current density charging in &lt;30 min and fast discharge in 12 min), along with battery safety, are breakthrough technologies behind SIBs. The safe transport of sodium-ion batteries under 0 V conditions eliminates the risk of commercial transport of such batteries. Generation 2 cathode materials are based on lamellar oxide materials with energy densities reaching 140 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup> and are projected to increase upon further development to 180 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>. Generation 2 cathode materials were first introduced in the H2020-EU project (875629), NAIMA, in 2022.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0344" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0344_R_d154663148e15859" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 344">344</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
                     </li>
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>Natron Energy (2012): A Stanford University spin-off, Natron Energy, uses an analog of Prussian blue for both the cathode and anode with an aqueous electrolyte. Natron Energy claims to be the world's leading provider of high-performance, long-life, cost-effective Prussian blue SIB solutions for critical power and industrial applications, material handling equipment for centers, and electric UPS systems. In 2020, Natron announced the world's first sodium-ion battery as it obtained its UL listing for its battery products in 1973 and began commercial shipments to customers in the data center, forklift, and EV quick charger markets.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0345" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0345_R_d154663148e15868" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 345">345</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup></p>
                     </li>
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>HiNa Battery Technology Co. Ltd (2017): HiNa Battery Technology Co., Ltd. was founded in 2017 and was a spin-off of the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS). It leverages research conducted by Prof. Hu Yong-Sheng's group at the CAS Institute of Physics. HiNa's SIB products are based on a unique copper (Cu)-based oxide chemistry and anthracite-derived soft carbon as the cathode and anode materials.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0346" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0346_R_d154663148e15877" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 346 - Engineering">346</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> In 2014, the research team at HiNa first discovered the electrochemical activity of the Cu<sup>3+</sup>/Cu<sup>2+</sup> redox couple in a P2-phase Na<sub>0.68</sub>Cu<sub>0.34</sub>Mn<sub>0.66</sub>O<sub>2</sub> material.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0347" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0347_R_d154663148e15895" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 347 - Chin. Phys. B">347</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> As a result, they can provide an energy density of 120 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>. In 2022, the MWh SIB-based energy storage system was put into operation by HiNa Battery Technology (Figure <a href="#aenm202303833-fig-0041">41</a>).</p>
                     </li>
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>Altris AB (2017): Altris AB is a spin-off of Angström Advanced Battery Center and Prof. Kristina Edstrom of Uppsala University in Sweden. The use of Prussian blue analogs as anode and cathode materials with nonaqueous electrolytes distinguishes the technology of this enterprise. The raw material availability, safety, and cyclability are the main advantages of Altris batteries and counterbalance the low-energy density of these SIBs.</p>
                  </li>
                  
                  <li>
                     <p>Contemporary Amperex Technology Co., Ltd. (2021): The Contemporary Amperex Technology Co., Ltd. (CATL) Chinese battery maker announced in 2021 that it would launch a sodium-ion-based battery by 2023. A Prussian white analog is used for the cathode, and carbon is used for the anode.<sup>[</sup><span><sup><a href="#aenm202303833-bib-0340" class="bibLink tab-link" id="aenm202303833-bib-0340_R_d154663148e15915" data-tab="pane-pcw-references" aria-label="Reference 340">340</a></sup></span><sup>]</sup> An AB battery pack solution can integrate sodium-ion cells and lithium-ion cells into one pack.</p>
                  </li>
                  </ol>
            </div>
            </section>
         </section>
      <section class="article-section__content" id="aenm202303833-sec-0250">
         
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title section1" id="aenm202303833-sec-0250-title">7 Conclusions and Perspectives</h2>
         
         <p>Na-ion batteries have gained significant popularity in the last decade. Research in this field has intensified mainly because of the necessity to find alternatives to current LIB technology. Many critical battery components and their uneven distribution along with geopolitical tensions contribute to the quest to find abundant, long-lasting, and cost-effective energy storage systems. SIBs perfectly meet these criteria, and their development has known an accelerated tendency. Hard carbons, which can be obtained from various precursors such as biomasses, biopolymers, and synthetic polymers, have become the most appealing anode materials for these batteries. The properties of HC are closely related to the parent precursors but are also significantly affected by the synthesis conditions (pyrolysis temperature, gas flow rate, synthesis pathway, etc.). Therefore, the structure (graphitic interlayer space, defects, and graphitic domain arrangement), the porosity (specific surface area, pore size, and volume), the morphology (particle shape and size), and surface chemistry (nature and amount of functional groups) can be tuned by the synthesis conditions. In general, it was observed that the HC properties are precursor dependent; however, biomass results in materials with higher porosity, interlayer space, and surface chemistry, synthetic polymer leads to lower values of these properties, while biopolymers fall in between these two categories. In addition, the pyrolysis temperature affects carbon properties in a similar manner, and the values of many properties typically decrease with increasing temperature. Some exceptions are to be noted, such as the increase of closed porosity with the pyrolysis temperature. Several syntheses – properties-dependent relationships – were shown in this direction in this review.</p>
         
         <p>The electrochemical performance of HC materials (iCE, capacity, and stability) was found to be strongly impacted by the HC properties. For example, the iCE is strongly related to the specific surface area, surface functionalities, and inorganic impurities. All these properties lead to electrolyte decomposition, the formation of the SEI layer, and low values of iCE. Therefore, the best iCE obtained is linked to materials that present limited porosity and chemistry. The composition and properties of the SEI layer are not yet fully understood; however, the formation of inorganic and organic species is more likely to govern the carbon/electrolyte interphase. With regard to the storage capacity, several works demonstrated that the mechanisms are connected with the adsorption-insertion phenomena of Na<sup>+</sup> on the carbon surface and in the structure. Although these mechanisms are still far from being fully understood, the insertion between the graphitic interlayer spaces and the adsorption of carbon defects mostly contribute to Na-storage. Nevertheless, the closed pore filling mechanisms still require additional comprehensive studies.</p>
         
         <p>Based on the knowledge gained from all these literature studies, an “ideal” HC should have a low specific surface area (&lt;10 m g<sup>−1</sup>), convenient graphitic interlayer space (3.7–3.8 Å) and no inorganic impurities, to ensure high iCE, capacity and stability. However, other properties such as defects, heteroatoms, and closed pores can be tuned to improve HC performance, but their role has not been precisely established/quantified yet.</p>
         
         <p>In addition to the carbon properties, the electrochemical conditions (electrode formulation, electrolyte/solvent type, and testing conditions) play an important role in the performance. The lack of standardization of such tests makes the comparison between the data in the literature difficult. Despite this inconvenience, this work presented several interesting property-performance correlations, which allow the readers to have a general overview in this direction.</p>
         
         <p>The reversible capacity of HC is rather high (&gt;300 mA h<sup>−1</sup>), approaching that of graphite in LIBs, while the iCE was progressively improved (max. 92%). It can still be enhanced by increasing the purity of HC, by selecting convenient electrolytes and electrochemical testing conditions. The main challenges to address are the stability and rate capability of HC. As many tests are done versus metallic Na, the performance of HC in full cells is more than required. We reviewed some of them herein, and moreover, the history of SIBs prototypes and enterprises was also described. As the SIB market begins to develop, this will induce more research and development on HCs, electrolytes, and cathodes, which will favor the implementation of renewable and abundant materials, low-cost SIB devices, and low CO<sub>2</sub> emission applications.</p>
         </section>
      <div class="article-section__content">

      <section class="article-section article-section__biography">
         <h2 class="article-section__title section__title" id="biographies">Biographies</h2>
         <div class="biographies">
            <ul class="rlist">
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/f22377e9-373d-4173-aec9-22576a4a4901/aenm202303833-gra-0002.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/f22377e9-373d-4173-aec9-22576a4a4901/aenm202303833-gra-0002.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/f22377e9-373d-4173-aec9-22576a4a4901/aenm202303833-gra-0002.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/f22377e9-373d-4173-aec9-22576a4a4901/aenm202303833-gra-0002.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Camélia Matei Ghimbeu</b> is a Research Director at the Material Science Institute in Mulhouse (IS2M), CNRS, France. She is the head of the “Carbon and Hybrid Materials” group at IS2M and a member of the French network of Electrochemical Storage of Energy (RS2E). She received her Ph.D. in 2007 from the University of Metz, France. Her research interests focus on the design of new carbon-based materials with controlled properties, their multiscale characterization, and their application in energy storage and environmental applications. For more than ten years, she has greatly contributed to the field of hard carbon materials for sodium-ion batteries.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/dfad32de-894f-4d2e-8ce5-944376ecbfd2/aenm202303833-gra-0003.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/dfad32de-894f-4d2e-8ce5-944376ecbfd2/aenm202303833-gra-0003.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/dfad32de-894f-4d2e-8ce5-944376ecbfd2/aenm202303833-gra-0003.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/dfad32de-894f-4d2e-8ce5-944376ecbfd2/aenm202303833-gra-0003.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Adrian Beda</b> is currently a Research Engineer at Mulhouse Materials Science Institute (IS2M), in France, involved in several national and international projects. After graduating from his engineering studies, he continued his academic track with a Master in Science from the University of Poitiers, France, and a PhD in Material Chemistry from the University of Haute-Alsace, France. At the moment, his main research interest focuses on developing and optimizing new hard carbon anode materials for sodium-ion batteries.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/e445e914-c9b8-4e05-94f5-aca3240d8082/aenm202303833-gra-0004.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/e445e914-c9b8-4e05-94f5-aca3240d8082/aenm202303833-gra-0004.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/e445e914-c9b8-4e05-94f5-aca3240d8082/aenm202303833-gra-0004.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/e445e914-c9b8-4e05-94f5-aca3240d8082/aenm202303833-gra-0004.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Bénédicte Rety</b> is a research engineer at the Mulhouse Materials Science Institute (IS2M), a CNRS-University mixed research unit in France. She is part of the French Research Network on Electrochemical Energy Storage (RS2E). She obtained her Master's degree in Materials Science in 2015 from the University of Haute-Alsace, France. She is responsible for a TPD-MS (Thermodesorption coupled with Mass Spectrometry) and a thermal treatment platform. She works on different projects involving the synthesis, activation, functionalization, and characterization of carbon materials and their applications in electrochemical energy storage, catalysis, and depollution.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/183c237d-0bda-453a-b49c-724c38d7325c/aenm202303833-gra-0005.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/183c237d-0bda-453a-b49c-724c38d7325c/aenm202303833-gra-0005.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/183c237d-0bda-453a-b49c-724c38d7325c/aenm202303833-gra-0005.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/183c237d-0bda-453a-b49c-724c38d7325c/aenm202303833-gra-0005.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Hamza El Marouazi</b> is a post-doctoral researcher at the Research Laboratory LHEEA at Ecole Centrale de Nantes, France. In 2021, he obtained his PhD in Materials Chemistry and Physics from the University of Strasbourg, France. In 2022, he joined the Mulhouse Materials Science Institute (IS2M-France) as a post-doctoral researcher on carbon materials for Na-ion batteries in Dr. Camélia Ghimbeu's group. He is focusing on the development of materials for green energy applications (solar cells, photocatalysis, hydrogen production, photo-reduction of carbon dioxide, fuel cells, energy storage, and biomass valorization).</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/8ef2fb2a-1845-42d8-9772-e73e7b67f84d/aenm202303833-gra-0006.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/8ef2fb2a-1845-42d8-9772-e73e7b67f84d/aenm202303833-gra-0006.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/8ef2fb2a-1845-42d8-9772-e73e7b67f84d/aenm202303833-gra-0006.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/8ef2fb2a-1845-42d8-9772-e73e7b67f84d/aenm202303833-gra-0006.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Alen Vizintin</b> is affiliated with the National Institute of Chemistry as a researcher. His research interests are in material science and electrochemistry. He has a particular emphasis on the study of carbon-based materials and nanomaterials, and has expertise in a range of characterization techniques in operando, in situ, and ex situ mode. In the last years his focus was on a) carbonaceous materials synthesis and surface functionalization for Na-ion batteries, b) electrochemistry of Na-ion and metal-S batteries, c) studying the reaction mechanism in Na-ion, metal-S, and organic batteries with operando spectroscopic characterization techniques.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/70ecf274-6156-45a1-bf61-edf897196bab/aenm202303833-gra-0007.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/70ecf274-6156-45a1-bf61-edf897196bab/aenm202303833-gra-0007.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/70ecf274-6156-45a1-bf61-edf897196bab/aenm202303833-gra-0007.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/70ecf274-6156-45a1-bf61-edf897196bab/aenm202303833-gra-0007.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Blaž Tratnik</b> is a research associate at the National Institute of Chemistry. His main research focus is the pyrolysis process and tailoring of physico-chemical properties of biomass-derived non-graphitizable carbons for Na-ion batteries. He has also dedicated his attention to conducting research on the reaction mechanisms in Na-ion batteries using various characterization techniques and exploring the electrochemical insertion of sodium into non-graphitizable carbons for Na-ion batteries.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/7e75ca2e-0266-4b86-8250-74aa63c76151/aenm202303833-gra-0008.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/7e75ca2e-0266-4b86-8250-74aa63c76151/aenm202303833-gra-0008.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/7e75ca2e-0266-4b86-8250-74aa63c76151/aenm202303833-gra-0008.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/7e75ca2e-0266-4b86-8250-74aa63c76151/aenm202303833-gra-0008.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Loic Simonin</b> has been working as a research scientist and project manager in CEA-LITEN for 15 years toward the development of new cathode and anode materials for both Li-ion and Na-ion batteries. He has been working as a project leader in many projects involving industrial and academic partners. He has been the coordinator of an H2020 project NAIADES (grant N° 646433) which led to the foundation of the Na-ion cells manufacturing RS2E spin-off company TIAMAT.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/9474490a-240e-4db2-b023-72aa29dc0c89/aenm202303833-gra-0009.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/9474490a-240e-4db2-b023-72aa29dc0c89/aenm202303833-gra-0009.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/9474490a-240e-4db2-b023-72aa29dc0c89/aenm202303833-gra-0009.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/9474490a-240e-4db2-b023-72aa29dc0c89/aenm202303833-gra-0009.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Julie Michel</b> is a Ph.D. student at CEA Grenoble, France, and UNESCO-IHE Delft, the Netherlands; she obtained her master's degree at the Nationale Graduate School of Chemistry of Montpellier (ENSCM), France, in circular economy and biomass valorization. Her research is focused on biomass-based carbon materials for energy storage applications. During the last three years, she devoted her work to hard carbon synthesis for Na-ion battery negative electrodes. In particular, to understand the fate of inorganics during biomass hydrothermal carbonization and pyrolysis to provide the materials with the best performance.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/cd6c4754-8d00-4742-aae0-75a19a8512f9/aenm202303833-gra-0010.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/cd6c4754-8d00-4742-aae0-75a19a8512f9/aenm202303833-gra-0010.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/cd6c4754-8d00-4742-aae0-75a19a8512f9/aenm202303833-gra-0010.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/cd6c4754-8d00-4742-aae0-75a19a8512f9/aenm202303833-gra-0010.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>John Abou-Rjeily</b> is the NAIMA H2020 European Project Coordinator and R&amp;D Scientist at TIAMAT in France. In 2019, he was awarded a Ph.D. in Physical Chemistry and Chemistry of Materials by the University of Tours in France where he was later recruited for a postdoc fellow. At TIAMAT, he is principally working on hard carbon engineering, doping, benchmarking, and industrial collaborations with international companies. In NAIMA, his work included prototyping industrial Na-ion batteries, electrolyte optimization, electrochemical cell testing, postmortem analysis, and Coordination.</p></li>
               <li><a target="_blank" href="/cms/asset/3fccf809-16e8-40d5-a547-d6d7d382fa22/aenm202303833-gra-0011.png"><picture>
                        <source srcset="/cms/asset/3fccf809-16e8-40d5-a547-d6d7d382fa22/aenm202303833-gra-0011.png" media="(min-width: 1650px)"><img class="figure__image author__thumbnail" src="/cms/asset/3fccf809-16e8-40d5-a547-d6d7d382fa22/aenm202303833-gra-0011.png" data-lg-src="/cms/asset/3fccf809-16e8-40d5-a547-d6d7d382fa22/aenm202303833-gra-0011.png" alt="image" title="image" loading="lazy"></picture></a><p><b>Robert Dominko</b> is a Research Professor at the National Institute of Chemistry and a Professor at the University of Ljubljana. He is the head of the battery group at the National Institute of Chemistry and deputy director of the ALISTORE-ERI network. His current research interests are focused on post-Li-ion batteries and the implementation of smart functionalities in battery cells. He is strongly connected with the Battery 2030+ initiative. He is a member of the Slovenian Academy of Engineering.</p></li>
            </ul>
         </div>
      </section>
      <section class="article-section article-section__references" id="article-references-section-1">
         <div class="accordion article-accordion">

</div></div></div>

        </section>
    

        </div>
    </div><!--end pagefulltext-->
</main>
